We've reached a point where challenging anything earns a ticket to the unemployment line.

pros:
+ The company promotes a friendly atmosphere. Most people are very polite.
+ Interesting work (at least it was for me)
cons:
- Not all teams care about work life balance. Some people end up working 60 hours a week.
- Disconnect between managers and engineers. They don't really seem to understand what's going on in the code, leaving it up to the engineer to explain to his/her manager why meeting a deadline is absolutely impossible working 40 hours per week.
- Middle management could do with some more training.
- Office politics is a big thing. The talker is valued more than the worker.
- Egos. Especially in some of the core development teams, there seem to be arguments between senior engineers all the time. Junior engineers really have no say.
- Most new hires look like international NCGs who are willing to work excessive overtime shifts, which might explain the shifting expectations of the engineering side.
- Average pay for 40 hours. Horrible pay if you're putting in 60, which is not uncommon.
- Not very diverse.

review_title: Still feels like a small company in a lot of (important) ways
pros: NetApp likes to hire smart people who are passionate about what they do. There are high expectations for performance and even higher expectations about collaboration. It takes a while to get decisions made (both big and small), but once they are made they are executed with extreme efficiency.  The company is nimble and can still operate like a small company in a lot of ways.  The emphasis on company culture is truly remarkable and lived by virtually all of the top level executives. There is a lot less corporate ego here than in other places. The top execs stand in line in the cafeteria like everyone else.
cons: Having a lot of passionate people makes conflict unavoidable and decision making slow. For the most part however, people are very respectful of conflicting opinions, come up with workable strategies and move forward together.  Short term decisions and investments and little process becomes quite problematic as the company grows.

review_title: Great company, great product, strong leadership, lots of opportunities.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros:
I have enjoyed working at NetApp for a lot of reasons:
- We have a vibrant culture with a lot of good people that work there
- Very good pay.
- Continuous growth. Not only is the data storage market continuing to grow, we are continuing to grow our share of the market.
cons:
Not a lot of downsides. In my nearly 8 years at the company, my career has only been limited by my lack of vision. When I have been driven to find opportunities, I have found them.
As with all companies, there are good managers to work for, and some not as good. I have been able to work for both at NetApp, and now that I am in management, am recognizing many areas that I need to work on to be more effective as a manager and leader. All in all, I have had a great experience at NetApp, and hope to continue to have a great experience here.

pros: Just a few weeks into my job. The Pro that I could notice that the teams have been giving a lot of attention to their work and deliverable. I have not seen a lot of chaos. Everybody seems to be sincere.
cons:
I observed that to keep the release dates intact employees are being asked to work over weekends. VP level seniors have asked team members to work on weekends as part of communication in all hands meeting.
Program Manager has no Program Management functional team in NetApp. Everyone - Development, QA, Program Management report into Director of Engineering. In my previous companies, Project/Program managers used to have a separate job function with Manager/Director of project/program management leading the team and reporting lines used to merge at VP level. This gave project/Program management function more fire power to get the work done and take independent and neutral decisions.

review_title: NetApp is no longer the best place to work for
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: NetApp is one of the leading companies in the enterprise storage industry, and employs some of the smartest and experienced engineers. I joined the company fresh out of college and owe most of what I know in my niche to the people I work with who are very humble and eager to share their knowledge.
cons: NetApp used to be the best place to work for, but these days no one talks of such thing anywhere in the company. It feels like everyone is burned out and unappreciated. Ad-hoc decisions are the norm, and management seem confused most of the time. While it is too early to write it off, most people here at NetApp seem to agree that this is the beginning of the end for traditional storage companies such as NetApp, EMC and HP.

review_title: Good, not great, for eng/prod mgmt
job_title: Senior Product Manager in Sunnyvale, CA
pros:
=> Very high trust environment.  For instance, no "expense report authorizations" required.  Just do what you think is right and don't abuse it
=> Not cut-throat, collegial
=> Successful company with good product portfolio
cons:
=> surprisingly old (lots more "30 year tech veterans from Amdol" than 5 year out of school kids)
=> Rampant title disparity, some corporate staff roles do zero work (and earn Senior Director or VP titles) while line jobs (eng, prod mgmt, sales mainly) are carrying a huge load for Manager or Director title.  Sounds petty, but it's really frustrating to the line
=>  Surprising amount of red tape in the product development orgs - we're talking 16 months to get a feature included in a new release, and getting slower!  Simply not nimble

review_title: Great salary and benefits in a passive-agressive culture
pros: Overall good benefits and intelligent people to work with. Executive team is top-notch and extremely focused - which is great for bonuses, stock and long term growth.
cons:
Middle management from VPs down is very passive-aggressive creating a fearful, caustic environment.
Major disappointment when the execs are candid and open.
Great company, great potential. Yet it has become just a another company to work for insted of a Great Place to Work. Too bad, what a waste.

review_title: A company that provides great technology but has very inefficient processes and support challenges.
pros: Great technology plain and simple, most innovative I have seen.  I love the products they work and customers love the technology and simplicity.
cons:
NetApp has a policy of no training to control cost that is frustrating.  No formal training on new products about new releases.  It is frustrating to see internal process that are years behind the rest of the industry compared to other tier 1 storage vendors I have worked for.
That includes support which does not understand the enterprise or more importantly how to develop empathy for a customers situation.

job_title: Member Of Technical Staff in Morrisville, NC
pros: This company has a great working atmosphere. Compensation & benefits to employees especially in RTP office are great. Lot of self driven people. The company offers opportunities to grow technically not just through the work but other initiatives as well. Unlike most companies out there, people love to share, explain or disseminate knowledge which is always a great help. Managers maintain clear communications with their teams about the charter and expectations.
cons: Playing catch up in a very dynamic business environment which can create undesired pressure among teams even though it's not the company's core culture, probably due to bad business foresight. Company has seen workforce cut due to that as well as slowdown in technical innovation as this big machine has a lot of moving parts today. Sometimes engineers with experience tend to be underpaid as compared to new UGH.

review_title: NetApp: A Great Place to Work
job_title: Member Of Technical Staff in Durham, NC
pros:
NetApp provides you with the some of the best benefits, including paid-time off to volunteer, party "beer-bash" every Friday at various NetApp sites, and many more. NetApp is still a relatively small company where you have a chance of contributing and getting proper recognition for the contribution. 
The culture is very open: the management communicates directly with employees and work with them to help the company grow. 
The promotions I have noticed usually happen from within and I think that people here have a vast set of career opportunities to choose from. 
One of the best things about working at NetApp is that the people you work with truly believe in their work and everyone actually wants to be here.
cons:
The NetApp compensation is at industry average, rather than being higher. 
I work at one the the remote site's of the company and it seems that the environment can be somewhat different at the remote sites than the headquarter in SVL.

review_title: Great place to work as a company
job_title: PS Field Employee in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Fantastic place to work based on work vs family life balance.  Executive management believes in striking a perfect balance.  Work hard play hard mentality.  Endless training opportunities in your field of employ in addition to personal development.  Great opportunity to move up the food chain of management as well.
cons: Some of the field management, in particular areas (read PS), are not seasoned or have the requisite experience to run departments.  Frustration can creep in if you allow it and do not fight for your rights as an employee.  It would be nice to have a manager who knows more then the people they manage, or at least shows interest in knowing more about the job.

review_title: Ranked highly as a "great place to work" ... because of the people
pros:
40 hour volunteer time each year
5 weeks of vacation after 10+ years service
Compensation is on par with industry average for Colorado
Super experienced employees with a ton of new opportunity for new college grads. Easy to transfer around dept to dept too so there is some opportunity for growth.
cons:
First level managers are awful. We do a terrible job of recruiting internally and end up hiring candidates into people-manager roles that have absolutely no business being there (lack empathy, are passive/aggressive, or just don't like people!). 

Managements ability to make a decision is painful - takes a long time, and causes much churn. We have yet to release a web-based product as the programs continue to take too long, go over budget, or resources are needed for other revenue-raising products.

pros: Lots of history and a good track record of making technical advancements.  Competitive pay.
cons: As a 20+ year old tech company, they have a lot of home grown tools that are not as modern as open source alternatives.  Things like burt (a homegrown bug reporting tool) that would be better swapped for bugzilla.  The language of choice for QA is perl, where most of the rest of the world moved to Python 10 years ago.  And finally, in 2015 they implemented a security measure called the Dome that forces all engineers to access their engineering work via a remote desktop to a virtual machine.  The whole engineering network is disconnected from the world.  You can't access the web from the Dome.  You can't get your mail from the dome.  So, half of your work is on your laptop's interface and the other half is from this cut off environment where doing necessary things like system updates is exponentially harder than it should be.

review_title: A once great company has lost it's way
job_title: Solutions Marketing Manager in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: There are a lot of great people at NetApp and the culture has long been a strong asset. Their benefits are fair and in Sunnyvale, they offer cool perks, such as an excellent gym, with exercise classes, regular running events (the NetApp 5K), massages, and personal trainers. You have to pay for the massages and personal trainers, but they are on-site, which is nice!
cons: They have run out of steam. While others have innovated, NetApp has floundered. I work for a competitor now, and wish both could do well, but unfortunately that's not likely. Many people I know from NetApp are sick and tired of years of lay-offs. So many people have been let go, or have left to seek better employment elsewhere.

review_title: What was simple is now complex
pros: NetApp is customer focused. Customers are now more than ever re-evaluating how they store information, so NetApp is adapting to these changes. Due to these changes there are many opportunities and positions were new employees are needed and can make a difference. A lot of great people to learn from.  Compensation is on par with other storage vendors.
cons: NetApp culture has been changing rapidly over the past few years. Experienced employees feeling less valued looked into other opportunities outside of NetApp and found them easily. With the increase in attrition there are several key experience voids for new employees to fill, though it takes time for those new employees to come up to speed causing project delays.  Leaderships focus to improve upon project delivery time frames has created more top down management pressure which often results in less flexibility and can reduce creativity for individual contributors.

pros: Good work and Good Engineers around
cons:
Lots of uncertenities around whether you have job tomorrow and which is the team and group you will be working after 3-6 months. Lots of changes in the Engineering ladder is killing the company.

my group was told, there is change in the whole company org structure in 60 days once. But after 60 days, they asked for another 90 days time and said, there is a drastic change in direction after 90 days. These things kill the happiness and force people out of NetApp.

People are commodities they fire when they want and hire when they want. This is not based on performance in many cases, but based on the changes in product strategies which happens "very" often. so NO respect for employees and their outcome.

review_title: It all depends on the management
pros: NetApp is one of those companies that sucks you in with a lot of perks such as a gym, quarterly beer bashes, and 3 cafes. It's a high profile company and has been rated in the top ten best places to work for about 5 years running.
cons: The perks aren't free, they expect you to pay by being available all the time. The company is rated in the top 10 places to work because they offer employees an additional day off if they make it on the list. The company culture is a bit cold and people don't have much of a sense of team cohesiveness but untimately, I think it depends on your management. That is what really determines how you are going to do at a company. I had both good and bad management.

review_title: Be Nice culture and polite conduct to a fault, management needs to be more effective
pros: Polite conduct is the norm, trusting everyone is professional and uses good judgement.  Most employees are seasoned professional, and are courteous when interact with others.  Accept best effort.  Management consider Fortune's "Top 100 Best Company to Work For" a big deal.
cons: Management is ineffective in getting stock price up, and lack of foresight on how the company will perform.   Finance is weak on providing financial guidance and business partnership.  Marginal performer and slackers can survive fine as long as they social to be liked.  People who get promotions are the "nice to play with" ones and not the most knowledgeable and capable ones.  Senior management don't solicit employees feedback to improve functional performance.

pros: Good culture and nice people to work with. Company has open culture and is less hierarchical. It's easy to reach out to anybody in the company.
cons: Lot of things work on network and connection. It's hard to get opportunities without good network. Tendency to create a closed knit group serving each other interests.It's common to see people without performance record continue or being promoted at the senior level.

review_title: "NetApp Culture" is a shallow as a press release
pros:
5 days of volunteer time off (this looks good in press releases, so we find budget for it)
my local org is great (great people with integrity) - corporate level, not so much
cons:
New hires only get 6 days of vacation a year (they call it 12, but 6 mandatory shutdown days aren't really vacation days)
For low cost investment options, the 401k is ranks 4th out of the 5 tech companies I've worked for.

review_title: Depends on who your manager is???
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros: Great facility, decent benefits, and gym on-site.
cons: All though it's a "best place to work" company, all is relevant. I worked for the company for 3 yerars, and was happy there. Made a mistake of getting close to my manager and knowing too much about her personal life as well as sharing about mine. ...Hard lesson learned. Got booted out right before that person got promoted.... I saw the ball rolling, and could do nothing about it. Manager just went to HR and created completely untrue occusations. Said I can have flex hours to come in, and then fired me for "being late for work". Seriously? And that's after I worked nights and weekends, without really declaring those extra hours....I guess I knew too much for her taste. Well, not such a great place to work if you get booted out by one person. Hard to judge company in a good light when one person can have so much power and HR just does what they are told.

review_title: Overall great place to work unless in support
job_title: Technical Support Manager in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Great salary, benefits and bonuses.  Also great technology to learn.  Decent number of opportunities within the company to move to different roles over the course of several years.
cons: The support organization lacks enabled leadership.  Management has very little span of control up to the senior levels.  This creates an environment where executive orders are passed down but then management is not enabled to effectively complete those goals.  It also does not allow front line management the flexibility to make improvements where needed to retain top talent.  Finally, there is a major degree of separation between those with the authority and those with the knowledge to implement effective change.  Then end result is senior technical resources frustrated with neutered management.

review_title: Was once a great place to work, now just an "ok" place to work.
pros: Fast paced, autonomy, generally positive place to work.  Rapidly growing with good benefits and fair compensation.
cons: Increasingly bureaucratic.  Was a much better place to work a few years ago.  Run like an 8000 person start up and VERY silo-ed with a poor systems infrastructure.   Little opportunity for true career advancement.  Culture turning into a caste system of haves and have-nots.

review_title: 'Great place to work' is pure hogwash
job_title: Member Of Technical Staff in Bangalore
pros: Flexible work hours, Work from home.
cons: Lots of problems, I am yet to meet anyone I would call 'smart' in Bangalore centre. Most IITians do not consider it as a worthwhile option. Culture of pretend expertise and incumbent worship is huge. GPTW is no more than a blue pill for the semi drone types, which form the bulk of the engineering team.  An aging technology stack keeps getting more and more bloated and ridiculously complex with time. No emphasis on code quality/conciseness, functions with 30k loc and tens of 'if'  statements are considered 'routine' when the FOSS community scoffs at anything over 2k. Facing financial distress lately, reasons for which are easy to guess. With btrfs shaping up the way it is, Netapp can only go the HP way. Processes and working styles already are so heavy weight, they have measurable gravitational field. Compensation is inadequate.

review_title: NetApp is struggling with its transition to a mature, "big company" culture.
pros: Amazingly maintained gross margins.   Effort put in to "a great place to work."  Technology that you can win with.   Good education system and good communication within the company.  Slowing yet still strong revenue growth.
cons: Culture is turning into a "big company" with Fiefdoms developing and more and more politics.   Management is making the fatal mistake of attributing NetApp's success to their own actions feeding a significant and growing ego problem with the decision makers.   Significant defections in the technical ranks to companies like:  Whiptail, Isilon/EMC, Atlantis Computing, X-IO, Pure Storage, Nimbus, TinTri, and even VMware.

review_title: NetApp is a Software Company not a Hardware Company-->Chose only if you want to be in Software
pros:
1. Is a good storage domain software company and has good reputation in the market and performed consistently over some years
2. Has Good Open Minded Friendly culture
3. And as they pay descently compared other companies, except a good amount of work
cons:
1. Most people do not work at the Hardware Layer and join if you are interested in software
2. If you want to work at Storage Drivers,Firmware,Protocols,Storage Hardware Components, then do not join this company.
3. Should encourage people mastering technical skills,troubelshooting skills,deployement skills and should alot some free time in quarter for learning purpose(both external and internal sources).
4. Join this company if you want to build your career in automation like perl,C#,python,C,C++, as people who have this skills will have more value then people having broad range technical skills in storage and Storage networking domain.

pros: They have a very nice facility and all.  The personal and work life balance is ok also.  Compensation is just average compared to the companies I worked for before.
cons: They are very disorganized.  The department that I worked for does not value the people who are actually doing the job.  If you are not part of the people that interact with the customer, you are nobody.  At one time, our team has to deal with the issue that the customer is having.  The engineer (or so they say) that was in charged to help them couldn't figure out what to do to the point that they replaced an entire rack of units.  Our teammate was asked to assist and found out right away that it was a power distribution problem.  After a while, the department head sent out an email congratulating the no-good engineer and no mention of my colleague who actually found the problem.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: New CEO George Kurian is awesome, well- liked & respected, very warm & inspiring.  We have an enviable product line, GREAT engineering & development, customers that love NetApp & want to see us succeed.  Culture & values are strong and powerful force for good, people really LOVE this company & the respectful approach to business
cons: CEO Tom Georgens recently asked to step down by board, FAR too many layoffs in recent years- we lose REALLY great people.  Morale is taking a hit & we have some in leadership roles that don't mirror the company culture & values...not cool

review_title: Lacking in direction, focused only on Wall Street
job_title: Technical Support Engineer III in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: There are a number of great people still at NetApp.  The people in the trenches make the business work.
cons:
Promotions are next to impossible to earn.  Instead of promoting based on merit, the whole organization has to compete for reqs, and the reqs go to favored senior managers, who then promote based on political agendas.  Escalation Engineers avoid taking cases like the plague and tens to hoard knowledge instead of fostering team growth.  

The Financial organization is devastating the company as it bows to pressure from an activist investor who really doesn't care about the future of the company or its supremely loyal customers.

review_title: Good company, lot of fun events, great exec lvl mgt,,, pay, promotions, bonuses are so so
pros: Raleigh office - Every friday is beer bash, work stops around 3:30 and they bring down kegs for everyone to drink and some small snacks and beer food. They have had in the past casino night maybe once a year, a little carnival, and other events for the employees and their family where they give out prizes. They also have a pool table, a ping pong table, and a small but useful gym when you are working late.
cons: I spent five years at the company as a system administrator under different titles; two years as an intern and three years under three different contractors. In my time there I experienced a lot of first line manager turnover when my office was transitioning, because they were promoting the wrong people in my particular group. Finally, I'm fairly young and felt some serious age-ism, but not sure that is Netapp specific. Money related compensation is sub-par, but the benefits are worth it for many people, especially engineers.

pros: Top Notch Health and Investment Benefits, Exceptional Onsite Facilities including cafeteria and full gymnasium, People and Culture,  A willingness to always do what's right for the customer, camaraderie among co-workers and
cons: NetApp is still stuck in the 90's with their business model.  They are hesitant to invest in back-end technology to take their customer service to the bleeding edge in leadership.  Moving up the corporate ladder within NetApp is extremely difficult.  There are few opportunities for advancement and the ones that are available you must interview 4 or 5 rounds for in front of 10 to 20 people.  With the latest R.I.F. they did not compensate their highly tenured employees with a justifiable severance package.

review_title: Indeed a Great Place to work at
pros: Some of the smartest people in the industry. You'll always find someone willing to help you. Culture is great, the tech is great and they treat people with respect. Great place to collaborate! Company open to internal criticism and ideas. It's a unique environment and personally, I was treated very well, enjoyed being part of it but it was time for me to move on.
cons: It has become a slow moving train due to its size. Too many meetings and committees. A little too much politics as well. Limiting career opportunities because the company has not been growing as before.

review_title: Good company and benefits but 1st and 2nd level management not too good.
pros:
Good benefits such as health, vision, dental but these are being chiseled away.
Great stock purchase plan, two year price fix can make the plan very lucrative.
Nice facilities including several decent cafeterias, gym has towel service and classes such as spin, yoga, etc.
Company is well positioned to succeed in the marketplace if can deliver.
cons:
Forced distribution will eventually mark you as "needs to improve".   Ranking is sort of like playing in recreational league where you self-referee, the level of play is always one or two levels above the level of officiating (i.e. management)

Not possible to do a good job because too much to do and nobody wants to hear it.  If you raise concerns about not having enough time or resources, management will keep leaning on you until you change your answer.

pros:
Positive environment
Competitive product portfolio
Opportunity for growth
Great work/life balance
Interesting market potential
cons:
Highly skilled and nice employees whom lack of candor when it is needed most
Inconsistent development methods leading to poor cross functional collaboration
Outdated engineering tools could use refresh (+ slow adoption for new tool exists)
*Often areas for individual learning and growth are not well defined (varies - might be intentional)
Management does recognize many of these issues and they are being addressed (although, it would be recognized faster if employees had more candor)

pros:
Generally, the people I work with are nice, and my direct management has been great to work for. Unfortunately, the higher up the food chain you go, the more rotten it gets. Fortunately I can work from home, which is much less depressing than being in the office.
Not sure who fills out those "Best Place" to work surveys, but it sure looks good from the outside!
cons: A company that is clearly in decline - layoff, followed by a mass exodus, building closings, a steady rate of attrition and the constant threat of more layoffs. The openings never seems to get filled, workloads and pressure go up, and more leave. They certainly aren't doing much to keep people.

pros: Compensation is decent.  Great people to work with as long as they're not in Sunnyvale.  Free coffee, bagels & cookies and Beer Bash.
cons: Silos.  Also, lots of lip service without accompanying actions/improvements.  Many upper managers in Sunnyvale are arrogant and incompetent and do not comprehend the most basic good business  and leadership practices.  They spend most of their time trying to justify their positions and posturing.  Company has been heading southwards since 2011 too.  Not sure how much longer they'll be around.  I was never impressed with George Kurian.  Never seemed to have an original idea or plan of his own.  Always seemed like someone else was pulling the strings.

review_title: Was a great place to work...
pros: When I first started, the company was dynamic, growing and the exec mgmt. always wanted to do the right thing.  As the company things changed, but they strived hard to keep the 'culture' and for the most part they succeeded.   Biggest change was when Tom Georgens resigned.
cons: After Tom G, the company strived hard to make corrections thru priorities of investment in order to 'right the ship'.  Unfortunately, those changes cost the company it's soul as they lost their way in both market leadership and people leadership.  The collaborative culture that once defined NetApp still exists, but it is in pockets now and hard to find.  It's been replaced by a standard corporate culture with politics and drama being the new standard.

pros: Decent work/life balance, fun perks on the campus such as a gym, cafeteria, and Friday "beer bash" which is a company sponsored on-site happy hour.  If you want it there is a ton of free training and good sales coaching from middle management, plus great industry experience. Nice incentives for performance.
cons: There is way too much management and the sales team is pressured from multiple directions. Micro managing is the new trend and not only will your dials and call time be tracked but you'll be asked to log what type of call you were making. For all the management there is actually little direction to help you learn the sales process. Goals are split with a field rep so you can't make your number unless that person is successful. It's VERY hard to make good money as an ISR here.

review_title: Great place to work rating falling
job_title: Marketing Specialist in San Jose, CA
pros:
The employee benefits and work life balance are very good.  Employee training is great and you are expected to attend regular training sessions to improve your management skills and awareness.  Employees are generally friendly  
& focused on their work.
cons: There is an undercurrent of frustration and uncertainty that runs through marketing among the various teams.  A large part of that is the constant budget battle and changes within the organization which take place on a fairly regular basis resulting in confusion about how they are going to accomplish the goals that have been outlined. The higher the level of management, the less in touch with the actual challenges the budget issues evoke among the teams, limiting the ability for cross-functional cooperation.

pros: Seeing how badly a company can be run really is a learning opportunity.  In comparison with the shambles that is NetApp I think I can be happy almost anywhere.  I agree with several other posters in saying that someone must like them as they achieve high GPTW ratings - but I have no idea how this happens.
cons: NetApp's fundamental philosophy is "drive by selling" to make the quickest buck.  They have no concept of quality control.  They have no understanding of after-sales support, nor any desire whatsoever to aquire one.  They burn out workers, particularly engineers, who are treated almost like factory assembly line staff.

review_title: Was a great place to wrok
job_title: Member of Technical Staff IV in Sunnyvale, CA
pros:
Good technology if you are in core data storage areas
Good pay & benefits
cons:
We can create a linked list of management chain with the link property set as personal acquaintence. Talent is irrelevent in selecting people in high positions - favoritism rules. Managers form opinion not based on rsults of work but on the opinion of their favorite "lead". Very bad for energetic neutral engineers who are not "aligned" to management drinking cool-aid.

There are quite a few good managers around and if you are lucky to be with them, your life is good. Having few product lines, job rotation is not an option and best way to advance your career path is to leave for a better job.

review_title: Unclear and ever-changing strategy & vision.  Communication is not good.
pros: Decent salaries.  Some good and very bright people are still remaining.  Good benefits.
cons:
The culture has changed completely.  Morale is the lowest I have seen it.  Lots of rumors circulating.  Hoping that things become clearer after the new fiscal year starts.  If not, I don't see much hope here.  Some good acquisitions have been made by NetApp but the track record in incorporating these products into the portfolio is horrible.  Most of those products have ended up being discontinued.  
Forcing people to take vacation twice a year for company shut downs is not good for people new to the company because they have not accrued much vacation yet.

pros: Some good people. Work life balance, OK. Good social scene. Reasonable benefits/package.  Mature and committed channel.
cons: The obsession for 'best place to work' is a smokescreen as this only applies to internal staff, not everyone.  The good feelings arent being felt by everyone.  Products are being beaten from all corners due to a lack of genuine innovation; they are not only overly complex but cDOT was a concept most customers didnt want but had no choice but to adopt.   Crazy changes in accounts each year leave salespeople at the whim of management and the good politicians take the spoils.  Massive staff turnover in this last year with lots of leavers.   The company takes its most two most prized assets, its staff and channel partners for granted; how could either want to move away, we're NetApp?  At least EMC doesnt hide its dislike of its channel.  Senior management have completely lost any connection with the coal face.

pros: Generally low stress. Company pays attention to corporate culture. For senior/longer term employees incentive plan is pretty good. Good intern program which is fun for the junior employees.
cons: Bureaucratic nightmare developing after several weak quarters. Development and release cycle is much longer than rest of industry. Company is falling behind in innovation, engineering staff has lost faith in the vision of this company. Upper management is playing musical chairs and seems more interested in cost cutting than in moving the company forward. Company is totally driven by quarterly results and has little interest in the future.

review_title: Balanced Work LIfe but Management Sucks
job_title: Member of Technical Staff III in Bangalore
pros:
Facilities are good
Work life balance
Health insurance is good.
cons:
> MTS1 will be promoted to MTS2 in an year. BASELESS
> Compensation is average being an Engineering company, they just tend to keep it above EMC2
> Middle level management is a waste, some are arrogant and too much process oriented
> They have increased the MTS1 package abruptly but the same has not been done for other MTS bands.
> Feedback system is unsafe. I can't rely on my manager words of mouth to give a feedback over email. 
>  BEER BASH is a waste of money. STOP IT. Rather give some free lunch or dinner. makes for sense. Its a software company not  a PUB.
> Favoritism is in abundance and management is not transparent.
> unstable times between 2014 - 2016. Layoffs were frequent like a childs play

job_title: Support Account Manager in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: NetApp is positioned in the industry in such a way that one can gain exposure in many different cutting edge technologies. As a company the culture is wonderful and ripe for learning. Depending on what section of NetApp you work in you can feel as if your getting paid to go back to school.
cons: Currently, NetApp is in a transition phase. For current the employee, this can be scary but these changes if executed well will place NetApp not just with the current industry but ahead of it and back to being a leader.

pros:
- for the most part a great team
- some great technical expertise in certain teams
- access to lots of technical training (internal and external)
- career growth possible (although sometimes hindered, see minuses)
- fair package
- flexibility
cons:
- typically more managers than years in the company
- some say the only thing that never changes is change (can be good or bad ..)
- career growth can be hindered if you're "useful" in your current position
- management may stay in place if they're conformist
- stress level in technical support was high, but management did not prioritize that issue
- HR was horrible for the most part (i.e. never representing the employee's interest, but only the employer's ..)

review_title: A customer and employee focussed organisation
job_title: Sales Operations Manager in London, England
pros: NetApp always want to do the "right thing" for customers, employees and shareholders.   There is emphasis on the positive culture which includes ethics and standards of conduct that everyone is expected and does adhere to.  The company is well organised and knows what its products and services are and how to sell them to customers and with partners.  Many of the roles are challenging and everyone is expected to take responsibility for themselves and work collaboratively with others. I recommend NetApp both as company to work for or to do business with.
cons: Needs to be more proactive with planning and execution.  Often relies too much on the good-will and excessive working hours of the responsible employees.

review_title: Great people, good executive management, not-so-great middle management.
job_title: Technical Support Engineer in Raleigh, NC
pros: The benefits at NetApp are great and the pay compared to other, non-IT companies is above average. The people who work there tend to be good, fun people on a personal level and are on the whole incredibly bright.
cons:
Depending on who is your manager, your experience can vary widely. In general management does not do a good job of making sure information flows all the way down the ladder, nor does it solicit input from those two or more steps below on the hierarchy. It is often said that management is open to input, just make sure it is not something they do not want to hear.

Because employees are very intelligent, they also tend to have an ego. This causes friction when neither party can accept that they may be wrong.

review_title: A great hell to work, the worst place I ever been
pros: Good package and good products
cons:
Great place to work if ......
You have no kids , you are 200% dedicated to the company & NO LIFE TIME. After 1 year inside NetApp I said that great place to work at NetApp is just an illusion. What they call great place to work is just because after a hard day work you can go and drink a beer with your manager  and colleague...What a great fun !!!
 A very pyramidal and hypocritical management with a few core midle manager team who are competing each day to be closer to the direction....No real diversity ....etc....Culture and value are exclusively money, rolex and porshes oriented. Good place if you like exclusively sport , luxury cars and watch and live close with no kids, because there is no life time balance.

review_title: Not always a great place to work
pros: So far, there has been a lot of flexible work options - work at home some days and work a split schedule.  This flexibility has been a real lifesaver as a working parent.  The pay is pretty good and most of the people are dedicated to their jobs.  There are still occasional beer busts, and free food sometimes.  Finally,  the volunteer time off is a unique benefit and it has been wonderful to be able to give back to the community.
cons: After the last reorg, there have been almost daily fire drills with no end in sight.  While it doesn't seem to be a widespread problem, there is one senior manager who seems to be playing favorites, going so far as to only greet certain team members, so the situation is rather tense.

pros: NetApp has done a great job in prior years of hiring excellent engineers.  As a manager I'm constantly challenged by my teams and that has been very refreshing.  There are still pockets of the original NetApp culture, but you need to search for them because not all TG;s are created equal.
cons: NetApp executives talk about being a pay-for-performance company, but the forced performance quota's based on headcount are in direct conflict with this creating internal competition at the individual contributor levels instead of teams all working with the same objectives.  NetApp has gone through two realignments (re: layoffs) in the last 10 months letting go some excellent talent without an effort to re-assign internally.

review_title: It's true, NetApp is a great place to work.
pros: Fantastic collaborative culture.  Best storage technology out there with a future in hybrid cloud, flash and software defined storage.  Good training and reasonable hours.   Great customers.
cons: I feel that the culture is shifting a bit.  As NetApp is making the transition to cloud there are growing pains such as retention.  People are attracted to "flashy" new things.  As a result, some newer folks know less of the culture and as result, SEs, TAMs and even PS are starting to feel like more of  a commodity instead of an integral piece of an account team.

pros: Company is very competitive when it comes to compensation.  Most people do not leave the company for other offers since the compensation at NetApp cannot be matched by other Bay Area employers. It's a good working environment and not much stress.   The offshore is strong and responsive, which makes the onshore/offshore model easier to execute.
cons: Lack of strategy when it comes to the product side.  The vision of the company is becoming less and less appealing to the market. Company needs new technology to be able to survive in the storage and software market. Need to invest in acquiring new talents that can elevate the company.

review_title: It is too good to be true, but it is....
pros: NetApp is a company that provides me with challenges and encourages my "entrepreneurial spirit."  I am empowered.  My opinions and ideas are important and valued.  We work hard, but we get to work with wonderful and talented people who respect and value one another, nothing is taken for granted.  This is a company where you know you can make a difference and will.  The senior leaders are committed to sharing information promptly and candidly.  There is  "real" commitment to the employees and ensuring that NetApp is a great place to work.
cons: NetApp is a fast growing company.  If you need a lot of direction or set processes and procedures to do your job well, this is not the company for you.  It is a very fast paced (hectic) environment with little structure at the moment.

pros:
-Some ability to WFH
-Decent salary
-Good location
cons:
-Sexist
-Discriminatory
-If you are even slightly overweight, be prepared to be fired (of course they'll make up an excuse as to why you're being "let go" when you find out months later it's because you were too heavy).
-Liars and master manipulators (they tell you you're going to get X amount of bonus or raise, and low and behold, they LIED to your face, claiming "performance issues" even though if it weren't for you, they'd NEVER have anything completed--hmm, how is that performance based???!!)
-Lack of basic communication
-Annual review process and ratings severely flawed
-Too many senior level managers with no care to anything/anyone but themselves and their insanely high salaries
-If you're a hard worker, be prepared to be abused while other "slackers" are praised
-Never give you credit for your hard work or amazing outcomes, take your credit instead
-The Sr. level managers have a very "old school" approach to how they treat women in the workplace, they are LUCKY I didn't sue them for sexual harassment!
-ZERO growth!!
-Way too many political games!!
-Big time favoritism and clique's all over!
-Mind games and game playing is a "norm"

pros: Great people, culture and benefits.  Easy to move around into different roles.  Colleagues really want to collaborate to brng the best solution for the customer
cons:
NetApp Exec. Mngt is not doing enough to entice people to stay.  This is more about time to market with game changing technologies then benefits. Ex: Spinaker integration took far too long and FlashRay is still not released either.  NetApp has lost its innovation edge and as storage is becoming a simple commodity it is not doing enough to stay ahead of the competition.
y

review_title: Best company that I have ever worked for!
pros:
NetApp management's interactions with staff are based upon candor, honesty, and respect 
for individual contributions.  Managers are committed to earning the trust and confidence of their teammates. 

As a group, we achieve synergy through the skills and ideas of all participants. Through collaboration, we strive for win/win solutions to issues and problems.  Personal success is realized through team achievements. And as part of the NetApp team, I feel that I have the support and backing to be successful in my career.

NetApp cares about its employees and its contractors, which is rare. If you are a contractor, you are treated with the same respect as an employee, and are never treated like a second class citizen.
cons: There are not many downsides. Perhaps the only downside that comes to mind is that we might over communicate to our internal staff at times. So perhaps we need to have a more solid communications plan in place.

review_title: Can NetApp stamp out the politics?
pros: Very collaborate, positive and team oriented culture. Sales & support drive high levels of customer loyalty. Can do attitude permeates when the organization gets focused. Good benefits with volunteering encouraged and good 401k matching program. Smart people throughout the company.
cons: Politics has entered into the culture at NetApp and not in a good way in recent years and it has hurt internal decision making which used to be a strength. Specially prevalent in the TD community unfortunately. Still very engineering led and have repeatedly missed important market trends because of it, so playing catch up versus leading in a lot (most?) areas.

review_title: Cheap, cheap, cheap... but the people are great!
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Huge pool of some of the most talented engineers I have worked with. The most open management team I have ever seen.
cons: Don't believe the hype. For those that are there that chant at very company meeting "Its the best place to work", they must have worked at some horrible places. Technical Directors are a role without mandate with an inability to execute on a vision. Management that spends time managing up rather than be honest with the reality of what we were doing.

pros: Good people. I enjoyed the people I worked with. They had integrity and upper management was open to new ideas and willing to attempt challenging activities to succeed.
cons: Portfolio is mired in old technology that the market has limited demand for. The few new offerings NetApp has are not adequate to overcome the legacy ball and chain. The Data Fabric story was unique and compelling two years ago, but NetApp couldn't monetize the story then. And now it isn't unique anymore. Cloud kicked NetApp's butt. The talent flight away from NetApp in 2015 was the heaviest I had ever seen at any employer. My own team had almost total churn in 18 months (out of a dozen or so people).

review_title: Still a great company, candid transparent leadership
pros:
Excellent benefits
Great culture even after layoffs and downturns there's no question those of us who remain are treated well.
Exciting leadership with Dave Hitz, Dave Wright from SolidFire and George Kurian.  All blatantly honest, visionaries.
cons:
Crowded shrinking technology space, with the rise of cloud the Enterprise IT market is shrinking, but the number of competitors in the market keeps growing.
Big company makes pivots in focus painful and difficult, puts us at risk of not being able to shift fast enough with the rest of the market.

pros: The company has a pretty good benefits program. Flexible working hours, work from home, volunteer time off. Health benefits very decent.
cons:
Lack of career opportunities and development path.
Definitely play favoritism.
Of late management doesn't seem to truly listen.
Major lack of communication between corporate administrative functions and the business units. This is a huge issue and becoming worse.
Performance review process does not work. I received a one rating for three is running, was promised a promotion each year. And never received it. Extremely disheartening, which is why I left.

review_title: Hoping they can turn the ship around
job_title: Professional Services Consultant in Dallas, TX
pros: Great work environment, very flexible, good benefits. Lots of free training and new technology. Decent pay for most parts of the country, but probably not enough to live on comfortably in the Sunnyvale/San Jose area, at least for most non-sales types.
cons: Repeated RIFs have devastated morale. Most recently they let go of a bunch of E-Series sales & support folks, with very little warning, right before the holidays. I know OEM sales were struggling, and SolidFire is supposedly the new hotness, but still, c'mon guys.

review_title: OCI Software Quality Management a Disaster
job_title: Principal Software Engineer in Waltham, MA
pros: NetApp has a great name, and good work/life balance.  Vacation time is not bad too.
cons: OCI quality management process is slow, and the tools used are outdated.  Too much time is spent educating the manager as she lacks technical skills and always relies on someone to cover her up and do the work. Promotions these days are rare, and when a promotion happens, they are given to those that do not really deserve it. They are normally the people that kiss up to management. Culture has deteriorated greatly, and those that are able to  probably already left. Those that are remaining are there only for certain reasons.  Such an unprofessional work environment OCI has transformed into.

review_title: Netapp: Not #1 but #1,000 place to work.
pros: Beer on fridays.  Steady hours.
cons: Lack of proper training and preparation to support their products. Favoritism, isolation, micromanagement, lack of technical experience within management.  Weak internal interaction.  Customers are constantly lied to and not supported properly. Netapp makes promises to customers and employees just to make the Fortune and top 100 companies to work for.  Employees with lack of storage experienced are hired and told that they would be trained and mentored properly but infact they get thrown on the telephones to answer high end deep knowledge questions where in many cases the customers know more and are told to lie to the customers so they are satisfied with whatever answers are provided until the case is closed or customer is temporarily satisfied.

review_title: Company has great products and is well positioned, but has become political bureaucracy
pros: Good to great people to work with, good pay and benefits, great products that meet customer needs, company is well positioned in the storage market, strong executive team.
cons: Many long time NetApp people, therefore company suffers from lack of mid-level managerial talent and competence. Certain groups (Marketing, Professional Services, Management Software Product Group) are disorganized and dysfunctional. Many mid-level managers and some VPs better at managing up and managing their own positions then managing their own team and growing their people. Inability to set measurable goals and assess performance leads to "focal review by popularity."

review_title: Not a great place to work
pros: Work place and environment is okay. Beer bash and soft drinks for free.
cons:
- The Bangalore center is predominantly involved in maintenance and low end QA work
- The work culture resembles a IT services company than a product company
- Air is thick with politics with a very thick layer of top management. 
- Most of the top management in India have got a level higher promotion in Netapp as compared to other organizations like Cisco, HP, EMC, Dell and others
- Performance appraisals are a farce. Cronysim and Sychophants have a field day in the company even if they have brought nothing of value. 
- Layoffs and Organizational changes are very frequent and there are not based on performance. Most teams who were doing product development work with significant ownership have been laid off and the residual teams are into low end maintenance and QA work
- HR is rude and arrogant and aligns with top management rather than employees. Candor is tolerated and people who have concerns are slowly made to leave.

review_title: Working at NetApp is generally good, but can be frustrating with the constantly changing requirements to do your job.
pros:
Great training with quite knowledgeable trainers.
Work your shift without having to take work home. Good work-life balance.
Nice to not have to worry about how you dress.
cons: Lots of hidden caveats in working towards promotions, merit raises, etc.  Raises are minimal at best with a six month wait for your salary increase after your review. Promotions are the same - you may not get your increase until six months after your promotion.  Requirements for promotions are all over the board with no clear direction on what is required.  Very inconsistent.  Management is too concerned with the bottom line of the almighty stock dollar to care about rewarding employees.

pros: One sales rep to one SE.  The ability to become a cohesive team
cons: The acquisition of Solidfire split the direction of the company.  There was a Solidfire team and a Core team for selling to accounts and it fragmented the message.  Management brought these together so badly that it made the Core team and the Solidfire team feel like they were competing against one another.  Also NetApp always wanted their employees to think they really cared about them and they really don't.  They lay off people every 6 months to 1 year to change direction of the company.  It leaves you feeling uncertain all the time.

pros:
The culture is truly amazing- so many genuine people that truly want to help you out. People that have worked here for 5, 10, 15+ years and aren't going anywhere really reveals a strong foundation of loyalty. That is not easy to find.
- Benefits are great
- encouragement of work/life balance
-great management/leadership across the board. 
- Mission driven - NetApp is partnered up with Rise Against Hunger and makes this a huge focus, providing volunteer opportunities and a certain amount of VTO days per year. 
- Revitalizing the NetApp story has transformed the business. We are no longer just a storage company- we are managing your data wherever you want to store it- many opportunities for customers that want to go to the cloud.
cons:
-There have been some recent leadership changes, majority for the good, but with change can bring upheaval 
- some processes aren't as smooth as they could be

pros:
* Above average benefits
* Company as whole growing 
* In a industry that is bound to grow in the information age
cons:
* sweat shop
* Lack of honesty, integrity
* No desire to discuss issues, really a stated dictatorship, one man rule
* Spy on employees, with even low level management peers
* Favoritism to people of their gender, race or politics
* Employees benefit little from company growth
* Worst quality products seen, disingenuous desire to improve quality
* Overriding goal is always the quick dollar
* Due to the lack of management always playing catch up with no uniform strategy, management often absent
* Strategy usually changes monthly
* Worst engineering have seen with spaghetti code and no interest in fixing it
* Very unfriendly place socially full of introverts with little social skills
* Full of cliques
* Management is full of elitist who rarely reward some of the most deserving or productive 
* loaded with great work by thousands but only a few well connected to the inner group are appreciated no matter how flawed they are

review_title: This is mainly for the interview process for Business Analysts.
pros: Very Prompt scheduling for phone Interviews. The recruiters did not waste any time in getting back with various time options and the process was really good.
cons: Though NetApp boasts of a great culture, the impression one receives while interviewing is totally the opposite. They made me sit in a meeting room for over 2 hours with no communication .Looks like the interviewer did not turn up nor the recruiter. Finally one lady from the senior management turned up and blew her own trumpet about how successful she was. I answered 3 questions in about 4 hours as I did not get a chance to speak at all. I felt they conducted the interview for the heck of it and there was no real intent to hire. Companies like these should be the face of hypocrisy. Companied with great culture do not put up banners on their buildings! They let it speak from the employees. Whew! Even bad experiences can make up for good learning.

pros: The benefits are competitive and the salary was good.  The people were for the most part great to work with.  Culture and values historically were good but have taken a beating in the last couple of years.  There was an upper management effort to turn this around but I am not sure how successful it is being.
cons: As the company struggled the atmosphere took on a very political tone.  At the middle management level the focus became much more short term at the expense of long term prosperity.  Upper management seems to have a long term plan but communications seemed to stop at middle management creating a lot of uncertainty for the workers.

review_title: Good place to work, may become great again.
pros: Flexible with employees. Working from home/alternative offices can be arranged although not as freely as previous years. Salaries are above the industry standard; expectations are high without being unreasonable. Very little micro management despite clear goals/targets. Employees treated like adults, hard work is respected even if it's not recognised overtly.
cons:
Some recurring problems with internal processes, CRM (salesforce) has frequent issues that cause delays and frustration.
Not a great HR/Recruitment department, internal recruitment is a struggle, while offers regularly go out to external candidates which seem to be the preference. Too many soft hires in recent years, sales floor not as dynamic as once was. Could be more gender diverse but hiring should be based on skill and experience first and foremost.

review_title: Overall it truly is a Great Place To Work!
pros: You live the NetApp culture everyday, you count on others and others count on you. It's a very open environment where you have access to everybody -- colleagues, managers, execs.  You get to do real product engineering work, some of these are architected and designed from the ground up (Ver. 1.0).  Lots of top notch engineers and smart people all around you, most days you wake up feeling good and fired up to make a difference.
cons: Hard to maintain a work-life balance, lots of conf calls that eat into your mornings and/or evenings.  Comp and benefits are about average or maybe slightly better, but nothing to write home about.

review_title: Good for people who like to sit idle.
job_title: Member Technical Staff II in Bangalore
pros: When it comes to pros of the company, work life balance sits on the top. Flexible work timings and just average workload are the few things that people cherish over here. Also, NetApp emphasizes big on its values and culture. People are very friendly and collaborative. Cultural and social events are organized on a regular basis.
cons: The first thing that comes to the fore is the compensation. Netapp is really lagging behind in terms of compensation. Attrition rate has jacked up and people are not very satisfied with respect to career growth. Company is also cutting on various perks and facilities. There seems to be a little indecisiveness at the senior management level as to the goals are not very clear. Company went through few realignment processes recently which impacted several employees badly.

pros: Positive, generally collaborative work environment.  There is a strong focus on making this an excellent company to work for.  Tremendous pride in the quality and competitiveness of its products and services.
cons: At $5B+ in revenue, the company has build a lot of infrastructure, which tends to keep it from being as nimble as it ought to be.  This is a typical growing pain that afflicts organizations of this size, though, and will likely work itself out with continued growth.

review_title: Capsized Ship - swim out as fast as you can
job_title: Technical Support Manager in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Very nice facility in RTP along with Gym membership etc.
cons: Having left NetApp for its competitor, I can see how much the writing is on the walls at NetApp. Terrible middle and upper management with absolutely no commitment to customers unless cases are escalated to them and then they would haul at the TSE and manager and make them scapegoats. I have never worked in a place where "Who" the customer is based on their history of escalations is THE ONLY thing that was important to management. They totally ignored customers overseas and missed a big portion of sales overseas. I cannot believe what a filthy set of leaders they brought all from Nortel who knew nothing and cared less about people and customers. It was all about them.

pros: I spent 10 years at NetApp in various sales roles.  The company had (operative word) incredible technology, autonomy to get your job done as you see fit, good mid level management and a vision and culture that were unmatched.
cons: The company lacks vision, promotions given only to the "good ole boy club".  Senior / Executive management is worthless and incapable of making decisions and moving forward.  Worked with and for one of the most narcissistic sales leaders I have ever met.  He would sell his own grandmother if the price was right. ; ).   Frequent - at least twice annually - layoff.  Morale is in the crapper and culture is non-existent.

pros:
Very loyal customers, functionally rich and stable product, extended installation base, recognized brand name. 
Excellent engineering company.  Offers opportunity to work on a wide set of storage technologies.  
Great work-life balance, great campus.
cons:
Strictly hierarchical,  extremely clique, must be careful not to tread on toes. 
Not open to criticism.  Extremely slow professional progression.  Management suffers from analysis/paralysis in decision making.
For example if it had decided to adopt SSDs a few years earlier, it's growth would have been phenomenal  without the need for all the cost cutting that ensued. Also product releases need to be streamlined.

pros: work life balance, amazing people, interesting work
cons:
limited $ and resources in engineering.

Most employee's mentality is to just go to work as a job, and take advantage of the strong work life balance and benefits. There's no incentive to take ownership and do more because pay is much lower (very little equity is given) compared to other tech companies and vertical movement is very slow progress. 

Ramp up speed is also very slow. Every transfer of knowledge is done by word of mouth rather than written documentation. If there is documentation, it's very outdated. Ramp up should not be so painful. When a senior engineer leaves, the knowledge/expertise is lost.

review_title: Not the place it once was
pros: Great technology, products and people make it an invigorating job. Our customers appreciate what we do for them and respect us.
cons: NetApp has lost the start-up feeling and management is fully embracing a big company mentality. Work has become loaded with bureaucracy and stick-in-the-mud management that can't see the forest for the trees. It used to be a job you looked forward to, now it feels more like a source of a paycheck than anything else. Arrogance by executives who decide when you should be allowed to use your vacation time.

review_title: Great place to work for hard core technology person
pros:
Lot of scope to go in depth in technology
Lot of forums to learn and share knowledge
Twice a year shutdown provides great vacation time and allows to refresh mind body and soul
lot of email groups for everything to discuss with all employees :)
No need to setup lab. have a dedicated team for that. 
Dedicated WPR team which takes care of fun activities across the site every quarter like games, dance, fashion show etc
free snacks, beer bash and lot of options in cafe
cons:
Frequent re-org's and layoff's off late. no certainty on job 
Hardly any travel opportunities for IC's and cost cutting on travel, team building activities
delayed hikes and not so great hikes
growth as in promotions are very slow

review_title: NetApp, the little culture that once could....
pros: Global, good product offering, competitive salary and benefits
cons: Culture is struggling, many people are protecting their jobs or protecting others who have been there a very long time, some of those people are not pivoting and changing their GTM strategy in the extremely competitive storage industry. The sales teams are not very diverse within gender or ethnicity.

pros: The benefits at NetApp are great and keep getting better every year.
cons: Unfortunately the growth in this company is limited. The company itself is growing but they are not promoting their employees. Upper management do not support their direct reports nor do they care to learn about the culture or their colleagues when they are hired from outside the company. The lack of communication is disturbing as is the understanding of what actually goes on at the lower levels. The CEO has made political comments during his "All Hands" which are offensive to those who support their government leaders no matter who they are. The excuse that it is a California company is just that, an excuse. No one is taking the time to change and advance this company outside NetApp Inc.

review_title: Great place to work, they get things done, but too many inefficiencies.
pros:
Successful company with good products.
Competent engineering team.
Many opportunities for growth/expansion within the company.
Competitive pay and benefits.
Well rewarded for job well done, when/if recognized
cons:
Large company, slow to effect changes.
Lack of accountability from employees.
If you want something done, where another team is dropping the ball, you have to do it yourself. You will end up with your plate overflowing while others sit idle.
Internal communication could use improvement; too much email communication.
Too many meetings, can't reach a consensus without a meeting.
A lot of "throwing ownership" over the fence going on, nobody wants to own anything.
Everybody wants to go to the party, nobody wants to stay and clean up.

review_title: Great to disappointing instead of good to great
pros: Great top level leadership and by and large a skilled workforce. Generally paid well. Has great cultural roots. Executive management is highly focused on great culture.   At some point it just stopped to translate down the ranks. Some of the smartest people I've ever worked with. Exciting technology space.
cons: Somewhere the company strayed from its path. The management layer just below the X suite failed to live the culture and set some wrong examples. Lots of petty battles. Gradually loosing technology leadership. Some fear of taking moon shots and incubating new ideas with the start up mentality the company used to have.

review_title: Roots are strong..but leadership is shaky!
pros: It actually gives opportunity for anybody and everybody to grow! yes. A person with talent can go far. The open culture an candor play major role. Off late a lot of information is being passed through to all levels!
cons: Too much of time and energy wasted in consensus building and project tracking. At times hanging on to processes for sake of it!. Recently pessimism is getting upper hand! Under-committing is getting the lead.

job_title: Senior Project Manager in New York, NY
pros:
Friendly, professional, and smart colleagues
Good technology
Aggressive pursuit of market share
Good culture and striving to be Great - Supportive of work-life balance and community involvement/charitable work
STrives to be open and highly communicative
cons:
Hero-culture and silo-ed organization
Very much a "what have you done for me lately" culture
Ivory-tower mentality in Corp
No Careerpaths, no career growth
Hires new management mostly from outside
Weakness throughout management chain
Communication falters and breaks down from middle management to the front-line worker

pros: Great company to work for if your in the right department. The culture is not what it use to be but it still good. Work-life balance is great again depending on the department. A lot of good people to work with. Good Benefits!
cons: The company has moved away from what made it great. For example Business Operations lacks true leadership. Fear used as a tool to get things done. Is more worried about covering up problems than actually fixing them. Some management is quick put a target on your back if your not inline with them. Yes, even if your proactive, solving problems, and good at what you do.

job_title: Senior Engineering Manager in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros:
Some of the best and smartest technical people I've ever worked with. Great technology. Awesome focus on the community around us. Excellent benefits. 

Well positioned with strong "Data Fabric" story that resonates with companies moving from dedicated data centers to the cloud. NetApp technologies are enabling companies to access and protect their storage where it is most cost effective. 

The work they have done to get SAN enterprise ready and  to fold flash into the ONTAP offering has breathed new life into their strategy and they are winning.
cons: Storage market is becoming commodity and differentiation more challenging. Company leadership is having to make tough calls to right-size investments for the market - but those decisions are being made and the company continues to deliver on their performance.

review_title: NetApp - not perfect, but as close as I've found in 25 years working in IT
pros:
Work-life balance: middle and senior management actually help make it more than a catchphrase
Individual flexibility - little to no micromanaging, employees are given enough latitude to work well
Training - good corporate support for staying current
Pay and benefits: much better than most companies
Corporate culture: again, a nice surprise - it really does exist, and really is as advertised!
cons:
"Hands off" mgmt could be hard for younger employees
Annual performance review "system" is somewhat lacking
Top-down communication about new products, corporate direction not always clear
Company is still learning how to change from a small Silicon Valley startup into a more mature, bigger player. There are some bumps now and then

pros:
Beer Bash.
Flexible timings.
Good work for very very few groups who have big presence in bangalore.
cons:
Most group in india is given pathetic work or low priority. When the company has 0% growth, then these low priority group will be fully layoff irrespective of individual performance.
Lot of politics from USA directors,  product/modules which is about to be phased out will be sent to india and full new work will be done in USA. India is being used as junk yard.
No more good work sharing with India!.
Psycho VP's, who don't think much before doing layoff of full group in Bangalore.
Bangalore teams are easy pick for layoff as they will be doing/given low priority work.

review_title: Nice people but not a bright future ahead
pros: Not super stressful. Decent perks - on-site cafeteria, gym, etc. I think the CEO is doing an ok job - he is committed, passionate, and holds himself accountable. I just don't think there is much he can do to steer this ship around.
cons:
Not the top tier of people. A lot of top talent has left. It's a shrinking market so there's only so much NetApp can do. If you are near the end of your career, it might be ok to stick it out there, but otherwise, not a good place to develop your career. 

Not as much flexibility as I would have liked.

pros: Great pay and benefits, challenging engineering problems, weekly beer bash, and a decent “get things done” environment for a big company. Great place to start or end your career!
cons:
Being successful in Engineering without politics is tough. There is a lot of cliquey, mafioso-type attitudes at the senior / principle engineer and technical director level; merit at that level seems based on who you know not what you can get done. 

Engineering environment is lagging, circa de 1990. If you’re looking to leverage new or Open Source technologies then, with a few exceptions, you should look elsewhere.

pros: Strong culture, hard working people. There is also a very good gym onsite (in Sunnyvale) - if you get an opportunity to use it, though :).
cons: Salaries much lower than elsewhere in the industry. Very inflexible culture. I am expected to physically sit there in my cube, whether I have anything to do or not, whether I have to have my car fixed or not. There is very little opportunity to work from home, or to take time off here and there (i.e., come in later, leave earlier and compensate by logging in from home at night.) I am underpaid and micro-managed.

job_title: Data Migration Engineer in Orlando, FL
pros: There is a reason NetApp is listed as "one of the best places to work" year after year, and in many countries. The corporate atmosphere is so "polite", that it almost seems out-of-place to make a snide comment to the point that everyone just "gets along". I can safely say, this is was the best place I've ever worked insofar as job satisfaction is concerned. A total 180-degree difference from Red Hat :)
cons: The only "cons" I can even come up with are: 1) Tendency to cut contractors towards end of projects to save on operating cost numbers via out-sourcing their India-based location, and 2) lack of upper-level, corporate hierarchy's ability to properly propagate important issues upwards.

review_title: It used to be best company to work for in 2009 for a good reason!  Culture, top leadership, employee focus.
job_title: Senior Accounting Manager in San Jose, CA
pros:
I believe this company may still have some good DNA.  It is hard to believe that such a great place to work can change so drastically.
I believe it will recover again to an acceptable level where employees can recover trust and loyalty. Not everything is about the bottom line.
cons: No work life balance, no job stability, no promotions, no consideration for the employees been laid off from the US.  The company is shifting most of the work and with this the opportunities outside the US.  It is a great opportunity for the Bangalore employees to prove themselves!

job_title: Member Of Technical Staff in Bangalore
pros: Full flexibility at work. That comes with a bit of luck though. I got to join one of the teams with most modern and cutting-edge technologies, while being equally politics free. The whole team is kind-of a family -- they support you whenever you are in need.
cons: If you are competitive enough, you will feel bad that you are paid equal to many stupid dumb people around you who do nothing significant at their job. Heard some teams are literally waste -- work for which there is no need of hiring top college graduates but can be done by 12th pass students too(e.g. running some scripts, basic c++ etc). Heard that most other team has the main task as 'bugfixing' -- yep you got it right, most of the teams are just 'offshore maintenance centers' for NetApp US offices

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros:
NetApp has a pretty great culture overall. They still have a beer bash every friday, bagels friday morning, fruit on wednesday, etc. The benefits are still very good. Upper management communicates often with everyone on the direction of the company and they are generally very frank with their assessments as well.

The work itself is generally interesting and they rarely require anything beyond 40 or 45 hours a week.
cons: The morale of the teams has generally declined a bit over the last few years as some of the better experienced employees have quit while most hiring has been confined to college graduates with no experience.

job_title: Business Development Consultant in Washington, DC
pros: Excellent market share and penetration of US Government market including DOD and many intelligence and other agencies, better than its larger global competitor EMC.  Laid-back culture and trendy office environments and decor. International offices staffed by extremely bright technical professionals.
cons: Very rigid policies in business development leaves NetApp unable to move quickly, especially in vibrant Asia-Pacific countries increasingly tech-savvy and with lucrative public sector opportunities. NetApp prefers decentralization and delegation to detriment of capitalizing when deals emerge and need to be seized quickly. Senior leadership "not ready for prime time" when it comes not only to seizing immediate opportunities but also to long-term sales prospects.

review_title: NetApp is a terrific collaborative company with great opportunities for learning and professional growth.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Cooperation/collaboration!  We are ONE TEAM.  The other day someone suggested a change to one of our internal websites.  I thought about it and hacked a change, which worked on Firefox and Safari but not IE.  I posted something to an internal mailing list about it, and someone on the east coast found out how to fix it and updated the site less then 10 minutes later.
