I love this company because people are committed to doing the right thing for the company and for our customers.
cons:
There is a diversity of management talent at NetApp.  If you get a good one, life is good.  If not then not so good.

I'd love to see a pension plan beyond the 401k.

review_title: Great company, going through growing pains
pros:
The people. The people at NetApp are great. For the most part, everyone is willing to pitch in and help. Some of the best and brightest I have ever met work for or used to work for NetApp.

Granted as a company grows it is hard to maintain the same level of excellence, but I think NetApp has done a pretty job of it.
cons:
NetApp is growing and grew very fast, and that comes with some growing pains. Some of that pain comes from some of the hires that have been made who don't understand what NetApp is, in terms of a company.

As with any other vendor, there can be a very heavy sales focus. If sales doesn't like you, your life will be difficult. If sales likes you, your life will be great at NetApp.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Westlake Village, Optional[CA]
pros: Put NAS on the map.  Loyal customer base.  Focused on customer success.  Good compensation for those who can over achieve.
cons: Old portfolio.  Getting killed by newer disruptive technologies.  They talk a lot about culture but they have lost vision on the culture that made NetApp great.  Not a clear vision.  Lots of turn over especially with senior leadership.  Entire change in Americas Sales Leadership.  Not a good thing.

review_title: Cultural Transformation: Not Such A Great Place To Work
job_title: Support Account Manager in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Plenty of parking, onsite fitness center, food days (snacks, fruit, bagels), lots of people who still care about their jobs (so long as they're not in Support)
cons: Annual layoffs (although there's likely to be another one this fall), disappointing middle management with little/no direction, stock value dropped in half over last two years, beer bash no longer a weekly event...NetApp is no longer a Great Place To Work; they're not even on the list anymore

review_title: You get out what you put in
pros: Great people, great networking, great learning environment, fantastic benefit. It is very much a place where if you know what you want to learn and how you want to grow they can help make it happen.
cons:
HR hurts the business from getting top talent. HR is there to protect the company, I get that. However , the whole "rule" about no counter offers and that you can only give an employee a cap raise despite them going truly above and beyond their pay grade leaves a bad taste in most people's mouth. We have a saying as employees "you have to leave and come back to get around HR and get the pay/raise/promotion you deserve."

Other con is everyone has a "lay off" mentality.

pros: Great colleagues, family orientated company.  There are a ton of incentives from gym membership, international cafeteria to stock options and employee parties.
cons: Typical managers have more than eight employees to manage.  This equates to managers not being aware of duties and tasks an employee is taking on.  Last four years have equated to cut-backs (i.e. layoffs due to "TRANSFORMATIONS").  Management has difficulty directing talent in the department I was within.  No room to push through the Glass Ceiling to management UNLESS you find a department that is not cutting back due to the Transformation.

review_title: Good for the job they hire you for. No chance of growth.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Strong culture, great event participation, enough independence to do your own thing.
cons: Horrible, horrible middle management. I wish the Executive team understood just how little of their direction gets pushed down into middle management.  Trying to get something beneficial done that aligns with the company's culture and approach can often times be stymied by a particular director or VP's team and their own person agenda (i.e. We don't have time for that, even though we don't have to do any of the work).  There are so many things wrong within NetApp right now, it's amazing to me how many people continue to stay on the Titanic long after it has hit the iceberg.

pros: Friendly, collaborative atmosphere. Used to have a great culture.
cons: Too much bureaucracy stifles efficiency and innovation. Bloated middle management runs the business like high school. If you're not in the  clique, you don't get promoted and you're not listened to. Senior management struggling to find a place for the company in the new virtual storage environment.

review_title: A Great Place to Work; Should be The Best
pros: For folks below senior management, there are many enthusiastic, good people working to do the right thing to make NetApp succeed.  They work really hard, collaborate well, represent NetApp's values of Trust and Integrity and Get Things Done.
cons: I am surprised at the lack of conversation and demonstration among the executives about leadership. There is no well-developed professional or leadership development at the executive level, and none that permeates throughout the organization with any structure.  Options at the executive level for lateral moves or promotion are limited, even though there is great growth in the company.  Not yet convinced that this is a good company for women and minorities.

review_title: Stay strong and train the first rung managers!!
job_title: Technical Global Advisor in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: NetApp has made tremendous strides as a storage vendor and has been a leader in changing the roadmap in this industry. They have an excellent, down-to-earth senior management (executive team) that leads from the front.
cons: Organization maturity and processes are still in its infancy. They are still learning how to grow from another player in the industry to being one of top two leading vendors in the industry. The first line managers and middle management layer grew from the ranks - are not necessarily the best managers. Having an opinion and a voice may land you in soup.

review_title: Good company with very relaxed corporate culture
pros: Good culture (quarterly all hands meeting, fruit tuesdays, bagel fridays) and genuinely nice people are at the top of my list. The company is definitely a great place to work, and you never feel that the senior management is distant.
cons: If you are fresh out of college, NetApp may not be the best place to start your career because you become easily satisfied and may never try to leave and challenge yourself. However, if your goal isn't to constantly seek new challenges, NetApp is a great place to be at.

review_title: Good company to work for, need better senior management
job_title: Member Of Technical Staff in Sunnyvale, CA
pros:
Good work-life balance 
Great set of people to work with
Hands off management, just get your work done. 
Great start for a career
cons:
Too much importance for artificial stuff like great places to work rankings etc which are no good except for marketing 
Not too great set of perks, they cut back on lot of good stuff like weekly beer bashes 
Too much focus on ONTAP ignoring other BU's and technologies like flash drives. (Almost cult Like) although this is changing very slowly
Not much growth once inside the company compensation or otherwise

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Good work/life balance.  There is a culture of transparency from the upper management.  Very good benefits.  Lots of training opportunities. The upper management seems dedicated to making the company a great place to work.
cons:
Pay is average or below, advancement is very slow.  

As an engineer, it appears that the sales and support organizations are running well, but product development seems very broken.  Huge amounts of unnecessary process burden all aspects of the product development cycle, from product definition down to the level of the individual code check-in.   This results in some of the lowest productivity per engineer that I have witnessed. The engineers are working hard, but it is very difficult for them to get anything done.  

The upper management seems to want to change this, but the deep layers of middle management are so risk-averse that they seem to be locked in stasis until an EVP commands action.   

The HR policies are stuck in the 80's, with an oppressive annual review process (complete with annual goals), stack ranking, and a black-hole applicant tracking system that seems to grade every applicant unworthy of consideration.   For those rare individuals that do get interviews (usually because the hiring manager bypassed HR), the risk-averse culture demands multiple rounds of interviews.  I know of people hired only after running a gauntlet of 15-20 individual interviews, organized into 3 or 4 rounds.

pros: Working with team members has been great, within ones group and adjacent groups folks are eager to help.  There is a respect for work-life balance at NetApp.  Good technology teams putting energy toward succeeding. There is a desire to succeed.
cons: A leaning toward action that is good; however, too much of the ready-shoot-aim approach.  Senior leaders have trouble defining the strategy and initiatives aligned with it, the old-world of refreshing storage is too alive and well.  There is more of a tactical approach to the business that is quite reactionary.

job_title: Human Resources Manager  in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Good salaries.  Collaborative work environment.  Good benefits and very flexible about work/life balance.  The ability to work remotely is different in every group.  Some groups allow it willingly and others expect their employees in the office every day.  No problem getting time off for appointments or family issues.
cons: They have an 'open door' policy.  But you better make sure all levels leading to that open door have been given a heads up that you are talking with an executive.  It's a very hierarchical environment where decisions are made at the top and cascaded down.  Project issues or problems are first brought to your manager even if you are leading the project.

review_title: NetApp is an amazing place to work
job_title: Business Systems Analyst in Durham, NC
pros: Great culture!  Very nice work environment, everyone is very friendly.  Having come from a small business background, this was a great change in terms of size.  They still function like a small company, from their corporate events to the way they treat their employees.  Your voice is heard when you feel something should be.  I've never met a nicer group of people than those that I work with.  Everyone there is a friendly genious!  They screen their staff very well.  They are also a very honest company.  Where other companies will bloat results, NetApp seems to be the honest one that gives true expectations from their fantastic technology.
cons: I have to drive there?

job_title: Systems Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros:
One of the best culture's around.  Great products, great people.
The people at NetApp (including myself) have a passion for the product.  When I was selling NetApp, I knew that if the customer bought my solution, they were making the right decision and would be happy with their purchase
cons:
Recently, the forward momentum and innovation has slowed down, causing some backsliding in the market.  It's taken way too long to bring new products to market, and what has come out has suffered in QA and manufacturing.  

There needs to be a renewed focus on innovation.

pros: As a whole great company, still lots of great people, great atmosphere to learn from great customers, good benefits, good work environment.
cons: internal people to leaving and external people as the main source of staffing has created loss of culture.  Company is stuck doing thing the way they have been for 3,5,10+ years.  There is a "my way or the highway" mentality.  Failed to get the jump on almost every major trend in the industry for the last 3-5 years despite the company having all the technology and tools to be first to market.  red tape internally its absolutely staggering.

pros: The pay is high and the typical Bay Area culture is good.  As is heard in the hallways, we're "kindler and gentler" (than their top competitor, EMC).
cons: Travel (depending on the position).  There's a lot of arrogance about being the best.  This may have been true a few years ago, but there's lots of competition in the storage industry now.  I think many employees rest on their laurels and are resistant to change.  Not that they don't work hard, but they have blinders on and assume their stuff is still the best.  cDOT is a good product, but the complexity of moving from "7 mode" is a hinderance to profits.  Things aren't necessarily rosy for NetApp as their revenue keeps falling due to competition.

pros: Opportunities are available if you connect and reach out to different people. There are some outstanding people who really do live the NetApp values and are great to work with.
cons: For every great person at NetApp are a number of very difficult people. Some are in big leadership positions and are secured. Some are day-to-day contributors and NetApp is too nice to do anything about them. Layoffs seem arbitrary and doesn't necessarily weed out these difficult, unproductive folks. Salary seems to be on the lower range for Silicon Valley.

review_title: Used to be a great place, now it's just a good place.
pros: NetApp in its early days was one of the most exciting and innovative companies around; nowdays it is mostly just a big tech company.  Better than a lot of places, but nowhere near as special as it once was.
cons: Too much focus on growth and not enough on real engineering innovation and product quality.  Company is run by bureaucracy at this point -- not by engineering.

review_title: Most of the fresh grads leave within one or two years due to very dismal pay package.
job_title: Member of Technical Staff QA in Bangalore
pros:
- Great Work Culture
- Management very supportive
cons:
- Pay is less when compared to other good organizations
- Growth is stagnant 
- Bonuses are less
- NetApp India is amongst the worst NetApp Office even in terms of culture
- Working on bugs of outdated and ill written codes for most part of  2-3 years as a fresher which is frustrating
- Not much to learn if you love to code 
- Most of the people come through referrals and therefore the quality of niche IIT or NIT grads is missing 
- pay rise due to promotions is again very minimal
- annual pay growth is significantly nill

job_title: Customer Support Engineer in Wichita, KS
pros: NetApp has a great culture with competitive benefits and strong leadership.  They have a clear vision and are not scared to make tough decisions to be successful.  All the people I work with are friendly and helpful, which is all complimented by a casual work environment. We have yoga classes at the office during the day and company "beer bashes" every other Friday.
cons: As with any large corporation you experience frustrations with processes and procedures, but nothing too bad.  It can be hard to change roles or gain diverse experience, and vertical movement isn't easy.  Pay increases are minimal and a bell curve performance rating makes it difficult to get an above average review.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Good campus, good benefits, teammates in Support are always willing to help out. Good relationships between Field Support and Tech Support.
cons: As a company they are betting the farm on C-Mode when not all customers need (or want) all of the features. Past acquisitions are 50/50 in longevity where some products die off (Netcache, VTL) that had niche users who loved the products. Too late to the flash game, but I hope the SolidFire purchase turns things around. Support took a big step back when they moved to the 'coverage model'.

pros: At the time, everyone was really great and friendly, the buildings are modern and cubicles were roomy (until they downsized them). The thing I miss most is the cafeteria, it had GREAT food every day so I didn't have to worry about making lunch or going anywhere. Salary was decent.
cons: They are having an annual layoff now. Rumors are they'll have a second layoff this year. Company revenue is declining and they aren't innovating. I'm sure they are trying to keep afloat, and they'll be ok for years to go thanks to their cash on hand, but all the signs are there. Unless they perform a miracle, they're going down.

review_title: NetApp - Not bad, but certainly not worthy of "Best Place to Work"
pros: Offers great benefits and salaries are above average for the industry. The best technical group you will find to solve problems.
cons: Depends on the business unit, but SMAI is poorly run due to current GM and Directors. Most of the other units seem to be well run with positive feedback from employees. Middle management makes lame attempts to make decisions for the technical direction of products and process.

review_title: Great place to work for, except for the Bangalore manageability team
pros:
NetApp culture is very good.
It survived a couple of economy slow downs, which is bench mark for the capabilities of top management.
Flexible timings
Work from home
cons:
No cons at NetApp level, but at Bangalore manageability team: 
Management of Bangalore manageability team is not doing well. They don't seem to be concerned of whether the engineers are fairly recognized or not.
They don't seem to be concerned of the attitude of managers with respect to the fairness towards the engineers.
They seem to be believing in the management talent, not the engineering talent.
Your fate depends on the manager that you get to report to.

review_title: As advertised, great place to work!
pros: Impressive large company.  Great intra-company website where you will be setup without any issue, and has links to everything you need including training and education to improve yourself.  Everything just works.  Management team and culture is first class, down to earth and is great story.  Culture is what makes NetApp great.    Good work/life balance.
cons:
Only cons would be company is not as successful in years past, but still doing ok.  With any large company, career leaps and any recognition may be very limited.  
Not many perks as you would expect (besides volunteer time off and Friday bagels), but they are stable and some jobs are remote friendly.

job_title: Member of Technical Staff, Software in Sunnyvale, CA
pros:
Successful product backed by a strong sales force
A lot of technology to sink your teeth into
Typical big-company compensation and benefits
Many capable and nice coworkers
cons:
Super slow pace.  Many talented and dynamic people get frustrated and leave.
Dumb processes.  Productivity is appalling.  Tools and mindset are 30 years old.
Very hierarchical.  Decisions are handed down without explanation.  Engineers are just workers.
Increasingly political.  NetApp was once blessedly free of politics, but not any more.
Stagnant.  Gigantic technical debt.  "Top priorities" are not linked to any sort of fresh thinking.
Institutional paralysis.  Even when everyone can see that something doesn't work, we keep right on doing it.  The right conversations never take place.  Innovation has been bred out of the population, especially on the management side.

job_title: Manager, Customer Support in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Great campus in RTP, great work out facilities, etc.
cons: Terrible middle management. If you staff the entire management and Middle Management with ex Verizon and ex Nortel employees - see where both these companies have gone. Too much of boys club and this includes Verizon boys club and Nortel Boys club. I can only see this company go down the drain, due this poor leadership, excessive spending on unnecessary things such as beer bash - never understood what it promotes. I know its not networking within the company becos of the boys club already being so strong. I am seeing a ton of such comments written from every level and every BU of this company. I DON'T THINK HR AND GEORGE KURIAN cares to read. Anyways, my two cents worth.....

review_title: Great place to work. Could be better. Lots of smart engineers. Friendly atmosphere.
job_title: Member Technical Staff in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Very friendly atmosphere. Lots of smart people. Top management is great and very honest in telling the employees what's going on. Tom Mendoza the President is brilliant. Just hear the man talk.
cons: Career advancement is limited when trying to get to senior engineer or technical director. Lots of incompetent folks have been hired of late especially into management and product management. Hierarchy has become very deep

review_title: Used to be more of a great place to work
pros: Benefits are the best in the business.  Some departments offer great time flexibility -- depends on managrer.  Nice facilities and cafe -- albeit pricey.
cons: Getting incredibly political.  Middle management competence is seriously questionable.  The influence of culture of the home country of most of the staff is starting to wear away at what used to be a wonderful corporate culture where individual expression was prized.  Now it's more like -- keep your head down or it will be lopped off.

review_title: NOT so GREAT place to work for
pros:
Package at joining.
You get your maximum from CTC, no hidden optional benefits.
cons:
1. Favoritism
2. Blind (mis)conception over some
3. No proper growth in terms of salary, your college juniors would be joining at better package than what you are getting after so many years of experience.
4. No clarifications you would get, if you feel you are being treated badly at appraisals
5. You don't get any scope for assessing the usability of new technologies
6. You would be always working on the same decade old things
7. You won't feel like a Great Place at all

review_title: Lagging the industry, becoming very bureaucratic and complacent
pros:
Standard benefits, however 401K match vests over 3 years
Nice Gym, and grounds
Under cover parking
cons:
-Below market salaries 
-Not growing resulting in layoffs in May 2013 and another rounds coming in the next couple of weeks
-Poor middle level management, lots of cronysm, extremely slow to make decisions, everyone is trying to protect their territory. 
-Missed the boat on Flash array and are paying the price (announced layoffs this last week)
-Very rigid work culture most departments require being in the office and very much a culture of manager looking over your shoulder and its very stifling.
-Huge marketing effort around the "great place to work " this is a mirage.  
-Oh and the campus is situated next to a dump and it stinks all summer long so you cant use the outside grounds.

review_title: used to be best place to work, now losing famous corporate culture
pros:
For a large corporation, still good culture from top management downwards.
People have a positive attitude and are helpful.
Best top management I´ve ever seen in a large corporation. Great guys!
Still strong market position behind EMC.
cons:
Products have lost lead position, little differentiation to competition anymore, company was lazy in developing real innovative solutions as success made them saturated.
When Netapp became well-known, it attracted many mediocre people who brought in bad habits. Netapp did not select people carefully enough as they always did.
Bad product support with no change for better customer experience for several years now.

review_title: Great Products with a lot of potential
pros: Decent benefits and compensation. Volunteer time provided in addition to vacation time. Great product line.
cons: Repeating what another employee posted - it's difficult to grow within the company. First you feel bored in the same position, you become trapped and then become complacent. I think it's more common then mgmt wants to admit. Laid back attitude amongst protected employees does discontent.

pros: I worked at NetApp for over 5 years.  It was a wonderful experience.  The company was growing at a rate above 30% YOY when I joined.  I was given lots of autonomy, challenges and variety.  The leadership team was amazing and inspiring; I had a lot of faith in the leadership.  It was a very family oriented environment; working at NetApp became a way of life.  My family was brought into the fold via events that happened throughout the year.  My children really missed NetApp.
cons: In the last year of my employment, the business had slowed considerable and the executive level management team had changed.  I was worried that NetApp was falling behind on innovation compared to some of its competitors and the numerous start ups that had sprung up.

pros: Lots of work to do, lots of things to learn. Good compensation and benefits. Great facilities. Good scheme for purchasing stocks. Flexible hours. Option of work from home.
cons: Forced holidays. 1 or 2 less holidays than other companies. Lots of different projects to learn but difficult to change teams due to HR and management hurdles. Very limited communication between teams. No family day or annual day kind of thing.

pros: The people are extremely bright, nice and friendly. The benefits are great. There are a lot of fringe benefits that I have not seen at other companies. They have fruit in the break rooms on Tuesday, bagels on Friday. The Sunnyvale site has a free gym. The cafeteria is complete with sushi chef, dry cleaning service, oil change service, health clinic trailer visits Tuesdays, etc.
cons: There is no work life balance, at least in the area I worked in, and my friends have said the same. The work is very challenging and rewarding, but the hours are 70+ and the pressure is intense. I know some very exhausted people there. Also, like most corporations these days, they are willing to shed people if there is a hint that the financials that year won't be optimal.

review_title: Once a great place to work
pros: NetApp (Wichita) has a great company culture, and really inspires motivated people to succeed. Salary is competitive for the area. The in house benefits are great for this area (gym, decked out break rooms, beer Fridays, etc.) but the benefits you really care about (tuition assistance, insurance, retirement plans, etc.) are on par with or slightly worse than other local companies.
cons: There has been a lot of turmoil and uncertainty lately. New CEO and unclear direction have left a lot of people feeling uneasy about the future of the company and many are leaving for other opportunities.

pros: Netapp has some of the best leaders at one time - Dan Warmenhoven and others - who had the vision, passion, drive and discipline to get and keep great people. I had the honor of working at NetApp during its best time.
cons: Engineers running the company believing that if customers "just could understand" how great the products are everything will be ok - rather than listening to the customers and the market. Unfortunately now the leaders - especially in sales - are no longer the type you want to charge up a hill for. They are in protect mode - because they could be next to be gone - like some many before them. it is a shame but at this point I would stay away.

pros:
NetApp used to be a great company with fantastic opportunity, benefits and great technology.
Note to potential new employees - The RIF support process is top notch.
cons:
Reorganization of the company has taken it from #4 to last on Fortune 400 companies to work for.  
Why would management eliminate OEM E-Series business without at least considering applying internal Sales as an augmentation?
RIFs are/will be continuous and HR does not support existing RIF'ed employees find internal jobs. Very sad.

review_title: Loosing its leadership,  its talents, its culture and values
pros: Remote working, packages & benefits
cons:
The new management team has definitively killed the existing culture that made the company a unique one...The leaders are not inspiring anymore.  Too many transformation plans without a clear plan. the company advocates the retention of talents but does nothing to keep them .  it must be said that human resources have no power. 
about the activity: the products are still good enough even if the innovation is not impressive. the offer has became a bit complex and the sales are not able to sell the entire portefolio  
big gaps beetween corp and field. the field is suffering of loosing ressources when corporate is living in luxucy

review_title: This is not the NetApp I signed up for.
pros:
1)  Good people work here.
2)  Certain departments are flexible in regards to telecommuting.
3)  Gym is nice.
cons:
NetApp has changed over the last several years.  There is a tremendous amount of internal politics, which is spreading through the company like a cancer.  The results are apparent by the “Best Company to Work for Ranking”.  

I believe that NetApp will fall out of ranking within the next several years.

review_title: NetApp is going the way of SGI and Sun
job_title: Technical Marketing Engineer in Sunnyvale, CA
pros:
There are a lot of good people at NetApp and care about the company. My management is really good, but apparently this is the exception than the rule.

Despite the company's best efforts, we still have a lot of customers who love us and want us to succeed.
cons:
The company has moved away from focusing on the customer. They have been so consumed with the 7 mode to cDOT transition that they were really late to flash and missed the cloud totally. The opportunities for this company have been squandered. The company strategy until very recently was close the gaps in CDOT and customers will buy. Well, we closed the gaps and customers went to the cloud instead. 

The lack of situational awareness probably started with Dan W's final couple of years, and accelerated tremendously under Tom G. George is trying to turn things around, but it is almost too late. We literally are building products that our customers do not want to buy. 

Our company calls FlexPod cloud should tell you everything about were we are at. Our customers are fleeing to the public cloud as fast as they can. Our response has been to create poorly performing Cloud ONTAP product and NetApp Private Storage. The former is a cynical exercise in giving our customers a choice of poor performance in the cloud or buy on-premises gear you didn't want to buy,. The latter is just cloud washing wrapped in a solution.

review_title: A company "more or less" succeeding with transformation
pros: Strong Corporate and Geo leadership, product portfolio, culture.  Accelerating business model change with increased focussed on cloud, consumption, managed services.  Great people and opportunities to grow with the business.
cons: Still too many dinosaurs in Sunnyvale that are US centric and not connected enough with the global business.  The desire to transform fast often means that speed to deliver becomes the primary focus without a full appreciation of the mid to long term needs of the business or taking full advantage of option that could deliver significantly more ROI for the business e.g. business process and systems modernisation.

pros: Great opportunity to witness a dying company at first hand. Experience the most average middle-management leadership and sales teams in the industry, first hand. Enjoy people doing just enough to get to 80% of their goals as it would take a lot to get fired, as there is no performance management.  See how IT & CRM systems that were not even good 15 years ago, make doing everything harder. Enjoy the sorry delusion of a company whose once-famed culture has actually become a toxic blend of inaction and infighting.
cons: Banging your head against a brick wall every day leads to pain.  Pay / benefits not terrible however getting a pay rise requires some kind of sacrifice and recognition is now non-existent, unless its an entirely average act.

job_title: Member, Technical Staff, Software in Bangalore
pros:
* Used to be a great company
* Used to trust employees
* Had some challenging work
* Respected and cared about old timers
cons:
* Managers are gods, they are unchallenged and unaccountable
* Only company where there is no feedback process for managers. Any employee cannot give feedback for their respective managers. 
* No process in place for deciding on promotions
* Promotions given only on favoritism
* Only priority of management is to get listed in great place to work surveys

pros: It's still a great company with good technology.
cons: There is no clear direction and the company culture is decaying.  The ranking for best places to work dropped from a perennial top 10 to number 33 in 2014.  There have been two layoffs in the last year (800 and 600), and the company is late to market with new product introductions.

review_title: Outdated technology and tools, not a "great place to work"
job_title: Member Technical Staff, Software in Sunnyvale, CA
pros:
- Top notch gym
- Work life balance cannot be beat
- Relatively few unnecessary meetings
- Training classes available
- 401k match and ESPP
cons:
- Compensation (20-30% lower than other similar companies)
- No free food/snacks/drinks
- No personal growth due to using outdated technologies and tools (especially for bug tracking)
- Opportunity to write code as a developer is minimal due to large maintenance on aging codebase
- Little to no exposure with middle and senior management
- Upward movement is based on seniority rather than performance
- Many under-qualified employees (people who are settled down in life with kids, etc. and not interested in what NetApp does)

pros:
Smart people and professional work environment. 
Very collaborative approach with teams.
Good products, world class customers.
Nice cafeteria, gym, campus. Competitive pay.
cons:
Questionable leadership with plenty of turnover.
Hard to get stuff done with collaborative approach.

job_title: Member of Technical Staff IV  in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: The open culture and great people are the greatest reason to work at NetApp.  Most people are very good at their jobs.  Another reason to work at NetApp is that there are loads of exciting projects going on in all groups.  There are lots of opportunities to be part of good projects.
cons: Career advancement is individual's responsibility. Career advancement opportunities are limited.  Several groups prefer to hire from outside rather than grooming talent from within.  The company is going through growing pains that can be good or bad.  Sometimes the processes keep changing or new processes are put in place imposing large overheads without clear benefit. I guess that's part of growing up.

review_title: Eh.  They're not bad, but not the "great place to work" as they keep chanting like a cult.
job_title: Senior Product Marketing Manager in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Good market position, growth plans seem ambitious but a lot of focus toward achieving them.  Great benefits package, solid pay.  A lot of smart, focused people, if not particularly supportive of each other.
cons: If you aren't working on core technology, you're totally marginalized.  Their focus works against new initiatives.  Bureaucracy makes it seem like a much larger company than it is, and very difficult to move quickly on opportunities or take initiative in delivering more than is "scheduled" by middle managers.

review_title: Good place to work, but time for Dan to retire and take some of his old guard multimillionaires with him
pros: Pay, benefits, lots of talent, best standalone storage company
cons: Some of the old guard inner circle need to go, not even sure what most of them are accountable for. Dan needs to retire and take some with him, they don't need the money and aren't providing commensurate leadership. Getting more political.. Salary compression due to so many senior engineers. New rating system trying to address, but not working. A lot of folks resting while vesting. You have to be on the "inner circle" to advance your career. How long is it going to take to fix supply chain?  HR team is weak.

review_title: Company has gone down past few years
job_title: MTS3 in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Good technical work. You get to work with some really smart engineers. Company culture is also great.
cons: Past couple years, higher management has dropped the ball on various occasions. Mainly, they have been unable to forsee some trends in the storage industry, which has led to lost revenue recently. Also, the sales staff is not up to the mark with their knowledge of the portfolio and how to sell it affectively.

pros: NetApp still has the remnants of a great culture, and a notable percentage of folks working there are intelligent and friendly. Pay is on par, or a bit higher than other places in the SF Bay Area.
cons: The company has lacked an innovative - let alone effective - product and sales strategy for the past few years, and it's mostly due to leadership. Diminishing sales have taken a toll on revenues, and, subsequently, on the culture. Once a bastion of driven people, it now sees far lower levels of productivity.

pros: Decent pay, good work-life balance, Gym
cons: An entire company where all Directors, Sr. Directors, VP, spend 100% of their time playing politics and sucking up. Almost none of them are working on any real projects, products, or initiatives that are meaningful and instead create disastrous value-destruction messes in their wake. There is no accountability, money is spent like its monopoly money, and no clean-up or rationalization ever takes place.

pros: Netapp pays well and offer very flexible schedule.  The technology is good for the resume.  Fun people.   They offer beer bashes.
cons: The pay raises were very low (1-2% increase).  They are slave drivers.  I pulled all-nighters very frequently.  They have zero process (development).  Everything is done in a ad-hoc fashion.  One director often said in meetings: "make each working day an urgent day."  What is that supposed to mean?  That people should not have a life?

pros: They are super nice people and they try to treat the employees well.
cons:
I got caught in the last round of layoffs, but I am not negative towards them for that. I liked working there; I liked the people, but I was looking around anyhow, so it worked out well for me. The reason I was looking around is I do not see how it is possible for the company to survive without changing their business a lot. The change will require massive layoff. They have had them on a regular basis, but I suspect (I have no knowledge of this) that they will increase.
What I am saying is nothing you can't read in the trade publications. Storage companies like NetApp face competition from the cloud. Even if they do well selling to cloud providers, there will be fewer data centers than if every company had their own and, thus, less need for NetApp's products. 

Another is that they made an enormous commitment to clustered Data ONTAP, and I think the technology is outdated. I have many friends in Silicon Valley outside the company that work in businesses that have massive amounts of data, and many of them are shifting to commodity solutions (or started out that way). For instance, Facebook has used (and helped invent) Gluster, hdfs is used under Hadoop, which now being used by banks and other enterprise customers that are the kind of customer that NetApp serves.   These commodity solutions stripe data across a large number of inexpensive Linux systems and use block level replication for performance and data protection. Though this requires more physical discs because the storage is not as compact as RAID, especially with deduplication, reconstructing failed discs is much faster, and it provides performance benefits.  You can buy Linux systems for $9. 

Their hybrid flash solutions are excellent, well designed and reliable (like everything they do) but, you can buy hybrid drives at Best Buy. It is not the same thing but, they are high-performance and when used in conjunction with the kind of filesystems I mention above can give blazing performance. They could go into this market because better administration tools are needed, the deduplication problem has not been solved and much is needed but, it is a commodity market, which is much different than their current business. 

They are also competing in the flash market. They have no choice here but to be competitive on price. I can't imagine how they could maintain their margins if they have to do that so, again, they would have to go into a commodity business. 

I want to reiterate that I have absolutely no idea of what they plan to do and I am just telling you the logic that had me looking elsewhere.  The way it looked to me is that their high-end market was going to get eaten away by lower priced commodity solutions.  It happened to IBM, it happened to DEC, it happened to Sun -- IBM was big enough to survive but the other two are gone.  HP successfully switched to a commodity business but not without carnage in the workforce. 

Finally, it is looking more and more like memristors are going to work. They are being manufactured. They can be manufactured in current fab facilities with some modification. Flash memory requires specially build fabs. Also, flash has a short lifespan. You can only write to it a small number of times, and it stops working where the writes have happened. For that reason, the software that manages the flash has to be relatively complicated.  It needs to keep track of where writes have happened and choose the parts of the memory that have been written to the least. 

Memristors are so fast that they can be used both as long-term storage and as system memory. That means there won't be any external memory. Since they can be manufactured in ordinary fabs, the price should become quite cheap. They use 1/100th the amount of power, and a terabyte can fit in an area the size of a postage stamp, a petabyte in the volume of a sugar cube. That means even if the initial price is higher the cost of owning them is much lower. Besides all that, they can do millions of writes where flash can do thousands. 

It will be several years until memristors are ready for prime time, but they are being manufactured now. 

NetApp has a long history of being adaptable, and I would not be surprised at all if they made the changes necessary to survive in the changing environment. Unfortunately, I can't see how that could happen without a massive reduction in force. I started learning the new technology in preparation for moving on, and I did not even have to apply for a job.  I took some time off to do some projects I had been putting off and after I decided to get serious about finding a new job I had one in days.

Think about it. NetApp is laying people off and, logically, they will have to lay off more. The new industries that are replacing them are gobbling up people as fast as they can. 

You can learn there, it is a great place to work, the people are nice and it might be worthwhile. The tech industry is always changing but, be prepared for this to be a place that will be shrinking, not growing.

After a while, that gets depressing.

job_title: Member of Technical Staff II in Sunnyvale, CA
pros:
Nice work-life balance. 
Atmosphere that is simultaneously laid-back yet stimulating and hard-working.
Friendly, intelligent, and approachable senior engineers  - a rare trifecta!
Culture that used to be amazing, now still OK but a shadow of its former self.
Corporate sponsored beer-bashes.
Solid perks/benefits, especially 401k match and onsite training courses.
cons:
Company has slowly been going downhill; Salary hasn't kept up with industry standard, layoffs have been an annual occurrence, and growth opportunities are becoming even more limited within the company.

Instability - both in upper management and in the company's products themselves - has become a serious issue.

Both these have combined to dramatically lessen employee morale.

job_title: Member of Technical Staff QA in Bangalore
pros: Good pay, good stock options, nice perks. Time off to do voluntary work
cons: Everything in NetApp depends on the team that you are working on. The manager expected us to be subordinates to our leads, we were just supposed to work on whatever the leads assign us, without questioning. The manager rarely knew what was going on our end, no regular interactions with the manager. This was in particular in the CPE team in India.

job_title: Support Account Manager in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: The people... Good benefits and schedule flexibility.   Training opportunities...
cons: NetApp used to be a great company, but became content to rest on its accomplishments.   Years of poorly thought out strategy, and even poorer execution, has taken a toll on this once leading edge company.  Layoffs have become an annual event, and employee morale is the lowest I have seen since joining the company.   The other major problem that NetApp has, at least in the Support Center, is the lack of a strong management team.

review_title: Still a great company to work for
pros:
NetApp has a forward plan that is communicates to it's employees. And it's actually taking the steps openly to make these changes. The new management team from the CEO down are very competent and honest about what is needed to be done and what is at stake if we are not successful in this transition. Expectations are clearly laid out for staff on what they need change and focus on for all of us to all be successful. 

I feel like the changes the company has made and the future bets they are making are appropriate and will lead NetApp to still being relevant in 5 to 10 years if executed properly. 

The company has a different feel and some of the long timers are not supper keen on changing but in this space you now need to change or slowly die off.  I think it's inspiring to see what NetApp can become in the future and the value it will deliver not only to it's customer and shareholders, but also ultimately it's employees is retains. 

below is a list of all the Pro's to working here.
-Great people
-Very good culture
-Above avg compensation
-Excellent work life balance
-Great legacy products 
-Real products that work in the cloud today
-Product pipeline that will keep us relevant in this changing market place
-Great customers
-excellent benefits
-everyone has a voice
cons:
Changes mean lots of people that can't or wont change the way they do things and the skills sets they have will be let go. This can hurt moral for the short term. No one like to come to work and see their friends being walked out the door. New accountability mandates can lead to people feeling like the could be next to be let go. although this has stabilized quite a bit in the past year. 

List of Cons
-Customers are moving more and more to the cloud. traditional storage slice of the pie for NetApp to own is getting smaller. Only way to grow is to take market share faster from your competitors than then your slice of pie you compete to win shrinks. long term this is a losing proposition. 
-Bets on the cloud products must pay off for the company to succeed long term. 
-further downsizing will most likely need to happen to keep the company stock up. 
-Being the best company is a slowly shrinking market is not any easy pill to swallow. it's like being voted least ugly at an ugly contest. your still ugly, just not as much as the next person.

review_title: "Great place to work!" - says the propaganda.

Too much time and effort spent on meta issues and meta-meta issues. Too much emphasis on being nice and polite _all_ the time. No room for those that don't drink the Kool-Aid. Management too focused on managing Wall Street numbers. Too worried about "optics" and spinning metrics.

review_title: Not the culture it once was.
pros: Good work-life balance, stable place to work (except around quarter-end). Used to be a great culture but lost its way after CEO Dan and CFO Steve left a couple years ago.
cons: Lots of the driven, high-achieving people have left. Serious people remain, the people with a sense of humor have gradually left. Doesn't seem to have the same sense of urgency it used to. Lost its soul a few years ago, lost its way toward growth around the same time. Good stable place to work, tho.

review_title: On the surface; great. Dig deeper and read between the lines, it’s a different story.
pros: Flexible working is great. Kind and friendly management. Good pay. These essentials are what keep people here, though it never goes much further.
cons:
Processes are implemented without much wider consultation. Sometimes they fall flat on their face as a consequence.

Our cost-cutting and outsourcing of vital project functions to cheaper labour offshore needs a rethink. It results in clunky & awkward customer interactions.

Offices can be almost totally empty on certain days...

Staff turnover has been quite high last couple years, frequent layoffs are demotivating and demoralising. Happens every year.

There’s almost no opportunity for promotion if you’re looking for that.

review_title: One of the best companies that I have worked for!
pros: NetApp was a great company to work for from a culture and product perspective. They always promoted a healthy work/life balance and respected their employees. Their storage arrays were cutting edge technology with a unified architecture and an easy to manage product.
cons: Ontap Cluster mode.. I personally feel that NetApp should have ditch the convergence of Ontap and cluster mode a long time ago but they kept plugging along until it finally happened. From my perspective, the product went from easy to implement and manage to something that became very difficult. I understand that things are getting better but it was one reason for my departure.

review_title: Great initially but the company has fallen by the wayside in recent times.
job_title: Technical Support Engineer III in Morrisville, NC
pros: Pay and training were good. The training needs to be better now. Employees should not have to be in the same position for 9'years and should be worked with by their managers to be promoted to other positions.
cons: High stress environment. Managers are clueless. It's getting better but there is a long way to go. There seems to be a lot of employees that are dead weight or that are not looked at that should be. The environment needs to be more positive like it was 7 years ago.

pros: Salary is competitive and benefits are ok. The gym is nice and the cafe offers a huge variety of different foods. The campus is well maintained and fresh fruit and bagels once a week are a nice touch.
cons:
After the former CMO had turned the marketing organization upside down and everybody was slowly adapting to all the changes, they also brought in new senior management that didn't care about NetApp's culture. Backstabbing and politics took over.
Then the new CMO arrived and changed everything again but was hardly ever around and never connected to the team.

review_title: Used to be a great place to work
pros: A lot of smart and humble peers that can help you grow. Good work/life balance. Moderate upward mobility. Moderate amount of autonomy, Engineers have the freedom to innovate most of the time.
cons: Company got past a point where process bogs down engineer. Poor execution of higher leadership, now the the company is playing catch up with newer technologies. Stagnating wages, and degradation of company culture and employee morale.

pros: netapp offer a good work-life balance, flexi-hours, variety of timeoffs, one can choose the team they want to work for, one can even choose the kind of profile he/she wants to grow,  high career growth , people around you are equally passionate about the work and taking company miles ahead of the competition. it is like a close knitted family. people from different background, different culture do not just get chance to work together but share their culture ,express themselves through variety of events. we give so much back to the society by participating in food bank drives etc social events. the executives are just for it and we see them as heroes
cons: have not seen any todate

review_title: Well run company, some growing pains and some regional policies straying away the core of what it is to work for Netapp
pros: Benefits are great, people genuinely care and try to help each other out.  Training available when time permits.  Interesting products and good senior management.
cons: Management style of different regions vastly different.  Obvious drive to push the "numbers" at all costs.  Starting to see shift in Professional Services Organization towards micro-management.  PS folks in one region no longer in control of their own scheduling which limits flexibility and growth.

job_title: Technical Support Engineer II in Raleigh, NC
pros:
Company benefits, 401 match, Employee stock purchase plan, fun activities like "Beer Bash Fridays", cookouts, and other team building activities. Tons of training. Friendly Management. 
Relaxed dress code, and the list goes on. Competitive pay.
cons:
When it comes to the Management, sometimes the right hand doesn't seem to know what the left hand is doing. Some of the higher-ups make silly decisions that will make them look good to their Bosses, not realizing how it's going to effect the ones actually doing the work. 

If you don't like or can't handle a stressful environment, this isn't the job for you.

pros: Flexible / Employees are allowed to work from home
cons:
Company is full of cowboys who make changes to production systems at the drop of a hat without proper planning or process. Milestones such as code freeze are never met or adhered to.
Top heavy - Too many directors and VP's. No clear promotion path for lower level employees.
Heavy wastage of resources (people are not staffed properly). Some areas have too many resources and not enough work, while other areas have too much work and not enough resources.  Organized badly - No clear guidelines on which director or VP has accountability.
Workload is not shared equally by all employees.

review_title: They don't call it a Great Place to Work for no Reason
job_title: Member of Technical Staff, Software in Bangalore
pros:
The company boasts of an amazing work culture. There is a lot of focus on performance also. As such, people are very friendly and it is easy to go around and get your doubts cleared. The senior management is also very approachable and try their best to help out in any possible way. 

Its also a good place to improve skills as a Developer.
cons: You will not be able to know what kind of work you will be involved in till you actually join the company and start working.

review_title: A decent place to work -- just not in technical support
job_title: Technical Support Engineer in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: NetApp is a growing company with a good culture and fun work environment.
cons: Technical support is a mill at NetApp.  They're always too slow to react to new challenges or to get people trained in the right areas.  Always behind on CSAT.  Never staffed correctly based on what specialties are needed.

pros:
Great pay and benefits
Much talked about culture - can do attitudes and very helpful co-workers
Knowledgeable senior leadership
Great communication from senior executives via all hands meetings and initial new hire orientations
cons:
Not all management is aligned with valued culture - sometimes just words and not demonstrated in actions
Incentive compensation sometimes challenging around fiscal year end (receipt not always assured)
Poor experience with integration of acquired companies and intellectual property
Lack of career path opportunities from a management perspective (100% left up to employee to drive)
Multiple corporate layoffs in the last 12 months

pros: Work life balance is great. You can get good projects if you are a good performer. Salary, perks/benefits are top notch when you join.
cons: I served for over 10 years. Company sucks at acquisitions and integrating the same. Also management hides failures citing the reasons like macro and micro economic challenges.  Too many internal BU rename and realignment. Good at losing market dominance viz iSCSI and integrated infrastructure. It was a great company to work for, that phase is passed.

pros:
* Customer centric culture (in a good chunk of the company -- the ones who were with the company for some time).
* Company at that time had the desire to be disruptive in areas dealing with incumbency (technology, software)
* Reseller partners loved them because of the money they could make
cons:
* There was a lot of hiring, which didn't always match with the customer-centric culture (this can be tough for a company that scales beyond a certain point)
* Not always known for speed of innovation or efficiency of execution

review_title: Great people, growing pains, still stuck in box selling
job_title: Professional Services Consultant in Englewood, CO
pros: Smart, dynamic pears. Friendly environment. Easy access to education. NetApp technology can be inspirational.
cons: Field offices neglected. Still selling 'by the box'. Immature services offerings without enough investment in growth. Every role regardless of function is seen as a sales role - too much time is spent delivering and analyzing sales with non-sales staff. Travel is too much a part of the culture. Tendency to announce initiatives and then under-support or inconsistently support them.

review_title: Best place I've worked at so far in my career.
job_title: Professional Services Consultant in London, England
pros: My coworkers at NetApp are probably the smartest group of employees I've ever had the fortune of working with.  People who underperform tend not to stick around or are driven off.  It's also probably the first place I've worked where the HR department isn't useless.
cons: The hours are extremely long and there is a lot of time spent catching up with customers to respond to questions or resolve their problems.  As the consultants are mostly based from home, there isn't a lot of camraderie amongst us.  You often go for long periods of time without seeing your coworkers.  A lot of time is spent on conference calls.

review_title: Avoid if it is Professional Services Engineer
pros:
Workplace Facilities are really good. 
Few teams are good and fun to work with. 
CEO is driving the organization in efficient manner.
cons:
Lot of politics. you would not believe it is lot more than a service based company especially in services teams.
Partiality and favoritism is more here and certain people are treated in royal manner and others as trash.
Inefficient managers who do not interact well with employees and do not care about employee career.
There is no manager feedback which shows zero transparency
No more a great place to work for and pay is less than industry standard in certain teams

review_title: Good intentions, but bloated engineering bureaucracy
pros:
Open "cube culture" where even the top execs have cubes instead of offices. And frequent "all-hands" where execs address employees directly and in-person.
Perks like company gym, bagel Friday, and monthly beer bash help to boost moral.
cons:
Single product company with life-cycles so long that your children might someday see the feature you were working on. Some of the process tools used are OK, but many are so bad they are preventing a significant amount of work from being done (ex: QC). I really do not know how long NetApp can sustain this. I was so glad to go to a place where I work on something and ship it in the same few months. At NetApp, the product I worked on for almost two years finally shipped 6 months after I left.

The performance review process is to me completely unreasonable. 60% of all employees are given a "3" rating which basically means you get to keep your job. If you're lucky you get a cost-of-living raise. The top 30% or so get higher raises, and the bottom 10% better start looking for another job. The big problem is that this is "rolled up" through the company hierarchy, so people deciding your rating could be 2 or 3 levels above you who no way know your work. Since I was a manager, I had to opportunity to see how this worked, and I saw many instances of gross unfairness. Some other manager could be a better cheerleader to his boss than me, so my tight, productive testing team with great engineers would get the low ratings, and a bloated team that contributes much less would steal the 1s and 2s.

review_title: Working at NetApp has shown me how powerful executive commitment to employees can be - spending time with employees.
job_title: Senior Manager, IT in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Executive time spent with employees - talking, acknowledging accomplishments, answering questions, explaining, exciting.  Compensation is good, and stock performance has been very good in recent years.  Some of the engineers are world class.
cons: As the company is in the throws of adolescence, it struggles to cross the gap between the mantra of a new company "do whatever we can as quickly as possible" and one of a more mature company "ensure our platforms - IT, process, etc. - can sustain growth without sacrificing quality, time to market, and flexibility."

review_title: NetApp has been a great company for a long time, but may be on the verge of changing.
pros: NetApp is growing at a good clip, and has every opportunity to continue to grow market share and continue to provide good returns to investors.... and employees ....if it can survive growing pains.
cons: NetApp may overcome the obstacles to continued growth, but it has to avoid modeling itself on the wrong large companies. The problem is that NetApp is hiring many new people from those companies (and failed companies), who bring very different and quite likely undermining attitudes and ways. Strong leadership must take the company on a different course, as has been its tradition until now, in order to sustain growth. With growth comes positive opportunities for employees.

review_title: Used to be a great place to work
pros: Still has some perks for employees, like the gym and free coffee - but nothing new.
cons: It's no longer a progressive company.  No spark or passion left, only paid cheerleaders who want to keep their job or  are being paid very well to keep their job (aka Senior Management)  The rest of us are drones who come in day in and day out to earn a paycheck.

pros: There are still good people working here, but as each day passes, those numbers become fewer and fewer. The week of volunteer time off is great.
cons: They are losing their best sales talent, and then telling partners NetApp is better to be rid of them. All of 2014 Club winners have left the Central region, and turnover is out of control, specifically because the RD is a terror. They are no longer focused on strategic relationships (although they insist on and preach the contrary) but merely generating revenue at any cost. This includes bullying customers and sales reps. The end is nigh.

job_title: Support Account Manager in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: They had amazing tools here to help do your job such especially in reporting. One of the best I've seen in a company. Manager and team were wonderful to work with. Executive management became very political unfortunately.
cons:
Tons of innovation but the company didn't pursue their new technology to the end which resulted in other start ups taking their ideas and making them much better.  

A lot of processes, huge company; so not much room for growth. Support organization understaffed.

job_title: Critical Problem Resolution in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: The culture is still pretty good. The product is getting better, although showing it's age. Pay is good but not great for this industry (even at this location).
cons: There are generally no career advancement opportunities; if you want a "promotion" you have to switch jobs / departments. In my particular position, they have promised a promotion path for the last TEN YEARS but have never delivered. Upper management in particular is completely detached from reality. Even Marketing has no idea what their market is (with respect to pricing, etc.). New executives keep talking about what needs to be done but fail to provide any way to actually DO those things. After the most recent layoffs, any remaining trust or loyalty has been effectively destroyed and those that have not left probably should, as there are plenty of opportunities in the area these days. There are no raises this year and while we understand the "business reasons" for that, the bonus was terrible and you only gave small amounts to stock to favorites, including yourselves (yes, we noticed). Oh, and while the culture is still pretty decent, that's only because of the people that remain - it's NOT because of "management." Since you laid a lot of the good ones off, well.. The culture is going to vanish, too. Also.. Taking two mandatory "shutdown" weeks off every year for the last several years is a TERRIBLE way to manage a company; it's impossible to recruit anyone who will only get ten days vacation to start regardless, yet they have to use six of those at times that may not be convenient for them and their family. I've tried repeatedly to recruit very good folks but when they learn about that, they just say "no way."

job_title: Systems Administrative in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros:
The people! They are some of the best people I have ever worked with and the best managers I have worked for. I guess this would be dependant on your team, but from what I've observed, there are few bad teams to be on. It's all about the teamwork here and that makes for great culture.
Work/life balance is the best I've ever witnessed. Great Technology. Very little micro managing.
cons: A bit unstable as of late...lay-offs for a few years now. They aren't the highest paying tech company, but they do recognize hard work with bonuses. Just like anywhere else, there are ego's...just a few more here.

review_title: Great environment if you can handle the pace.
pros: The company is big enough to be able to provide excellent benefits and working environment, yet the organisation of the company allows engineers at the coal-face to be feel like, they can really influence the direction of products and hance have a positive impact on the company as a whole.
cons:
There is so much work to do, and the calibre of engineers so high that it can sometimes be a little overwhelming. Everyone I know works incredibly hard, and puts in a lot of extra hours.  

As with any company the size of NetApp (around 4500 employees) it can be frustrating when colleagues are in other timezones or countries.

review_title: Reality - Not such a great place
pros:
Senior leadership
Culture (on paper)
Technology
Customer base
Product set
cons:
Lack of trust for lower management
Questionable ethics on quotas and account assignments
Honesty and Candor - While it is highlighted as a big part of the culture, it is seldom practiced by lower management
Work/life balance is poor

review_title: Overall a great place to work, but as the company grows, the great culture doesn't always scale.
pros: I have a lot of respect for the C*Os.  Great products and team culture.  Great work/life balance.  They want employees to be productive so you're given the tools to get things done.
cons: I'm pretty unhappy about the layoffs in 2013; why do this when we're still making money? Some other policies suggest that "large-company disease" is setting in, e.g., why should any manager have the ability to blacklist any ex-employee (i.e., can never be rehired)?  Some departments have been decimated and demoralized by bad management hires.

job_title: Senior Professional Services Engineer in Charlotte, NC
pros: Hard working employees. In my 13 plus years at NetApp (Network Appliance) i worked with some of the brightest technical talent ever.
cons: Most of the techies have been laid off or outsourced. NetApp is heavy with middle management, product managers and program managers. Most of these "managers" only generate email to each other and schedule meetings where the only action is to schedule another meeting.

pros: NetApp offers a pretty decent benefits package, and every team I've worked for is very trusting when it comes to your work schedule. As long as you get your work done, you can be in the office or work from home when it makes the most sense for you/your team.
cons:
Ultimately, I have become totally disillusioned with NetApp in my time here, and there is an ongoing mass exodus of employees that feel the same way. Here are my observations:

- The biggest problem at NetApp is the business unit structure. While this model may work really well in other organizations, I consider this a colossal mistake in NetApp's case. The BUs act like little fiefdoms, who not only don't work together at all but actively criticize the others on a constant basis.

- NetApp has become increasingly political in my time here. There's an extreme attitude of "don't play in my sandbox", often at the cost of collaboration. The blame game is huge in every team I've worked for or with. This political atmosphere also creates a death-by-committee when it comes to decision-making. To get approval for even mundane things, you often have to get approval/input from 5-10 people, because they all want to be the decision-maker on everything.

- There is very little opportunity for growth here. Basically, moving your career path means moving into a lateral position, until there is another layoff. Layoffs happen often, and upper management never acknowledges them or explains them, so instead, one day you'll just notice a whole bunch of colleagues are gone.

- NetApp is stuck in its way of thinking, and from my perspective, out of touch with the market. It immediately dismisses competitors like Pure and Nutanix instead of learning from their successes. There's a reason potential customers love their simplicity...being outrageously complicated isn't a good thing for a tech company. And this "stuck" way of thinking might also be due to the makeup of employees. At least at headquarters, the average age of an employee has to be 50. There are maybe 20 people under 30 on the entire campus, and every year the intern program seems to get smaller. If you don't hire a better percentage of young talent, you're never going to evolve with the market and keep your perspective fresh.

review_title: Incompetent technical team and very insecure (leads to horrible politics)
pros:
1. flexible timings
2. average salary
cons:
1. Horrible politics.
2. teams keep fighting with each other for work and job security.
3. people even design systems keeping job security in mind! what a product company!
4. mgmt never tries to keep the domain and scope of teams separate.
5. usa conf calls are always at night india time, no respect for indians
6. it is gradually becoming managers'company, no more a tech company.

review_title: NetApp not worthy of the hype.
pros: Benefits are good.  In general there is a good work/life balance.  Regular working from home is encouraged and supported.  Facilities are generally good.
cons:
IT degenerated under current leadership into a highly political organization where personal relationships are more important than competence.  Competent employees were not recognized for their contributions.  The strong drive to the bottom line results in line staff that just can't get the job done.  Most staff, including the contractors, are better at hiding their incompetence and taking credit for the work of others than doing the job they were hired to do.

There's a strong "blame the victim" mentality among IT leadership and HR; it's never their fault that something failed in the face of poor management and planning, it's always the employee's fault.

pros: Friendly working environment. People are candid. Culture matters.
cons:
Perks are not as good as those internet companies but kind of well played in the storage industry (or system level company in general), may be after VMware.

Cooperation with team players in Bangalore is kind of pain sometimes due to the timezone. Plus some of them are very in-responsive to working emails making me think they're not working..Investment in India might be too much and not exactly worth it in my opinion.

review_title: Great for exposure to a broad spectrum of technologies. Not so great for professional growth. WAY too many meetings.
job_title: Unix Systems Administrator in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Opportunity to enhance skills in every aspect of the modern datacenter: VDI (VMware, Xen), networking, storage (FC, iSCSI, NFS, CIFS), Enterprise OSes (Windows 2008/2012, RHEL/Debian/Suse, FreeBSD)).
cons: Limited/unclear professional growth path for 'in the trenches' IT. Frequent layoffs that negatively impact overall perception of the company among current employees. Management calls far too many unnecessary meetings with no clear purpose for all participants.

job_title: TSE in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: In our vertical there is excellent management support.  I work with the best group of people I've ever worked with.  Training offered is very good.  Pretty good perks.  The famous (or infamous) Beer Bash on Fridays.  I've never had a boring day.  I've been here a year and I love it.
cons: As a whole the company has been slow to respond to market changes.  I love working here, but I can't help wondering where it will be in 3-5 years.   It was slow to recognize the the growing strength/threat of cloud based storage to its oem server hardware approach and failed early on to develop its own products for that market.

job_title: Software Engineering Manager in Wichita, KS
pros: company now has a strong product portfolio (data services, performance, scale out). management truly cares about employees and people are encouraged to do the right things. not overly heavy on processes; strives for agility. strives to be a best place to work by giving everyone opportunities to contribute. the company is improving its operational efficiency, which should help us grow our bottom-line (long time criticism of the company)
cons: too many layoffs and not enough stability. the company grew fast over the last several years and struggles to deal with the challenges of a 10.000+ employee company that they didn't have to worry about when the company size was 5000 and growing.

pros: Overall good working environment, people, and culture.  Benefits and compensation is on par with other storage companies/tech firms.  Moving up the chain as a leader in the Flash market.
cons: Lots of turnover from senior management to field sales.  Recent layoffs and some politics as people are very concerned about losing their jobs and trying to look busy and valuable.  Tough storage/data management market and macroeconomic issues are creating lots of pressure and a bit of panic mode. Inspection from all levels on deals on a weekly basis.

review_title: Good company to Work With with bad Managers around.
pros:
Good workplace.
Free Snacks every evening 6 PM.
Unlimited Free Beers every Friday.
Excellent new Campus
cons:
Managers are very worst especially the level 1 managers they do the full favor to the one who butters them well.
Frist line (L1) managers in support are not even fit for their job, they are biased and have lacked in leadership quality. So many good guys left because of their managers.

pros:
Corporate culture - people want to be at NetApp and generally try to make it a great place to be.
information shareing  - you can generally find what you need to know, who you need to talk to and they actually call you back  !
cons:
middle management doesn't get it.  It's one of the best led, worst managed places.
Recruiter team is slow to respond and doesn't know how to follow up.  candidates languish and twist in the wind while waiting for a call back .

pros: It's great to work for a company that has customers who are very enthusiastic about the products. Also, Netapp is in the sweet spot of a growth industry. The product features are very good and you can see by the amount of sales that even in this economic downturn, our products are where they need to be. Combine that with an excellent compensation package and there is almost nothing to complain about. Compared to other employers, I could really see what makes this company a Great Place To Work. From now on, I only will work for companies that rate high in Great Place to Work competitions.
cons: There is no possibility of working part time.

review_title: Life at NetApp is pretty good compared to other high tech companies
pros: They treat employees well; lots of perks & freebies; good benefits; nice surroundings; great food in cafe & break rooms. Flexible scheduling when possible. Good teamwork & work ethic. Management more human than some other places. Still opportunities to carve out career paths. Change can happen fast from top down; employee suggestions are often listened to.
cons: Workload can be considerable to impossible. Communications between teams/depts could be better. Middle & lower management not always as good as top management. Change can happen fast from top down; ideas are listened to but implementation can get complicated.

pros:
Benefits and Salary are pretty good.  For the most part employees are treated fairly well. 
Career advancement opportunities are available.
cons:
Not a problem before but now that they have grown so big a lot of employees can be self serving so depending on what department you are in you might have to watch your back.
I've seen this happen to a few people; if a manager wants you out for any reason (including personal) you will be gone eventually.

review_title: Management be aware of the politics and discrimination to Non-American employees!
job_title: Software QA Engineer in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: its a ok place to be, if you not in the group of nasty people
cons: HR and management not ruling the company well. There is a lot of discrimination against foreign nationals.

job_title: Senior Software QA Engineer in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: 10 years ago, this was truly a great place to work. Even now there are plenty of challenges. Certainly there is room for improvement and innovation in the product, if only management would get out of the way. It depends to some extent on which group you work in; there are a small number of business units where the micromanagement has not yet become oppressive, if you can get into one such group you may be very pleased to work here.
cons:
The company has lost its way, stifling innovation through its policies of overtaxing employees to the point there is no time for creative testing or creating innovative product features unless you are willing to give up any chance of work-life balance.
