Over the past several years the influx of former Cisco VPs and upper management has changed the culture to fear-based management and their policy of requiring that some percentage of each business unit's personnel be given a bad focal review rating even when performing well has turned the culture from one of cooperation between peers to one of competition between peers. This has led to backbiting and unrest, loss of productivity and decline of the once-great culture. Correlation is not the same as causation but it is interesting to compare Cisco vs NetApp 5-year stock charts as Cisco shed  these knuckleheads and NetApp brought them on board.

Raises and bonuses have been pathetic across the board for several years and the much of the best talent remaining after so many good, high-performing people were laid off has left due to feeling under-appreciated after the latest performance review cycle. 

The company killed of 7-mode ONTAP to push C-Mode, when many of the top engineers felt that there was nothing C-Mode accomplished that could not have been accomplished in 7-Mode. Why? Apparently because C-Mode requires updated hardware, and somebody thought that forcing customers into forklift upgrades would boost the bottom line. Too bad they overlooked the fact that when faced with a forklift upgrade customers will look at what other options they can forklift in, and there are other products out there with better innovation roadmaps.

pros: Shut-downs 2 times a year gives time to travel.
cons:
Doesn't Recommend
Negative Outlook
Very slow processes, laid back, boring, low-pay, very slow promotions. Lot of senior engineers and managers who have been here for a long time and keep creating projects which never get implemented (they spend a lot of time on this anyways). If you are in the core teams, you will be stuck with old-generation C coding which will not help your resume much i.e. no new technologies/tools used. Frequent lay-offs in the past few years have also led to a lot of unnecessary drama and rumors. If you are on H1-B this affects your green card process. If you are new grad, do yourself a favor and do not join.

review_title: Netapp was once a great company
pros: Great people to work with. Excellent work/life balance. Beautiful Sunnyvale campus with a top notch cafe that serves many choices. Nice company gym with free classes, basketball court, and wide selection of equipment.
cons: Increasing competition from startups (Pure, Nimble, etc.) and poor vision from executives have led to NetApp tanking over the past few years. Company has had yearly layoffs the past 4-5 years which resulted in poor moral amongst the employees. NetApp dropped off the list of Fortune's "100 best companies to work for" for the first time this year (they were once ranked # 1 back in 2009)

job_title: Senior Member of Technical Staff in Bangalore
pros: One of the best perks of working at NetApp is the lucrative package they offer inspite of the lesser work pressure. And off course, the friday beer bash is famous industry wide.
cons: But the kind of responsibilities they offer to an employee are sometimes not sufficient to quench the technical thirst of an employee and he/she ultimately ends up just earning money and not a good amount of learning along side.

review_title: Horrible, harassing and stressful - expect PTSD
pros: If you find the right position and work with a honorable group this is a great place to work.  I quote one of the TMEs "I love this job!  It's like being retired and collecting a paycheck".
cons: There was no personal growth, no upward mobility, horrible salary increases, poor review processes.  As an example, they use laddering to rate every person and enforce the bell curve so if you have a small team, the curve is skewed and a team of top performers could not all be ones or twos.

pros: The work environment and people, in general, are great. Typical perks of a large company including snacks and drinks. Occasional company events that are well done and people seem to support each other. Plenty of managers do a great job supporting those below them and are very knowledgeable.
cons: Recent layoffs make things unpredictable at times and the data storage industry is as well. Need more direction towards cloud computing or sticking with storage only, but decisions need to be made.

review_title: Decent pay, decent benefits.  Poor management, and the employees are generally not treated well.
pros: Pretty good pay, good benefits.  If you have a good manager who is willing to fight for you, it's a decent place to work.
cons:
I have very little faith in upper management.   Quarterly all-hands meetings involve the guys in charge standing up there bragging about what a good job they are doing, and making excuses for why the company isn't living up to expectations and why the stock is tanking.  When we do well they are geniuses, and when we do poorly it's about "market conditions".  

Individual project managers are worse: they are only concerned about getting THIS release done on time, so they can collect their bonuses and move on to something else.  They generally don't care about actually doing it properly, so that the solution scales and is maintainable.  This leads to things getting VERY messy.  It's obviously a lot less work to make an initial time investment and do it right the first time, but project managers have no incentive to do this, because they will be leading some other project by the time the sh*t hits the fan and someone has to clean up their mess.  Suggesting a good, scalable solution instead of a "quick hack" will get shot down because of time considerations... the fact that the good solution will save many man-months of work in the long run is ignored, because the guy making the decisions only has monetary incentive to get this release done ASAP; there is no incentive to actually do a good job.

The company doesn't care about their employees.  Last year they shut down over the whole week of the 4th of July.  Your choices were, either take 4 days of vacation, or don't get paid.  Who cares if you had other vacation time planned during the year?  Not the guys in charge, that's for sure.

review_title: a company going from a great startup to a big company.
pros: stable company now in terms of cash flow.  pays well and expects to get your job done as defined by your boss.  transitioning to a  big company
cons: classic big company problems - beaurocratic, fall inline attitude, risk averse, etc.  many of the old timers are just waiting for retirement.  they should retire if the company has to grow and by that i mean > market growth.  there are several core gangs that have formed over time that resist newer thinking.

job_title: Technical Marketing Engineer in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: NetApp has an amazing set of products and solutions for enterprise data storage.  NetApp has a well-communicated strategy to approach a changing IT landscape. The culture is good and the focus on being a great place to work with a good work life balance is nice.
cons: With several reductions in force in the past few years, it feels like there is always a looming threat that if two quarters of flat or negative growth occurs, there will be another reduction in force.

review_title: Layoffs drain away the confidence of employees
pros:
Free beer on most Fridays, free cookies in the break rooms, a in-house gym, most teams have a good WFH policy.

Central location, and a nice well maintained office buildings
cons:
High performing employees are no longer confident of retaining their jobs, since there is absolutely no logic when it comes to laying off people. 

Even employees with top 2 rating have also been laid off. Moreover, layoffs have become an annual affair now...sometimes even bi-annual. If you manage to please your US boss, you may retain your job during layoffs. Indian managers have absolutely no say....they even do not know who in their team gets laid off.

The HR is mostly non existent after your joining formalities are done. The team that I was part of had absolutely no interaction with the HR team during the 5 years of my stay there, except during hiring and during the annual layoffs. My peer level managers too mentioned they meet HR only during these times.

The salary packages are now way below the industry benchmark. It used to be attractive about 5 years ago. 
Many teams have not got any salary raises last year and this year....and the bonuses have been miniscule in comparison with what was paid around 5 years ago.

Career growth in India is limited....favouritism is raising its ugly head in many teams, especially since the few  projects that come to India are very reluctantly given to India by the US bosses.
Looks like they are aiming to have only a marketing and sales presence in India in the years to come.

It was truly a great company to work for till about 3 years ago...not anymore.

pros: Smart middle managers with expertise.  Co workers are generally nice and support each other, trying very hard to succeed in spite of a lack of resources and constant organization reorganizations.
cons: Too many chiefs -- a  very vertical organization.  Little autonomy.  No chance for advancement.or meaningful pay increases.   Lack of sufficient staffing and funding.  Cumbersome internal approval processes.  Annual layoffs beating down morale.

review_title: Good but with lots of issues
pros:
Netapp has good pay and health benefits plus turnover seems to be pretty low.  And the internal education site has access to such things like the Harvard Manage Mentor modules, in addition to all the other technical training provided.  And you get something like $5500 a year for college reimbursement, but has what seems like tighter than average rules on it.

A neat benefit if your into volunteering is paid volunteer time off to a charity organization.

If your a coffee drinker and happen to work in one of the offices, save your starbucks money because the coffee is usually starbucks beans in a custom machine.
cons:
Only in Sunnyvale or RTP do you really get access to the onsite benefits.  The other locations are typical office buildings with cubes, nothing special.

If your an overachiever, the hiring process makes you think your going to work with people at or above your level.  But its more like Wile E Coyote using black paint for the tunnel, and you quickly realize your the train about to run them over.  Lots of old decision making processes, that don't make sense regarding customers, products, tools, and teams.  And there always seems to be restructuring going on somewhere.

So a big grind from all the people I talk to is vacation, when you first start there you get 2 weeks just like everyone else.  But they force vacation as a shutdown at Christmas for 3-4 days, and starting in 2012 at 4th of july for 3 more days.  So your losing 6-7 days or you go without pay during the shutdowns.  

Time management is critical at this company, because it is overwhelmed with busy work of emails and meetings.  The amount of email is at least double of any other company I ever been at.  And finding information is always a challenge, due to the shear number of "portals" the company has.  They are trying to consolidate but at a snails pace.

Something in regard to annual reviews that all members of my team never understood was the rating system.  Ratings from 1(best) to 5(worst), but by HR definition only 10% are allowed to be issued a 1. It is then that something like %20 can be 2, then 50-60% are 3's.  4 and 5 are reserved for people not doing their job.  So if there are only 5 people in your dept, then only 0.5% can be a 1.  And your rating of course determines your "merit" increase, as there are no cost of living adjustments I have seen.  So they claim a life / work balance, but not if you expect a 1 or 2.  If you just go to and from the office in typical fashion you will get a 3.

I have never been at an IT manufacturer before, where the internal IT really was behind the times.  Your local in office people are good, but decisions come from HQ and India. There are constant upgrades happening and such, but the shear number of outages to critical databases is sometimes staggering.  The help desk is definitely run out of india, and they will close tickets as resolved when their clearly not.  But instead of re-opening a ticket, they create a new one.  So somehow the metrics are tied to number of tickets resolved.  And you will end up opening lots of tickets due to all the portals you will need access to.  But everything is designed with Windows in mind, so if you happen to have a MAC, which they claim to support, you might be out of luck getting help.

job_title: Unfortunae Engineer Worked In Eyewash R&D Group of NetApp Bangalore in Bangalore
pros:
Easy to decide whether to join R&D group of netapp bangalore or not
Don't ever think to join NetApp Bangalore's R&D group, you will be incompetent very soon and you logical ability will go in vain and will be completely lost among bunch of illogical management and senior people in this group.
Worst place in this world to work for any reasonable good person
I wish there is -ve infinite rating to rate, I would have given -ve infinite
cons:
Complete eyewash in the name in R&D
looting of hard earn NetApp money 
Dictatorship, angry and retaliating nature of management
Political and non-sense senior people who will make your life hell if you work with them
Management is completely dull and sick and makes other people sick as well
No value of being technically good
You are valuable only if you are politically aligned with management

job_title: Technical Support Engineer III in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: It can be difficult to make a decent wage in IT and not work 60+ hours a week. NetApp is has a great work/life balance. I really never work over 44 hours a week. Also working in support really sharpens your skills, but it can be painful. I am twice the engineer I was prior to coming to this company.
cons: Three layoffs in 2 years. The workload can be overwhelming and creates alot of stress, but at least there is little to no OT. Far too many antiquated systems causing you to have to do work in 6 different systems rather than just one. Bleeding talent.

review_title: Too slow to adapt to change
pros: Decent salaries, industry standard benefits. Good and knowledgable co-workers. Storage is a good industry to be in.
cons: There is a good amount of non-performers in every level(engineers to vp/svp). May be about 30-40 percent. Good engineers/managers pay for it ( in terms of no raises, no rsu etc. You will be surprised to see how long people who are not productive are stuck to. It will take some non trivial effort to make the company go in the right direction.

pros:
Like any job, working at NetApp is largely dependent on what you make of it. If you stay positive, work hard and contribute, you will succeed. If you maintain an air of negativity, do the bare minimum of what is required and stay in the shadows. you won't be as successful. 

The culture is great - lots of opportunity to do different things, learn, tinker and take risks. Work/life balance is really about how you manage your time.

As for senior management, moving Kurian to CEO was the right call. I was very close to leaving after the last RIF, especially since it seemed way more random than the previous ones. I've been at NetApp for nearly 10 years and survived several of those, but that one made the least sense in terms of who they let go. But getting rid of Georgens was a good start. I also agree with the overall direction and strategy of NetApp in a crowded, ever changing storage landscape. I still believe in NetApp and am not convinced that any other company is without their own set of challenges.
cons:
Work satisfaction also depends on what department you work in. I started in support and am now on the product operations side. There is definitely a difference in the "Great Place to Work" reality between the two.

Support was always "row harder" and driven by some flawed metrics. Too many managers that don't actually manage their employees, but simply serve as escalation managers when customers call in to complain about long running cases. TSEs are always backlogged with cases and many of them will sandbag to slow the deluge. The backlog leaves little room to self-improve during business hours and instead have to work extra hours to stay ahead. Promotions are hard to come by and seem politically motivated at times - sometimes to simply keep people after they threaten to leave. I can't speak for job satisfaction as a manager, as I never worked in that role.

In my current role, it's night and day. The stress level is very low and the amount of work is manageable rather than  overwhelming. However, this role has different challenges, such as lack of a clear definition of the job, which leaves it open to interpretation when reviews come around. There is also a lack of metrics that matter, which is alarming for a role that is less reactive (such as support) and more "how are we helping generate revenue." It's near impossible to make meaningful sense of our actual contributions to sales, even though it feels like we do meaningful work.

pros: Overall there is Respect for people and diversity. Good salary, challenging jobs, nice people. Best Croissant on Fridays:-) good salary.
cons: Not enough focus on people and people development: it's simply not seen as something which has a ROI. Lately too much company focus on saving money, even in development of software, with consequent delays in providing fixes. There are still some managers, senior mgr and directors who are too unexperienced to make a difference.

pros:
They offer very flexible schedule and work life balance was great and benefits are good.
The work was very challenging and interesting.
Get to work with very smart people who really care about the company and what happens to it.
cons:
Layoffs every 6 months, no security.
Company did not change directions to meet the market need soon enough and I'm not sure if they are going to be able to catch up.
They change directions every time they have layoffs so just about the time you get going in one direction, it changes again.  You are never able to accomplish anything.

pros: Management, Peers, and Sales team were good people to work with. Work life balance was never an issue. Products and technology is solid.
cons: Upper management was disconnected and almost unaware of what was going on in the trenches. Decisions were made, often, that were not logical. Middle management was not included in key decisions that directly affected the team. Customers wold often get upset with the frequent changes in staff. Perception was that the company was unstable. Frequent changes in the portfolio made it difficult to instill confidence in the customer base.

review_title: One of the Best Places to work in the San Francisco bayarea
job_title: Support Program Manager in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: I worked at NetApp for 10 years. Great place to work, good middle management and excellent benefits. The vast majority of people there enjoy being there and driving the company forward.  After the recent changes, I expect them to recover lost ground quickly.
cons: The last CEO was too slow to make the changes required and also kept some of the wrong people at senior executive level.

review_title: One of the Best Employer in the IT Industry
pros:
- Work Culture 
- Benefits
- Care for the Employees 
- Most important - Competitive Salary  and benefits
- Top Class Campus and amenities
cons: One thing I dont like is frequent Layoffs

review_title: Your happiness within a company can vary dramatically depending on the GROUP you are in and who you report to.
pros: If you have a good Manager who knows what work/life balance is, then its great.  But, many there have no idea what that term means.
cons:
I think your happiness within a company can vary dramatically depending on the GROUP you are in and who you report to.
I was in 2 different groups at NetApp and had 2 totally, TOTALLY different experiences. The lunch room prices were also getting very expensive.

review_title: Lots of potential; critical issues not being addressed that diminish viability of work place.
pros: Top level leadership is impressive.  Pay is decent.  Benefits are decent.  There are perks:  employee gym,  free Peets and Starbuck coffee, bagel bar on Fridays, free fruit on Tuesday - $.25 sodas, I believe subsidized food at cafeteria - and seems like folks order food all the time for meetings and share it with the rest - and a beautiful campus plus flexible work environment.  There are a lot of smart, talented and friendly individuals.  Extra holiday provided as long as company maintains best place to work status.  Company parties are fun and generous.  There is a lot of intent to make this a good place and top management appears to lead by example with is energizing.
cons: Too much talk about being the best place to work - not enough proactive management to ensure accountability so that is actually IS the best place to work.  In Marketing - it's clear the executive team is in disagreement with one another just through the conflicting directions employees receive on the same topics.  Plus,  the waffling back and forth over the course of months on topics is inexcusable from leaders.   At the same time we are expected to work as teams - to conflicting changing  goals that are rarely expressed in SMART fashion let along actually measured and adjusted for reality.   Escalation of conflict to the managerial level means you are not doing your job - even though the conflict is a level or more above your role.  There seems to be a pervasive habit of back stabbing and bad mouthing - disagreements are won in passive aggressive fashion and employees are stuck in the middle.  This environment leads to fear - and fear based behaviors are prevalent.  There is a lack of trust and also a lot of chatter about how bad it is and a lot of people looking for jobs - and leaving but offering to help anyone else left to get out.

review_title: NetApp - Not as great as they used to be
pros: NetApp does pay attention to the "Best Places to Work" criteria. The benefits are good and you have to admire the 40 hrs/year of paid volunteer time off.
cons: The lack of discipline was OK as the company was growing, now that the company is a lot larger the "cowboy" way of creating products will hurt the company's ability to put out reliable products. But the company has a lot of "heros" who will put in long hours to solve a critical customer problem.

pros: NetApp has a lot of good people and has some unique products in the market. The work life balance is good.
cons: Perpetually late to market with innovation, are rarely able to capitalise on the innovation they bring. Stuck in a cycle of selling to an ever decreasing pool of existing customers. For the past few years, they have been abandoning their reputation as 'the good guys' and not being honest to the market- 5:1 data reduction guarantee- really?

review_title: A great first impression from a new hire perspective.
pros: I feel taken care of here. There are many resources available and you're encouraged to take charge of your own professional development. Some people may not like the open-ended environment, but this is something I thrive off of. A lot of learning material is available online and there is a good sense of community.
cons: Haven't been here long enough to know the intricacies of the company, but the only complaint I have so far is that the employee resources could be organized better. I have run into broken links and outdated information, but I make sure to do my part and report them.

review_title: Realize your potential and allow people to realize their potential to the maximum.
pros: Smart people around you (not that the smartness is used and they start rusting). Not too process oriented but not sure for how long.
cons: Being at cross roads from a small efficient start up like setup and a big lethargic slow moving company, there is lack of long term focus in the various activities.

review_title: Good, but not great place to work
pros:
Smart, fun people. 
Interesting technical problems.  
Consistently profitable company.  
Reasonable benefits.  
Executives who are smart and communicate well about their vision for the company.
cons:
Less generous vacation policy than other tech companies.  Combined with mandatory time off (i.e., use your vacation days or take time without pay) at Xmas and July 4th, you have very little discretionary vacation time until you've been there long enough to get more then 3 weeks/year of vacation

Very tight with discretionary spending. Breaking records for revenue quarter after quarter, but it's a major struggle for distributed team members to meet face to face once or twice a year.

review_title: NetApp was an OK place to work, Apple was much more interesting and dynamic.
job_title: Senior Program Manager in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: There are a few pockets of brilliance. I enjoyed working on a high performing team for most of my tenure at NetApp.
cons: There are many mediocre managers who are interested in self-promotion and are not contributing to moving the company forward. Unfortunately, upper management appeared to not have a clue who these people were even though HR knows. They were unable or unwilling to eliminate bully managers who are detrimental to the company's success. Lots of political infighting.

pros: The company's definition of "best places to work" means "free fruit Tuesdays" and "Bagel Fridays."
cons:
Product managers are not respected by anyone, and there are very poor career choices for them.  Engineers claim they don't treat product managers well because it's a "engineering-run" company.  What BS!

The worst middle managers you will find anywhere - insecure and not transparent.  People with 10+ years here are just coasting, without doing any work.  A lot of people (including those in sales) are leaving, and management's attitude is that instead of doing layoffs, they will not issue replacement reqs.  People staying back have to work harder, with no rewards.

pros: There is still beer on most fridays and the gym is nice. They have purchased new equipment for the conference rooms. They got rid of their CEO.
cons:
It has lost all of the innovation and vision that it had 10 years ago. 
They are super late to the party on new technologies, ie all flash, cloud and clustering.
Internal tools could use a refresh badly.
Wage is below local market value in area

The last round of layoffs is proof that they do not think things out before executing

job_title: Member Of Technical Staff in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Great Salary and Benefits, lots of nice people working there.  It does appear that the corporate culture does value employees and tries to provide many avenues for balancing work and life. I did meet some very pleasant people here.
cons: Heavy on process, lack of transparency , losing market share so frequent layoffs.   New product development doesn't happen here, only extension of existing products. Current management has a CYA attitude, and cost cutting / outsourcing abounds.  Managers expect you to be on call 24x7 so as to accomodate offshore development teams.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros: NetApp's founders had a very good culture in mind when they started the company, and tried very hard to keep it going. There were some very smart, competent, compassionate people there.
cons: Like any company, NetApp had its share of incompetent, petty, mean managers who promoted their friends and punished others who might have brought different views or suggestions for improvement or change.

pros: Good pay and progression opportunities
cons: Has always been self-indulgent culture, but has become very political and fickle over past 12 months. A lot of people are blowing smoke and not taking care of business. Everyone is a bit dizzy from the stock price. A lot of people getting fired in the name of transformation, but really just to create a distraction from their bosses incompetence. There is a lot of fear and it is challenging to recruit people.

job_title: Member Technical Staff in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Stable job, no major layoff history, good gym, cafe.
cons:
No career growth, too many managers in engineering dept.
Lately NetApp has hired a lot of managers in engineering dept. A lot of them do not manage engineering projects directly. Their job is to just manage other managers.

review_title: Great company that needs new laptops.
pros:
- Great pay. Even the summer interns make more annually than most starting engineers in the Valley.
- Good food in the cafeteria. Very expensive and high quality but very cheap (2-9 dollars).
- Awesome HR staff.
- Beer bashes! 
- Great benefit plan. 
- Paid time off for volunteer work.
cons:
- Antiquated equipment. Some of the laptops they give out are T40-T42 series, which aren't exactly the best machines to develop on.
- Beer bashes are something like monthly now. 
- Public still doesn't know enough about NetApp. It may be one of the best companies to work for, but having to explain who you work for to non-techies is annoying.

job_title: Member Technical Staff II in Bangalore
pros: Cutting edge technology to work on. Good work environment. Excellent learning curve.Fair understanding of OS , Storage protocols such as FCP, iSCSI, NFS , CIFS . All are integrated together under one umbrella. Gives scope for testing all protocols
cons: Pay can be on par with the best since technology is the best. Management needs to be clearer on individual goals . The goals are very ambiguous . This needs to be corrected . Focal should be aligned with other companies time period

review_title: It was a wonderful experience, with lots to learn, a lot of opportunities and exposure to cutting edge technology
job_title: Member of Technical Staff, Software in Bangalore
pros: The work culture is great. There is open communication at NetApp. I felt proud working for NetApp. I am looking forward to an opportunity to continue to work with NetApp once after my MBA studies. Core Values and Principles are emphasized really well.
cons: The support staff at NetApp needs to be more polite and less arrogant. Its a great place to work and need to concentrate to become #1  storage solutions vendor in the market

pros: Great work culture, flexible work hours, personal and career growth. The team members are friendly.
cons: Depends on the manager....mine was a really bad one and he showed favoritism and discriminated based on gender, language, made inappropriate and unethical comments. Despite showing proof of the manager's bad behavior, no action was taken. It brought a lot of stress and made my decision to quit that much easier.

pros: Great People, nice place to work overall, but that is about it. Company is not well balance between Sales and rest of the organisation, if you are outside sales be prepare to work 12 to 14 hour days, daily.
cons:
Outside sales, be prepare to work extremely hard and long hours. Nearly all resources go into Sales headcount. 
The product is 1 dimensional and company is pretty flat, all the best people are leaving. 
NetApp have wasted their opportunity in the market place which they work hard to get too 3 to 4 years ago.

pros: Highly motivated and talented employees -- very helpful people even across divisions. Fast paced work culture and it can be sometimes overload. If you are a great engineer in dev team, you probably would see very fast paced career (and compensation/rewards)growth.
cons: Non-engineering functions in  sites (outside US) usually do not get the right visibility and growth  despite great talent. Site based re-organization/consolidation is something that needs to be a one-time change and not something that changes on a regular basis

review_title: Stuck in CDOT, Stopped Innovating, Doesn't understand Cloud
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Existing culture is still OK. That's the people culture - not the corporate Culture.
cons:
Corporate wants the "Best Place To Work" and touts the culture. But it used to promote that first knowing that the company performance followed. Now that the company has lost it's way every other sentence in All Hands seems to be about Culture - but there's no corporate backing for it. Corporate wants it all - but is sacking people like EMC - numbers.

Netapp USED to have one layoff for an entire recession, re-strategize the products, and come out running with good products - and no fear of further layoffs.  

This is the third layoff in a row - the 1st was "the one for the recession" - but it showed they no longer understood the market (hint - it's NOT CDOT - too myopic on that one). Last years they sacked most of the few cloud projects while saying "we don't understand cloud" and it was obvious by who got laid off they "gave up" on a fiscal deadline for re-slotting people.

So for most, last year in particular was a wake up call for employees. This years - including appropriate corporate sacking - showed no further understanding of market or vision. Sure they patched up a hybrid-cloud strategy - that's good for NOW - but what's the strategy? CDOT is, what 90% of revenue, and they've not acquisitions on sight either way.

Kurian is a bean counter and his main advice at all hands was "execute faster" Execute a market indicated failed strategy faster?

review_title: Great company to work for in a great industry. No real complaints.
job_title: Sales Development Representative in Boulder, CO
pros: Understands modern work environment. I work hard because I want to, not because I’m being micromanaged. Does mean some minor personal growing pains but allows for more organic growth at a personal level. Support when needed from management is there. Room for growth within the company and industry with a growing market segment and improved tech.
cons: Not a con if you know what you’re doing but is a very relationship based role and excellent networking is needed to grow within the company

pros:
Flexible Timings
Compensation/ESOPS/RSU
Competent Peers
Good Technology - 
Branding - Netapp brand is a huge value add to one's profile.
Beer Bash
cons:
Tons of process,reviews.
Legacy monolithic system. Work is hampered by process,dependancies between teams. 
Sadly,everything is evaluated by the count of the burts solved.
High level of Micromanagement prevails,
The work totally depends on the team. Some teams have fabulous work and the workload is quite steep.
Quite a disbalance in terms of workload between teams
No transport - Go green and connect to work in public tansport .
Work from home depends on the team.
The culuture is very similar to other product companies. Strange that they get the "great place to work".

pros: Very supportive, people-first environment.  Senior management values the fact that NetApp is a great place to work, and they want to keep it that way.  Exciting product portfolio that seems well positioned to succeed in the "new economy."  Great benefits and perks.  Work-life balance is excellent.
cons: Some disorganization, but that is typical of most large companies.  Seems that quality control was lacking in the past but management seems to be aware and is really working on it.  Upward mobility is not necessarily limited but could take a while.

pros: NetApp was an awesome place to work. Executive that was in place in the distant past was excellent and was able to pull it through the dot com bust. Since Dan left has totally changed, they totally missed the boat on cloud and are now paying for it. Culture used to be the primary thing that made it a great place to work but that has been lost. It is now a cut throat culture. One of the reasons that so many people stayed for so long but are now being dismissed without consideration.
cons: Mis-management has it going down the tubes. Multiple reductions in force occurring each year. Work life becoming unmanageable as there are fewer and fewer people to do the work.

pros: This is a very forward thinking company.  Senior management has good communication and keep all the employees well informed.  Their new hire orientation is the best i've every seen in my 20 year career.  The senior management is very straightforward and honest in their messaging.
cons: Not so good if you are in hardware as they OEM HW.  Now if you are looking for a job in HW where you want to cruise then it may be the perfect job for you.  Also, the stock has not done so well recently.  But, hopefully thats only temporary due to the economy in general.

pros: Culture is amazing at NetApp from the HR team to the janitors it's rather nice place to work. They take care of their employees, and truly value community service.
cons: The growth path is just not there. People either have to die or get fired for any real growth paths to show them selves. The dream that you are sold on as you enter the work place is just that "a dream." It very much a stepping stone to something better not a full on career choice. Pay is not that great, and they truly are the feel of a 6billion dollar company. This companies worth is truly just a resume builder.

review_title: Truely a great place to work.
job_title: Member of Technical Staff IV in Bangalore
pros:
+ great culture and values (used to be)
+ great work place benefits like cafe, play area, gym, etc
+ great technology
+ work life balance
+ beer bash :)
cons:
- good growth oppertunity only during initial years. you hit the glass cieling very quickly
- company has become big and is no more fun it used to be. The culture has changed a lot with too much of beurocracy
- a new campus is coming up in whitefield is going to become inconvinent for a number of old timers

review_title: Good place to work, transforming to a better place
pros: Great people to work with, company is fairly good at allowing individuals to grow their career and change assignments.  Company is on an "uptick", transforming from a "start up" mentality to a fully formed and functioning IT corporation ready to take on their competition in the IT Storage and Cloud arenas.  An exciting time to be a part of NetApp!
cons: Too many job cuts in the past several years have had a major impact on morale.  Too much work moved offshore and contracted, making it hard to get into NetApp to launch and grow an IT career in the Storage industry.

pros:
Work life balance is given importance hence engineers are not encouraged to attend conf. calls
Great people with immense talent
Very transparent Management team
Awesome work culture
cons:
Package is good but not the best in the industry
Managers should encourage organic growth
Lack of accountability may lead to misuse
People who joined the company from other companies are diluting the quality of hiring by trying to bring someone from their previous organisation would have a negative impact

pros:
40hr volunteer time
Beer bash still onsite, thankfully
Good people to work with
Compensation ok
cons:
Performance feedback vague...NetApp says you "own" your career, limited opportunities
Lost culture that defined the work environment.  Senior management, VP's clueless to this shift, unfortunately.
Engineers expected to work cadence above all else, quality is lost and we pay for it later with field issues.
Losing engineers to competitors and management remarks this as planned "attrition".

review_title: Used to be a lot of fun, with happy, competent people working as a team ... it was the best place to work.
pros: Fast-paced environment. Challenging and engaging.
cons:
Too many changes and re-orgs. Too many priorities and changes in focus. 
Management has not been able to move from tactical and reactive back to strategic thinking and solid execution.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Sunnyvale, CA
pros:
Working in the product development at NetApp for 8 years, I see the products fairly mature from a feature perspective. This gives an opportunity to work on some of the most technically challenging problems to make it even better. 
In short, there are lots of interesting and challenging technical problems to solve.
cons: System is complex and requires patience and lot of perseverance. The new grads get impatient and tend to quit. Need a more streamlined and soft initiation process for new college grads.

review_title: Need to transition to Cloud... Fast
pros: Great hardware, but software is showing its age.   The company has a underdog attitude, but may have gotten a little lazy in recent years.  Most of the frontline staff is sharp, and know what to do.  Question if management will listen to them.
cons: Unclear if management can tackle the job of transitioning to the cloud.  And they struggle with how to support the top public clouds and maintain strong partnership.   Complicated by two or three groups all trying to own strategy, without coordination.

review_title: NetApp - A Great Place to Work
pros: NetApp has is a great meritocricy.  People who work hard are recognized and compensated appropriately, people who do not are dealt with appropriately.  Beyond all the great benefits, free food, and parties, this is more important than anything at NetApp.
cons: Touchy feely employee culture.  Many of the employees get their "feelings hurt" too easily.

job_title: District Sales Manager in Vienna, VA
pros: The products work. The customers actually like the people who interface with them - and I think it is because the corporate culture values the employees and the customers. I have worked at several nightmarish companies and I have real scars to prove it.
cons: It's growth curve is so steep that planning for 3 years is dizzying. There are new employees showing up daily - and I have trouble keeping track.

review_title: A pretty good place to work
job_title: Member of Technical Staff  in Sunnyvale, CA
pros:
NetApp is a successful company with a lot of interesting technology.  Engineers with the right skills
and temperament have good opportunities to influence direction and produce innovations that make
a difference to the company's business.
cons:
NetApp is very inward looking.  The system can be bewildering in its complexity; many newcomers
have trouble mapping their past experience.  The company is best at evolutionary baby steps, and
often has a hard time getting new initiatives going.  Many people would say that the environment is chaotic.

pros: There isn't a perfect place to work, but NetApp is pretty damn close. Nice perks, great benefits. Very good training programs are available. Collaboration is very much encouraged. Mangement has been easy to get along with. You can tell this company has high standards. Upper management seems to communicate very well. Yes, we even get free beer on Fridays.
cons: Make sure they don't take too much of your time. Some perks are going away because of the bad economy right now, but everybody's doing that. Hopefully they'll bring most of it back when things improve.

pros: Some of the best reasons to work at NetApp is the culture, depending on your team, can be laid back. There are flexible working hours, options to telecommute, and some good people.
cons:
-Critical information not always shared down the ladder. 
-Probably the same at other companies but is it's not too difficult for people walking in the hallways to look up and smile at each other. So smile or at least recognize you're walking by a colleague.

review_title: They're tactical.  Not strategic.  Innovation lost.
pros: Benefits are great. Work life balance great, too.
cons: Upward mobility nearly impossible.  They hire externally and don't promote not within.

pros: Still an industry leader; old but solid technology base with interesting possibilities; good people and traces of the old NetApp linger on;  pay and benefits in line with other big companies.
cons: Big company attitudes; layoffs now almost routine; forced vacation; no equity for new hires--you are just a wage earner; morale-killing stack ranking; generally antiquated and heavy processes leading to low productivity; workspaces decreased to absolute minimum size tolerable by humans; top-down me-too "strategy"; lots of pressure to produce, but you are just a cog.

review_title: It was nice while it lasted...
pros:
There are (well, were...) a lot of good people at this company. I have met some great people here. Smart, hardworking, dedicated, caring - you name it. There is some great sense of camaraderie within a lot of the individual teams within the trenches. 

The pay and benefits package are nice. Good insurance, additional fringe benefits such as employee discounts, nice gym, good cafeteria, etc. 

Solid infrastructure and an IT team that's usually on the ball. Generally had no issues with onsite or remote network access, got a laptop ugprade every three years, intranet and related resources are pretty reliable, and was usually able to get the help or tools when needed (even though it can take a bit finding out where to get it). 

Top-level management consistently communicates to employees in a professional and informative manner, and appears to want to promote a positive culture of people wanting to do the right thing, being a great place to work, and being a good corporate citizen.
cons:
Perception and reality are far removed from each other regarding the "great place to work" claim for one of two possible reasons: 

1) Management just pushes the message of being a good place to work and caring about the people and the culture as a part of their well-paid job to carefully manage its identity and perception by employees and stockholders. In reality, they really don't care what goes on in the trenches, how people really feel, and the actual issues that can make work here really difficult sometimes. 

2) Management actually believes their own stuff they are dishing out to people about it being a good company with a good culture and good work environment; in reality, they are completely detached from what goes on in the trenches and haven't got the faintest idea of the real issues that the minions are facing daily. 

I haven't decided yet which one is the case...

Specific issues: 

There is an ever-growing rift between the minions in the trenches, middle-management, and top-level management. The vast majority of the minions are good people who just want to do their job well. Middle-management is mostly concerned about justifying their existence, playing the corporate game, and buying into and promoting the whole micromanagement/managing-by-numbers style, whether it actually makes sense or not. Top-level management, well, see above. 

The larger the company grows, the slower it gets. Creativity and productivity is getting choked by processes, micromanagement, and management by numbers. What used to be an easy task and could be done quickly with some lateral informal communication now has to be done by the book/up the chain. Yes, processes have their place and purpose, but not if they impede productivity and morale. 

Speaking of: morale has taken a nose-dive over the last year or so, especially in my area. The constant call for doing more, faster, with less is wearing people out. Schedules keep getting tighter and more aggressive. Management only seems to care about numbers and schedules and bottom lines. Budgets are getting tighter and tighter, hiring freezes, off-shoring work to India for cost savings, annual layoffs - you get the picture. Apart from the occasional beer bash or rah-rah speech or email, very little is done to help improve morale, motivate people in a positive manner, or curb the alarming, ever increasing attrition rate. 

It's really a shame. It used to be a good company, but things have gone downhill in many regards over the last few years. As a result, a lot of the talent has left for greener pastures.

review_title: Company is trying hard to turn things around
pros: NetApp has been a fantastic company to work at which has delivered outstanding products and services to it's customers. It embodies caring about the customer's ultimate success. Takes care of employees, treats them with respect and empowers them as much as possible to work through obstacles.
cons: Company has been attempting to transition itself for the last 3-4 years, and the target changed each of those years, so minimal progress was made. It seems like they have now set a firm target for what to change to in 2016, but by now the changes required to right the ship are drastic and painful.

review_title: NetApp was a great company once, could be great again
pros: Competitive pay, decent benefits, flexible work schedule, coworkers are generally friendly and willing to help
cons: Corporate culture is nonexistent (NetApp was consistently rated in the Top Ten places to work until 2013/14, but now barely makes top 100), senior leaders care more about shareholders than employees (and they do not attempt to hide that fact), company future is still uncertain

review_title: not the best place to work, maybe it used to be
job_title: Member Of Technical Staff in Sunnyvale, CA
pros:
Some  co-workers are nice.
Besides that, I cannot find any pros.
cons:
-package is not competitive
- not diversity
- very political,especially in the WAFL and Data Protection Group, managers don't care the product and their people, they only care how to look better in his/her boss's eyes and how to move up
- most of the managers are not fair, those who have good personal relationship with the managers no need to work and get promoted easily
- culture favors the person who can talk well, not the person who can work well but not good at talk

job_title: Software Engineering Intern in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Friendly people, great intern culture. We had leadership give us career talks and volunteering in the community opportunities.
cons: Unclear leadership, project design specs. Felt like my project was not very important, however I do know some interns who had better experiences. Company has a pretty old average age and not growing or changing very well against circumstances.

pros: Fast paced, energizing, when you are winning you get the recognition. Has the potential and the talent to dominate the market.
cons: Slow to change, even when everyone realizes it is time to. Staff get stuck on the how and rarely is someone empowered or takes the lead to drive it. Lack of clarity and support from executives.

job_title: Senior Engineer in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: good technology company with great engineers but with constant layoffs the good ones are leaving
cons: constant layoffs, bloated middle management

review_title: Great company, but make sure you're bullet-proof
pros: Excellent growth, fantastic culture for technical people.   Leadership is good, but unilateral. Company throws (or used to throw) great parties for customers and partners. There are lots of venues to learn and share information, but it really boils down to who you know and how much they trust you.  Tenure doesn't mean much since most of the senior staff have been there for long times, but if you're willing to work hard to get ahead, there's lots of opportunities.  You need to be able to recite technical documents  verbatim to impress senior leadership for promotions or raises.  Promotions won't come often, either, as they have more often gone outside of the company rather than promote from within any more, which is funny since that's how most senior leadership got to where they are.
cons: Blind to faults or shortcomings of products. Too much "build it because we know best" mentality.  There would be more career opportunities if the economy was better.  Recent reduction in force ensured senior management got their bonuses at the expense of those who lost their jobs.  Nothing noted or released to the press that the executives were foregoing their bonuses to keep the company in the black.  The culture is one of fostering growth, but the problem is that people hoard data and information to make themselves more important. There are also the usual "clique" type mentalities that have to be dealt with in order to get information and to get ahead. Leadership is good, but unilateral. You're expected to pull yourself up by your bootstraps without the moral boost if you don't work in a corporate office.

review_title: Not the same company it was a few years ago
pros:
NetApp as a company is great (but there's a sense that NetApp UK isn't really part of that company - we're more like a subsiduary).
There's plenty of work to keep you busy - There's always something that needs doing, and generally management keep pushing work onto people until they push back or quit. While many have left recently, there are still some very smart people here.
cons:
Chronic underinvestment in the whole UK business. 
Office facilities are appauling (not enough parking, one very unreliable coffee machine shared by about 60 people, often have to queue to use the toilet etc).
There's simply not enough pre-sales guys to support the sales reps, and as a result the pre-sales management have been trying to offload as much stuff from their pre-sales guys as possible. 
Over time this has lead to a pre-sales team which now has almost no technical knowledge. They can't perform a demo, they can't size a solution, they can't even talk for more than 5 minutes about core products & features. As a result, its become more of a struggle for an SE to actually convince a customer to buy anything, so instead they rely on the Consulting SE (CSE) team (which is 5 guys for the whole of the UK) to do all that stuff.
So basically, 5 people are doing all the actual presales work, and the SE team pretty much just organise meetings & conference calls.
Oh, and employees are gradually being treated worse and worse. It seems like the "great place to work" results are thrown around constantly by senior management to try and fool people into thinking this is a great place to work.

review_title: A great place to work, though frequently under pressure to deliver quality for customers.
job_title: Software Engineering Manager in Raleigh, NC
pros: Good benefits, positive environment, great upper management communication.  The corporate culture encourages participation and the communications of successes and things necessary for success are clearly outlined.
cons: Management tends to be "home grown" and not trained.  This leads to ambiguity of method, goals and a lack of clarity of where to go when there are problems.  Line employees are encouraged and developed.  Managers are left on their own.

review_title: Best Place to Work? Not really.  More like better than being unemployed.
job_title: Supply Chain Analyst in Sunnyvale, CA
pros:
HR does a great job with benefits and employee perks.  I firmly believe the reason NetApp is always in the top 10 of Fortune's Best Place to Work is due to the external factors that make employees happy - good benefits, pay is alright (I'm sure great for engineers and such), awesome cafeteria (not free food like Google but still good quality food), WFH program (if you could get your boss to approve it - our boss clamps down on it due to being in an order/sales support organization), the usual employee friendly things like Employee Appreciation Week (there's a whole shindig where you can take your kids on Family Day - petting zoo, crafts, face painting, the works).  

Very nice gym (again external employee perk - make sure your workload actually permits you to have time to go to the gym, lol)

Very nice campus and grounds (love the fountains, the infinity pool, walk ways, mini putting green, redwoods and maples - very zen)

Executives seem to have a clear vision of where to take the company.  Love that they make themselves available for new employees via TOAST (Training on All Special Things) - I was very motivated and pumped after TOAST.

People are genuinely nice and the teamwork mentality abounds.

Volunteer time off (VTO) - another employee perk.  How cool is this?  You get paid to volunteer at a charity of your choice or your group's choice.  I love VTO and this concept of giving time (rather than just money) to good causes.
cons:
Rotating to other functions is not encouraged at all.  Some folks in our group have been at their jobs for over 5 years!  While being a Subject Matter Expert is good, it also tends to breed complacency and resistance to change (notice that about my group).

Our middle management (people manager and director levels) prefer "youth" and seem to dismiss experience (i.e. people like me who are over 40 and have a lot of experience but cannot create a macro, lol.  I guess Excel macros are more important than real world experience).

I think this is where I take issue with the whole "Great Place to work" deal.  Externally, it does look like NetApp is a great place to work (see above pros).  But when it comes to professional advancement, gaining new skills, and mentoring, I don't see much at all.  "Moving around" seems to be discouraged or people just don't want to move around!  At least not in the sales support side.  And it is hard to transfer from one org to another (e.g., Sales support to Operations/Supply Chain).

Quality of middle management is average to inferior.  Very political. Lot of favoritism.

Groups do not have best practices.

Work-life balance does not exist.

job_title: Member of Technical Staff QA in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Some technology are still good.
cons:
After working one year at Netapp in Sunnyvale, I feel it is the worst decision I ever made to choose Netapp as my first job.
Salary is at best the market average in the bay area, most likely well below the market average. Name a company that's the same size with Netapp and easily you'll find out most of them pays better than Netapp.  Lay-off has become a habit whenever the revenue doesn't look good. Management aren't doing anything serious to bring the company back into growth. Morale is pretty low among the engineers and NCG keeps leaving within a year or two. Shut-down week happens twice in a year and if you don't take those days off as vacation, your income is impacted.  Good culture is going away.

review_title: Used to be "Great Place to Work"
pros: There are still some really good people left. Technology is exciting and quality is improving.
cons:
Too much negativity in the ranks, too many middle managers with no clue. Too much managing up.
The famous culture of candor doesn't exist anymore. Everyone is in it for himself. 
There is no way to advance within unless you weasel or brown-nose into it.

review_title: Many years on Forbes Best Places to Work
pros: The individual contributors and lower management are great to work with, providing a great day to day experience. Nice salaries and benefits.
cons: Upper management can't quite seem to get it right, and the company future has become very unstable. Recent layoffs have all but ensured that quality will suffer.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros:
Talented Engineers, Good Teamwork, Competitive Pay and Benefits.
Good technology domain. Fantastic culture.
cons:
Incessant Layoffs. Every year since 2011 there has been 7 to 10% layoffs and in 2016 two layoffs.
in the recent layoffs, the senior folks have been impacted since their benefits are higher. So senior folks better watch out. The constant chatter of upcoming layoffs or just concluded layoffs kills the morale. This was a great company once and i sincerely hope it returns to its past glory.

pros: Competitive salaries and benefits were pluses at NetApp.  The work perks that were available in Wichita were also great to have.  The people you work with are top notch and great to work with.
cons: At this time NetApp is very unstable and the layoff fears seem to always be in the back of everyone's mind.  Because of this, the competition component comes into play and people are looking out for themselves.

review_title: Houses fall into the ocean on schedule
pros: It is a large company with plenty of room for a person in their first 1-5 years of a function to grow.  All of the bells and whistles are there for benefits and you could raise a family easily by sticking with the company.
cons:
Like most companies who have transitioned from an aggressive tribe to civilized city dwellers, the more experience you have and greater desire to 'make a change' the greater your frustration will be.  That is unless you have moved passed this onto your Sunset life plan of being an invisible COG whose sole purpose is to meet about the meeting you are going to meet about.  In the early days the company was great, almost too good since it ruined people working anywhere else.  This came from the leadership in place and the passion they instilled into every person that worked there.  

Open Door Policy,... it was actually an open door policy to anyone you wanted access to but at the same time you had to be prepared to hold conversations as to not waste people's time.  People aggressively challenged ideas, not to tear you down, but to ensure that the idea was fully fleshed out before impacting customers.  You were treated like an adult, with an adult's career and with the expectation of doing the right thing,... like an adult.

This also lead to a 'middle out' company where the middle portion of leadership ran the day to day decision making process with the execs providing overarching strategic views.  Although execs got involved, they were wise enough to use their power in a limited fashion rather than crushing the people driving their vision.  Over time, this morphed into a top down approach as people fleeing from horrible companies further down the path to mediocrity could not wait to bring over the bad habits that destroyed their previous culture.

When you hear people speak positively about NetApp they are either,

a) Reminicing on what it used to be

or

b) Early in their career and it is absolutely an awesome time for them much like it would be anywhere they would work since,... well,... they are early in their careers.

Like the title of this review states, you could track the erosion on the company culture on a timeline so it is not a surprise that it fell down into being an IBM/Hitachi/EMC/Cisco clone.  Possibly a good thing, maybe the way things were was doomed to eventual failure, who knows, but that unique experiment deserved to continue on and it deserves to be noted as unique in an industry desperately needing originality.

review_title: Everyone has a right to their own opinion!
pros:
While making long term investments in technology that already passed them by, they took a big slide in the wrong direction. Any other company would've sunk OR been acquired but not NetApp! They changed their strategic direction by working out those that were stuck in the past, knew that making small strategic investments in existing 'hot tech' AND building new and existing partnerships with ALL the major players across HCI, Cloud and any complimentary tech, would be a catalyst for change. 

Change resulted in new and continued Pros, like:
Catapulted stock price
Dividends
Most competitive ESPP program in Tech world
Realistic forecasting that drove the street to believe we can deliver
ICP over 100% (with competitors getting little to NO bonuses in this macro environment)
Continual work/life balance that in unsurpased
Job satisfaction
Stability
Empowerment of employees in all functions at all levels
The belief that the turnaround is just the beginning of unlimited potential
cons:
As all companies that go through a macro change:
There will be some 'bad hires' in upper and lower management but again, everything is relative at a company of this size and our cultural has historically and continually worked out the bad seed.

People that become complacent and scorned about being required to be more efficient with less resources. Again, part of the growing process.

Risks that don't always pay off.

People impact (RIF, Layoffs or whatever you like to call it). When the previous regime over-invests in the wrong direction, everyone pays for it. New leadership had no choice but to right the ship, reduce cost and increase efficiency.   What we've been great at is our diligence to get great people back and forge ahead.

review_title: NetApp Mid-Management, don’t overlook loyal star-performers. Or your reqs will never close, boo...
pros:
- Amazing CEO George Kurian, a humble visionary who knows the tech
- Overall company values are great: integrity, dedication, passion for tech, heart for the customers
- NetApp is known as honest and “deliver-what-we-promise” company both in solutions and services, and in alliances and co-lab with other tech market champions
- Friday morning croissants 🥐 :)
cons:
- Annual salary rase mechanism  is barely keeping up with the yearly market inflation rate. It seems easier to negotiate a higher salary when you change position/manager horizontally, than to progress, if you are 3+ years in the same role. Even if you overachieve all goals of the previous year!
- NetApp mid-managers, stop fearing for your heads while managing budgets, spot & reward your stars, or they will go.
- Archaic annual review structure, 100 meetings about how it “changed” with the new HR tool. Where is the change? Still looking for it :)
- KPI’s too much based on what upper management tells to focus on (and boy, they really struggle to be concrete, but in the end of the day demand a lot). Too little interest in professional and personal development of individual contributors :(
- there is enough social althruists in the company keeping the culture alive and the company enjoyable to hundreds. Usually, these are just humble individual contributors, who get most “hi fives” on their floor or in the lunch cantine. Some of these wonderful givers organize sport tournaments, fun events and after-work drinks, some put many hours on top of their official 40+ into diversity and inclusion initiatives, setting up volunteer projects., etc. They often have little in common, but one thing: they are invisible to LOCAL (commercial) management and LOCAL HR. Again, NetApp, recognize your givers or they will get tired....

review_title: A good place to work, warts and all
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Waltham, MA
pros:
It's a friendly, open atmosphere.  Decisions are explained and consensus is important.
Humor is evident and encouraged.
cons:
Very shaky and yet somewhat arrogant IT.
Some insulated engineers who don't seem to understand industry best practices and think their ideas are revolutionary.

pros: good compensation. Respected company. If you are going to be working in the main headquarters @ Sunnyvale Ca. it is a different company. Very up beat and positive. If you are in the field there are none of the benefits.
cons: Current cutbacks seriously hamper your ability to sell. NetApp is a great, growing company. They are a small company that got really big, really fast. They are not an enterprise player as they tout. They do not understand the concepts of selling in an enterprise space.

review_title: Depends on the function you support...
job_title: Member of Technical Staff IV in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Reasonably good communication from upper management and engineering management. The majority of engineers and managers in dev, qa and tech mktg (especially the old timers) are great to work with and for. Competent, dedicated and solution oriented.
cons: During the hiring frenzy of 2005, engineering brought in some real deadwood senior managers, more than should be expected in any company this size. Those managers proceeded to hire or refer their incompetent buddies.

review_title: Can be rewarding for serious engineers.
job_title: Member of Technical Staff III in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Smart People. Great Technology. Lots to Learn. No shortage of work. Nice surrounding living area. Relaxed work environment. Flexible Hours. Decent compensation. Free beer.
cons: Growing process-oriented culture hampers innovation. Constant fighting of battles to obtain permission from peer engineering groups for project go-ahead. Not enough heads to tackle the massive work charter.

job_title: Order Management Specialist in Beaverton, OR
pros: Truly deserves their ranking of one of the Top 10 places to work.  There's lots of upward mobility potential if you live in Silicone Valley, Wichita, KS, or North Carolina.
cons: No longer an office in Oregon.  Would love to continue to work for this company, however they have very limited Telecommute opportunities, and it is extraordinarily expensive to live in CA so relocation isn't really a viable option for most.

review_title: Good company to work for if you are interested in Protocols, Low level coding and in general, Systems programming
pros: Nice work atmosphere, employees and managers are really cool. You might end up having to be a workaholic depending on the team.
cons: Not sure how the company's long term path might fit your careers goals, especially if you are starting as an NCG at NetApp. They do not have too many new projects, so you will end up fixing a lot of Bugs along with a few features. Most of the code has already been developed.

job_title: Marketing Events Manager in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: I worked for NetApp for 3 years. I came to NetApp as part of an acquisition. I was a contractor for 18 months (which is the longest you can contract there in one position) and I was finally converted.
cons: Being part of an acquisition didn't lend to the most positive work environment. Our business unit always felt as though we were the red-head step child. Everyone talked about how wonderful the company culture was, but I am not sure I experienced it the same way. Not to say that things were bad, but it wasn't the most amazing work environment.

review_title: No longer a great place to work
pros:
Great talent, good people, competitive compensation and benefits. 

When the subject of conversation is what we're working on and how we're doing our jobs, people are motivated and creative. Unfortunately, the company no longer values those qualities.
cons:
Morale is poor and the future is shaky.  Everyone has to watch their back. Do not recommend to new hires.

Employees cannot trust anyone in upper management. CEO uses silly words like "transformation" what he means is major layoffs and outsourcing to India. No innovation anymore, just working and reworking of old technology.

review_title: Not the NetApp from 5 years ago...
pros: Competitive compensation, great benefits, beer bash.  NetApp culture is still kept by most people, so you'll find great people to work with everywhere at NetApp.
cons: Layoffs every year, company direction doesn't seem to be solid.  NetApp used to be ranked in the top Best Places to Work At for many consecutive years.  Unfortunately, it is nowhere to be found in the list over the last 3 years.

job_title: Inside Sales in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Great people to work with.
cons: I came to NetApp expecting a great experience buy ultimately got coal for Christmas. the pay is below average for inside sales the benefits are standard fare and the morale is dirt low.  If you are looking for a job it's a higher paid stop gap but not a place to build a career.

review_title: Lackluster career opportunities with a tactical leadership team.
pros: The non-executive people that work at the company are very kind. I felt a great sense of inclusion from my peers immediately.
cons: Executive leadership is not strategic. Decisions are made, then immediately retracted. The VP level+ club operates in a bubble, with little understanding of the business and or the ramifications of their decisions.

pros: NetApp gives employees flextime and the ability to work from home.  NetApp also has volunteer hours that you can use to take time off for volunteering.
cons: Although the company has grown larger, the back office infrastructure investment has been lagging behind.   Although this is changing in certain areas, it is still very difficult to implement process improvement (for happy customers and happy employees) due to the inflexible systems.  Middle management quality is hit or miss.

pros:
good benefits
AMAZING peers
really innovative people
cons:
promotions recently have gone to pushy, hyper competitive people which does NOT reward NetApp's professed culture of One Team.
too many directors, not enough people who do work getting recognized
a lot of "we're a 5 billion dollar company, to get to $10 billion we need to...." directly and exactly reflects Sun Microsystems....

review_title: Best company I've every worked for, more like a family than a corporation.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Extremely flexible with employee environment, work remote, in the office, etc. as long as the employee is productive, that's what matters, not where.  Excellent benefits, consistent incentives, and very open policy with annual bonus/salary increases.  Some of the most intelligent engineers on the planet and the product innovations show it.
cons: Challenging to work with product management and upper management when neither comes from engineering.  The technical leadership (TDs) help overcome this.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: It's hard to believe that I'm going to celebrate 8 years at NetApp this summer. I'm often asked in interviews what I like most about NetApp or why I'm still here. While I could wax on for an hour about "my why", the answer is simple. I love who I have become while being a part of this team. The team, the challenges, the people, the killer technology and the opportunities have been more than I could have possibly imagined. I wonder how many people feel that way about their career and job?
cons: Compensation could be more competitive

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Great Benefits.  40 hours of volunteer time each year.  Great 401k matching.  Employees want to help each other.  Weekly Friday beer bash.  Flexible work environment and great work life balance.
cons: Culture tends to lean toward risk averse which can make it difficult to move quickly to get something done.  I don't this this is different from other companies but it is definitely not a startup type culture anymore.

pros: Semi-competative salary.  Decent health benefits.  Standard vacation plan (3 weeks to start).
cons:
POLITICAL.  Middle management is willing to throw you under the bus!  More red tape than action.  Spends money on crap projects and delays things that are worth-while.  Extremely short-sighted management.  It wasn't like that in the beginning.  

It amazes me that they have been able to stay anywhere on the great places to work list!  They won't stay there for long.  Employees are leaving the sinking ship in droves!

pros: Decent salary, Free snacks, Transport after 8 PM, Work from home options, You will get lot of stocks if you are great performer
cons: Struggling company , layoff's once in a year, No salary increments, benefits are going down every passing year,  Inhumanly project schedules(They expect you to work like donkey still you know the schedule is just impossible)

job_title: Member Technical Staff, Software in Waltham, MA
pros:
- Smart people, Teams focused on getting things done.
- Free Breakfast, Beer Bash on Fridays and Mid-week Free lunches.
cons:
- Processes have crept in a little too much lately and acts as an impediment to being productive as an engineer.
- Interviewing bars are not the same compared to say a couple of years ago across different teams.
- Promotions and performance based incentives are clearly lacking.

pros: I truly can't think of any. The work/life balance isn't too bad...
cons: NetApp is a behemoth of an organization where you can expect little meaning in your work and minimal creative ability. The left hand has no idea what the right is doing and they force you to take vacation days (or go unpaid) for two weeks per year. Everyone is siloed in their departments and don't do much more than is asked of them. Their systems are outdated and the supervision is weak. Avoid this place at all costs unless you're fine to disappear within your department and just play it "safe" in your career. If you're a visionary who wants to change the status quo, stay away.

pros: Great compensation and benefits. Good values, employees treat each other well. Doesn't micromanage people, employees have a lot freedom to "do the right thing".
cons: NetApp has made several strategic mistakes over the years and is now paying for them. For example, NetApp was too late to get on board with the flash revolution and instead of doing an acquisition they started the Mars project which ran for 3 years w/o delivering a product and then it got cancelled.

review_title: NTAP will emerge from the tough times ahead
pros: NetApp focuses on 3 differentiators - Culture, Partnerships and Innovation. Culture is a big thing for the company and if you are of the right fit then it is a great place to work. It is a relatively transparent and open organisation. NTAP needs to find its position in the market. They are not agile enough or innovative enough any more. A reset is on its way.
cons: Going through big transitions - recent lay offs/restructuring will affect the morale and key personnel will move on but opportunities will emerge as a result.

review_title: Pretty good way to start career
pros: People are quite friendly and helpful, the campus has lots of amenities like the gym, badminton, basketball, volleyball courts, the company is doing well financially
cons: Salary for freshers is a little less compared to other IT companies, the work one is given is highly dependent on the team, the mid-level managers seem confused with decision-making sometimes

job_title: Technical Support Engineer in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Their IT staff is top notch.  I didn't work in IT, but their ability to organize their IT staff was really good.  Their intranet is chock full of technical details of their product, and its' design, and their engineers are generally eager to share information.
cons: When i was there there was a bit of lazy that had set in from too much success after a high riding stock, and a pretty great success in the market.  Now that they are fighting for market share in new places, that must be shrinking.

pros:
Sunnyvale has a really nice modern campus and buildings..
Standard benefits for a high-tech company in Silicon Valley, and the benefits are really over and above if you have children.

Until a few years ago, we knew we were making a difference, knew we were helping to build something great, knew we were making history. We knew we were working too hard, and being paid too little, consuming more late night pizza and cola than bears thinking about, but wow, we were really having fun. We were all empowered to take risks, to innovate, and to drive change. Managers did real work. Executive management did a fantastic job with the vision, finances, etc; and was open, honest, trustworthy. Employees were loyal, and dedicated to doing something we could be proud of, and winning. It was all incredibly satisfying.
cons:
Employees are no longer empowered to innovate.
Management is making decisions for political or CYA reasons, rather than strategic reasons.
