Middle managers hired from the outside by friends inside, or promoted from within to their level of incompetence. 
Too many people doing little or nothing. Really good people let go in last Feb layoffs, and so many useless people retained, and still wandering around doing nothing. Incomprehensible.
Products go to market too fast. Too many bugs. 
Infrastructure is falling apart, and funding to replace it is scarce or non-existent. IT seems to be exhausted (though that seems to be the case almost everywhere).

NetApp is no different from any other company now. As it matures, it is becoming fearful of change, inflexible, process heavy, hiring managers who are killing the once-extraordinary culture very rapidly, and hiring average or incompetent individual contributors who are just looking for a paycheck. Many formerly dedicated employees are becoming recruitable. There is a steady trickle out of people who cared, and when the job market gets easier,  my guess is that it will be a rolling river.

review_title: Good to get into storage software domain
job_title: Member of Technical Staff, Software in Bangalore
pros: Netapp is a great company if one wants to get into the storage software domain. If you get to work in the filesystems or kernel team; it's a good learning experience.
cons:
1) Salary is not competetive anymore
2)  There is a lack of trust towards newer members in the company. If you are a new member working on the filer; you will have to cross numerous prejudices to add any substantial code to the codebase.

review_title: Great company with great opportunities that know how to go after them
job_title: Systems Engineer Manager in Washington, DC
pros: The company is really growing fast with lots of new opportunities all of the time. The benefits are very good and most of the people are really focused and work hard. There is pretty good comradely and almost everyone is willing to jump in to a situation and help.
cons: As the company grows not everyone has the same entrepreneurial spirit. Some come aboard thinking it is a big company and they simply have to focus on their little piece. Those people don't go far and as you look through the reviews it is easy to find them.

job_title: Human Resources Manager in Sunnyvale, CA
pros:
Good people
Opportunity to make an impact
cons:
Culture is fading
Sr leadership not making bold, innovative decisions
Lack of planning leads to snap decisions and changes mid stream

review_title: Incredible co-workers, Horrid Management.  Company leaders have derailed the advertised culture.
pros: Incredible co-workers that are highly intelligent, sharp, and good people by nature.
cons:
Management cripples employees, has their own individual agenda that in turn leads to chaos, a lot of wasted cycles, and a highly political environment.  Being thrown under the bus is such a common occurrence, one might think their desk is on the 405 at rush hour in LA.  Two years prior to my employment, sales reps averaged 200% of goal.  The two years of my employment, sales reps averaged 70% of goal.  The path they are headed on is not one that is righting the ship.

Contractors are treated as second class.  Beer bashes and the fact that the company serves beer on Friday's is used as propaganda to encourage contractors into filling out favorable employment surveys that are used to attract great talent that will quickly be turned over.  For some reason, these contractors are hired in large numbers just before employment surveys are sent out by Forbes, GPTW, etc.

On the beer note, it is not uncommon for a manager to selectively wait a few weeks for an employee to attend a "beer bash".  Once the manager sees an employees has had a beer, management has been known to slide a yearly review in front of them without any prior notice that the yearly review will occur with the goal of procuring a rubber stamp approval.  It might just be me, but I thought yearly reviews should be scheduled and not be conducted when an employee has had a beer that was encouraged and paid for by management.

review_title: Needs improvement and it seems to be heading that way
pros: In years where the business is good there can be a lot of money to be made at NetApp.  Benefits are good and it's a great place to learn a lot in a short amount of time.
cons: The company made a big bet on it's clustered ONTAP product, ignoring other emerging technologies like flash, which has cost them dearly in the market.  Because of this mis-step the company has been in a transitional period for several years now and is doing layoffs twice a year.  So job stability is now a concern at a company that used to seem immune to those sort of problems.  The cuts have been so deep that much of their top talent was either impacted directly or got fed up and left.

pros: Great work life balance. Especially if you work 3 day weekend or 4 tens. Pay is great! Training is near perfect. They give you all the tools needed to be successful.  Very relaxed atmosphere and non strict dress code. You can literally work in shorts and a T-shirt. Each team is very close. I enjoy beer bash and dart wars!
cons: You have to worry about layoffs.  A lot of products which is over saturated I’m my opinion. Need to innovate more.

review_title: Nice place to work with good salary package
pros: Nice  money package. Good work culture and excellent people around you.  Management is very communicative about all news floating inside and outside company. Transparent communication across employee level.
cons: Internal politics happen during promotions or giving bonus package to employee. Promotions not happening at right time is sometime annoying. That can help some good people to stay in firm for longer tenure.

review_title: Overall, a very good place to work
pros:
•	Strong culture
•	Excellent compensation
•	Collaborative environment
•	Great co-workers and team
•	Work Hard/Play Hard mentality
•	Strong executive leadership 
•	Ability to be creative and do your job autonomously
cons:
•	A lot of politics and bureaucracy for a ‘small’ company
•	Why change it if it isn’t broken mentality doesn’t consider changing it because it is no longer applicable for a larger population
•	Managers generally focus less on managing people than other work deliverables
•	Huge lack of infrastructure
•	Too focused on contractor/temp hires versus building and growing in-house talent

review_title: The NetApp culture is the best that I have experienced.
pros: I have the privilege with working with some of the most talented individuals in the industry, given the challenging changing environment that we are in, migrating to the cloud.  Pay and benefits are on par with the best in the industry.
cons: In HW engineering, lack of the ability to advance.  Company develops experts of certain portions of the position skill sets, and were not always able to fully utilize individual skill sets.

pros: Great work environment. Smart people. A collaborative environment where people help each other. I've worked here for 8 years and compared to other Fortune 500 companies I've worked before, NetApp is far and away the best!  It's an environment where the company trusts employees to get their jobs done and empowers us to make important business decisions at every level.
cons: NetApp promotes work/life balance which does not equal laziness as some have suggested. It hasn't been my experience.

review_title: Great place to work, very slow to change
pros: Great place to work with top executives (SVP and above) continue to focus on new technology innovation, operational excellence and culture.
cons: Entry level and mid managers/directors/sr. directors are very slow to adopt changes. This causes many great leaders who were driving change left NetApp due to significant political pressure from those who are against change.

pros:
* Very good culture, you'll want to spend a lot of time here.
* very good office
*Zumba, Yoga, gym - all very nice
* TT table, Badminton court etc
* No hierarchy
* Good pay
*Its a multi national with start up culture which is slowly changing
*People rarely quit the firm
cons:
*The company is in a transition mode, hopefully it will be back on track
* The management should try and retain the culture that everyone is so fond of.
* Lot of competition to get converted from contract worker to permanent worker.

job_title: Member Technical Staff in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Good people. Good products. Good vision. Interesting work.
cons: The constant focus on cost cutting has produced an environment of nervousness among employees due to the excessive use of layoffs.

pros: NetApp is a technology leader in lot of areas and there are good opportunities to work on cutting edge technologies
cons: Old boys clubs and cliques are very common in most functional groups. If you are not part of it you will be sidelined during opportunities, growth, rewards, etc. Pay for performance is a lip-service for HR, in reality it is all politics and nepotism that determines your pay.

review_title: Fine if you are in SVL or RTP
pros:
Flexibility
Pay
Company Management
C level staff pulled the company through the recession  greatly.
Company really believes the great place to work mantra
cons:
Life in a remote field office is nothing like life in RTP or Sunnyvale.
Employees are ornery. New blood is needed. Employees are just bouncing between emc netapp, oracle, and hitatchi.
IT moves at a glacial pace and have decided to outsource most IT Roles.

review_title: Super nice people but company is stuck
pros: It's a top ranking "Great Places to Work" because people are very nice, lack of ugly politics
cons: senior leaders are in biggest jobs they've had and they are way over their head. Decisions made on relationships, company is risk-adverse, lack of accountability, consensus decision making to the point of insanity. Poor execution. The CEO and many of his old timers need to move on.

pros: Friendly, flexible, good people to work with.  Benefits are good.  Good work-life balance.  Nice family-friendly company events.  People want to do well.  Management strives to maintain a good culture.
cons: Large company processes impede efficiency.  Inconsistent middle management.  Recent business climate has made rather difficult decisions emerge that impacted ability to effectively perform.  We are constantly being asked to do more with less.

review_title: Work life balance is the main positive point
pros: Office culture is good: a sense of mutual respect is there. Flexible timings and less formality in interaction with manager. Work from home option also adds to flexible work schedule. Offers some facility in Employee health care.
cons: Package is not competitive at all. Moreover Micro managing has also started.  Work life balance actually depends on group and manager.  NetApp has good technical talent but lacks good managerial talent. Growth is not as used to be 3-4 years before.

pros: This company has great products, and greatly values customer satisfaction. I think they will turn things around and be a more stable company in the future.
cons: However, if you are not a sales person, I don't believe you are truly valued, especially outside of the corporate headquarters. There is little room for growth or career development for operational personnel outside of Sunnyvale.

pros: The perks are good - volunteer time, freedom of hours, bagel and beer Friday.   If you're in, then it's very good.  If you're not in though....
cons: Very nepotistic.  People who had been there 10+ years couldn't advance because they didn't "play the game".  Management seems to prepping the company for buyout by not listening to customers on cDOT.

review_title: Did not adapt to game change
job_title: Manager, Analyst Relations in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Known for being named on Forbes Best Places to Work. Great work/life balance. Took advantage of corporate gym. Good people to work with in marketing, but lots of churn. Worked under two different CMOs within two years.
cons: Recognized the industry's move to cloud computing and doubled down on existing proprietary hardware/software. Disappointed Wall Street and layoffs have been ongoing since 2013. Hopefully the new CEO can turn things around.

pros: Strong salaries; pleasant colleagues, fruit on Tuesday and bagels on Friday. CEO/CFO are fairly transparent with strategy and success/failures of specific products.
cons:
Company culture is not to offend anyone so unanimous agreement is required to move projects. Oftentimes results in projects taking much longer to complete at a higher cost or momentum slows down and projects are closed down.

Many tenured employees doing it the "NetApp" way and are reluctant to entertain new ideas. 

Transformation resulted in lack of opportunities by not promoting. People are unable to rotate to new teams as teams are not able to backfill for lost resources.

review_title: A good place to work for indeed but not among the best
job_title: Member Technical Staff, Software in Bangalore
pros: what makes Netapp different from others is its culture. The work environment is very conducive. Peers as well as managers are very co-operative.
cons: Doesn't get to work on any cutting edge technology. As the company has increased manifolds in past 5-6 years, the standard of facilities has decreased. Compensation is not as competitive as used to be.  High attrition rate has been observed because of bad policies. Not enough career growth rate in terms of technical expertise.

pros: As a former long term NetApp employee I can say technical work is never boring. Working from home is a possibility or if you don't want to commute because of the weather. Management is generally flexible if you need some time for personal business. Coworkers are great. Perks like food and beer Fridays are ok - but unnecessary.
cons:
Management expects you as a rule to work at home in the evenings and on weekends. Assignments, goals, and expectations are not clear and consistently lead to surprises at review time . this seems to be the norm for senior level individual contributors.  

Despite suggestions of an open door policy critizing the way programs / projects are managed, complaints about managers, or other items are held against you. Expect that your comments will come around to haunt you either by a direct confrontation or in the form of limited projects. 

NetApp corp spends way to much time patting themselves on the back as a great place to work. Understand that NetApp is a public corporation out to make the bottom line. They have layoffs like everyone else and no one is immune - except management. I've never seen a manager at any level laid off -- despite having some that need to be. Management doesn't give employees a chance to switch departments prior to layoffs. Older employees seem to the top layoff candidates despite performance. They layoff just enough younger workers corporate wide to avoid discrimination charges. It seems clear that NetApp doesn't want anyone over 45 working for them. 

Lots and lots of managers and groups whose purpose seems unclear. Their functionality is never explained. 

Raises and stock options are scare and only given to the employees that receive the highest rating.

pros: NetApp is a medium sized Fortune 500 company which has been around since 1992. The people are really great to work with here, from all walks of life. There is a sense of helpfulness.  The population at HQ is diverse, challenging, respectful, and full of intelligent individuals.  It is neither a progressive high tech company, nor a stagnant old school dead wood place.  It is somewhere in between with a good feel.  There are people that have stayed here over 10 years as well as those that put in 2 and leave.
cons: The culture seems tied down, silo'd departments that don't talk.  NetApp hires well, good skills sets, fine employees, however they are not given the ability to use the skills where it would matter most.  Management does not empower their lower level who are fully capable to make decisions- and have a proven track record in the past.  The decision process takes way too long and involves too many.  Even for the smallest change there has to be a "Project".  Too many projects that used to be referred to as "goals" .  Too many non-involved groups have to have a say,  which creates indecisiveness, and this makes NetApp slow to improve, slow to change, update,  and most likely why they are not number one in their industry.

review_title: NetApp was a great company to work for, but became too big.
pros:
The work was very interesting - don't underestimate storage software.
Great coworkers - lots of friendly, family-oriented people.
Beer bash every Friday.
Really good work/life balance.
cons:
Too many projects spread out across too many time zones.
Too many layers of management.
Not enough internal opportunities for career advancement.
Promotions for political reasons and not based on actual abilities.
Layoffs of talented senior and junio people (don't worry, they all got jobs immediately at NetApp competitors down the street).

review_title: Was great, now is in a freefall
pros: Good Benefits.  Pay is good.  Some of the people are great.
cons: To numerous to count.  1. Saving judgement on Kurian, the rest of the team needs to move on.  They don't work well together.  Sales leadership (TG and RS) are old re-treads that need to go.  Noviello is dangerous and untrustworthy.  2. Company missed the changing industry and now cannot compete. 3. Too much politics.  Too much focus on investors.  Attrition is at an all time high.

review_title: Can be an OK place to work
pros: Established Fortune 1000 customer base, many very loyal to NetApp. Lots of ammenities:  gym, dry cleaning, nice cafe, car oil change service.  Easy enough to change jobs within the company.  Can be a good place to work, like anywhere, it depends on your manager.
cons: Recent management turmoil, slow to innovate and missing changes in the market place, therefore losing market share.

review_title: Worked at NetApp for the past 2 years
job_title: Member of Technical Staff QA in Vancouver, BC
pros: Lots of benefits and perks from working at NetApp.  Great working environment with a focus on innovation, the latest trends and teams are generally tightly knit.  Skills are easily transferrable to new jobs as well.
cons: I feel that there can be a disconnect from upper management sometimes, working with offshore teams can be difficult.  However management often tries their best to mitigate these issues.

job_title: Member of Technical Staff IV in Cranberry Township, PA
pros: I work at a smaller site which is held in very high regard.
cons:
As many old and current employees would tell you, this was a truly great place to work at one point and for a long time. Not anymore.
I am an eye witness to that culture changing.
NetApp is truly a pay for performance company though. You work crazy and put in the time, you are well taken care off for the most part. But 5 layoffs in the past 3+ years has changed a lot of things.

job_title: Senior Engineering Manager in Wichita, KS
pros: Supportive engineering environment with high quality talent.
cons: Company has not kept up with the market's shift to the cloud. They are scurrying quickly to catch up but are 3-5 years behind the market. This is causing them lay off people to cover the costs of this transformation. There are way to many executive management levels adding more operating costs.

review_title: not the greatest place to work
job_title: Software QA Engineer in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: work-life balance, good people, decent benefits
cons: frequent layoffs, poor management,low raises, no path for advancement

review_title: Still the best game in town
job_title: Escalations Engineer V in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros:
Technology-oriented, leader in the industry.
Good pay despite hearing tons of gripes, still has very good benefits.
Small Silicon Valley culture still present for us old folk.
cons:
Cronyism has been rampant lately, recruiting poor, big company attitude seems almost welcome by many.
Promotions are inconsistent (dumb people getting better jobs, good people being passed over repeatedly)
Stock awards have dropped to maybe one-tenth of what they used to offer (used to get 2000 options for a good job, now you get 200)

review_title: Great place to work, if you have a good manager.
pros:
What you can accomplish here is basically limited only by *you*.  If you see something that needs doing, it's not *that* hard to sell it and get started.  There's a lot of freedom here.  At the same time, if you're a junior person looking to learn stuff, there are great mentors here.  If you're technical, don't be put off by the idea that this is a storage outfit; there are all kinds of interesting things to work on here.

Great communication from upper management.  I used to work at a place where you'd read something about your company in the paper before you'd hear it from The Boss; here, they trust you not to share information with 200 of your closest friends in the securities industry.  And speaking of the boss, our chairman/CEO and the president/COO are outstanding guys.  You know that they're interested in the company's future and not in this just to get rich themselves (Dan would have quit a long time ago if that were the case).  They are here to create an enduring organization that will contribute to the industry long-term, and thus have no problem telling the stock analysts, "We're gonna invest in the company's future, rather than doing artificial stuff to make you guys happy this quarter."  I love it when execs at a public company this size can say that -- and do!
cons:
As someone else has noted, we're trying to grow into the size we've become.  Though the small-company feel is great, it comes at the price of some immaturity in the area of "processes."  So we've got to work on that.

A lot of your experience at NetApp (as anywhere) depends on who your direct supervisor is; get assigned to a bad one and things will not be so happy.

review_title: Coming to work for NetApp was the best career move
job_title: Technical Marketing Engineer in Raleigh, NC
pros: NetApp provides interesting challenges  daily, this company stretches the abilities of its people and encourage constant growth.  In five years, I have never been bored.  NetApp provides spot bonuses for excellent work, Friday beer bashes, and phone calls from Board members as recognition of excellence.  On top of all of this, the employees are the very best and brightest in the industry.  For the past fifteen years, NetApp senior management has been dedicated to fostering a happy culture.
cons: I have no negative comments about my company.

review_title: Middle management out of touch, overly political - smacks of Sun in 2005.
pros:
Great work life balance (although many, many, many people take advantage of it)
Work from home is okay, by manager.
Paychecks don't bounce  - yet.
cons:
POLITICAL, POLITICAL, POLITICAL - Marketing morale is awful, Alliance Management is bleeding people.
Middle management (from Group/1st line and up to VP) is clueless about the dissatisfaction and therefore can't fix it.
No room for individual growth.
Mentoring program is a joke.
TOXIC work environment. Only reason it's a GPTW incumbent is because there's an entire HR department dedicated to it - and yearly bonuses are tied to it. Incent people with $ and they'll rate ya, why not?

review_title: Great place to work, just going through a little rough patch
pros:
Very supportive SE management team who are genuinely interested in hiring quality people and developing talent.
Very liberal work-home life balance - work from home at your own discretion when not required for face-to-face meetings. Doctors, Dentist appointments etc come out of work time with no questions asked.
Every company has some bad eggs, but at NetApp the people are of a generally high calibre, a pleasure to work with and you can rely upon them. This is something I've really struggled to find elsewhere.
Expenses are very liberal with SEs like me actively encouraged to entertain customers / partners to build our own relationships in social environments.
Lots of opportunities for progression and active participation in anything you find that doesn't fall under the remit of your day job.
cons:
There has been a higher than normal level of attrition in the past 12-24 months with several long standing employees leaving. Reasons for this vary with no common theme. Some cite the change of NetApp from a small company to a big one with the influx of too much bureaucracy and process. I personally think this just brings a different type of challenge and it might mean we need different types of people to overcome it.
Financial packages are generally not quite as high as you probably could get elsewhere if you are a high achiever.
SE management is currently in a state of transition and trying to figure out what it wants to be. There is some frustration in the business about the slow reactions of this management team and the fact that they are all people managers rather than technical leaders.
There is a major product transition going on at NetApp as we take customers from 7-mode to Clustered Data ONTAP and it is creating a lot of pain for both customers and field sales. The corporate message is that the destination is worth the journey and if I put my hand on my heart I think it is, but it still makes it stressful sometimes when you're the one having to make that journey day in day out.

review_title: Superb company that truly understands work/life balance. Everyone is friendly. NetApp embraces positive company culture!
pros: Clear communication of all top-down company plans and strategies via multiple channels. Managers and directors are in place to support and help excel their under employees. The company culture of hard work, team collaboration, and friendliness is preserved and encouraged highly. NetApp compensates employees well with salaries, stocks, bonuses, plenty of vacation time, etc. Superb medical insurance and benefit options. More than anything, at NetApp, if you are creative, can think outside the box for new or improved ways to do something, part of NetApp's culture is to embrace those ideas and give employees opportunities to foster those ideas. NetApp has been known to "purge" employed individuals that have later been found to not align well with the company culture. In other words, those that do not "fit in" well with the culture, tend not to stay long. That's how seriously this company values its rich culture. Lastly, every quarter, NetApp throws beer bash events for employees only which are great. Also NetApp has fun family and kid oriented events around the big holidays. HQ has a state of the art workout gym facility.
cons: In my experience, I've found that moving around inside and advancing inside the company is encouraged and welcomed but is not always advantageous from a monetary perspective. But that was just my experience. That may not be the case in every event. NetApp has very good products that customers appreciate however NetApp product is VERY expensive compared to some competitors. NetApp is not growing exponentially as it once did, instead growth leveling off in some markets. This changes thing

review_title: OK, but losing its sheen rapidly!
pros:
1. Generally good work-life balance.
2. Lots to do if you are motivated and supported.
cons:
1. No clear owner for projects and releases.
2. Too many forced shutdowns take away all your vacation days.
3. Resistance to work on innovative products and technologies.
4. Lot of politics at higher level, both technical and managerial.

job_title: Senior Finance Manager in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Still some really good talent there who still believe in what was once good company.   But maybe not for long as attrition is high.
cons: Little opportunity for advancement or promotion.   Lots of attrition of really good talent with no chance to backfill.   People remaining just have to do more with less.

review_title: Good company, currently going through a tough phase
pros:
Top notch CEO in George Kurian, an aggressive, intelligent chap with great potential to take NetApp to new heights. 

Very employee friendly work environment. Brilliant products.
cons: Very slow to adapt to changing market dynamics. Taken too long to recognize and act towards strong trends of cloud storage, distributed shared-nothing storage, new age distributed databases.

review_title: They used to be a great company but slowly got taken over by old network of complacent management
job_title: Escalation Engineer in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: A good starting ground to gain knowledge in the storage industry. Used to have lots of perks, not sure about now. The technology is lagging behind all of the new modular storage options.
cons: Lots of politics, therefore there were lots of people scared to open their mouth and share their opinions. Managers play favorites and can be vindictive. Male dominated environment.

review_title: A great employer with great technology to sell
pros: good management in most cases. social mingling and exchange of ideas among different departments. smart people. great benefits package, great cafes for lunch, flexible schedules. ability to be creative in how programs are built and executed, ability to take the initiative and bring a program to the next level. pride in garnering industry recognition. having a unique, useful product/solution to pit against established industry leaders. accessibility to management, excellent internal communications worldwide, instant notification from management on critical or competitive situations. team work and spirit, colleagues who go the extra mile in most cases. respect for maintaining a work/life balance, e.g., with employees with families, children and interests outside of work. information all-hands meetings on a regular basis to keep all employees aligned on corporate goals and marching in one direction. growing site at corporate location, i.e., new buildings and parking structures to accommodate head count. great espresso machines in each building! Reasonable budgeting and resources, while not ever enough, are bearable and don't give cause to 12-hour days most of the year. good intranet site that's packed with resources and even easier to navigate today.
cons: Not always being recognized for a job well done. A fast growing team sometimes built from ties and employee relations at previous companies, not necessarily always with consideration as to whether a job candidate has qualified or optimal professional backgrounds for a role. Corporate politics, as with any corporation. Bureaucracy, which NetApp is building up in order to analyze operations and streamline efficiencies, and will likely get somewhat thicker before it dies down. The flattening of the employee hierarchy, giving rise to numerous levels of even middle management. Enthusiastic team members, who sometimes expect others to be logged on to email as late as they are. dubious search engine on intranet site. too many contractors who come and go, in some cases.

review_title: Fun and interesting place to work; still growing into its current size.
job_title: Senior Manager, Engineering in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Good management, not perfect but communicative and open.  Good open-door policies, people who really like what they do, still has lots of small-company feel to it even though it's gotten pretty big.
cons: NetApp is struggling a little bit to bridge the gap between being a small company and a big company; some of the energy and fun is getting left behind.

review_title: Wins Great Place To Work awards by rigging the deck
pros:
Great heritage, I'd know after 10+ years
Still sells stuff
Comp package is pretty good for sales.  Not cutting edge, just pretty good
Good cash flow.  At this point there is not a lot of risk working here in terms of getting paid
cons:
-Innovation USED to be tops.  Absolutely stagnating now. 
-Company is MAJORLY cheap. Cut virtually all sales perks, no more kickoffs to motivate nor much else in terms of perks
-A train wreck in the acquisions department.  Gosh.  Just check the records...pretty much every one of them is either terminated, or is limping along. ByCast will be the next tombstone, and the wailing of the banshee will be heard for LSI eventually.  Another company falls prey to NetApp.
-Won't even spring for some swag on occasion for their top customers. Like, seriously folks...we're talking cheap. 
-Margins to rewards ratio is disgusting.  They're between 62 and 72% gross margin depending on the geo, and again the company is too cheap to share in praise with employees who got them there
-As the title indicates, the GPTW survey is totally contrived. They USED to be, not so much anymore. 
-Support organization is crippled.  If you still decide to join and sell for these bozos, then for heavens sake only sell Premium support (contributing to their GROSS gross margins) as Standard and Warranty support are beyond bad. 
-They swindled me, a many year veteran of final commissions even tho I gave proper two weeks notice (HR and Payroll Dept have made countless mistakes over the years without taking any responsibility for their actions, or humbling themselves to apologize for mistakes)

pros: Good products, decent benefits. Some flexibility in work schedule (but not enough).
cons: Lack of opportunities for growth, too many office politics for an organization of this size. I'm all for collaborating with colleagues, but the over collaborative culture breeds a lack of responsibility and accountability. There is a lack of transparency with some of the leadership. All of this combines to make this "not a best place to work" for those employees that are not satisfied with mediocre results.

review_title: Good work life balance, facilities, technology but worst Politics in some non Data Ontap departments. Lobby culture.
job_title: Member Technical Staff, Software in Bangalore
pros:
1. Work life balance.
2. Office facilities, free beverages, snacks , beer etc.
3. Technology exposure.
cons:
1. Worst in politics.
2. Lobby culture. People will try to revenge in groups. Can go to any extent. No ethical boundaries.
3. Unstable for sometime. Firings and restructuring.
4. Management in non Data Ontap departments is very immature and incapable.
5. Polishing is open and seems defacto expectation within all levels of management.

4.

pros: I am a mother of 2 kids. I think I did not quit after my second child only because of the work culture in Netapp. Very flexible and great work culture. Managers value the work life balance and support the career paths.
cons: Currently company is not doing good due to strategy issues but I think its just a temporary phase and Netapp will come over it since the product portfolio is good.

review_title: Great Place to Work with some ifs and buts
pros:
1) Work Life Balance (2 company wide shutdowns lasting approx. 10 days each), Work From Home option available
2) Weekly Beer Bashes
3) Good technology and interesting projects to work on.
4) Very cooperative peers with amazing technical knowledge
cons:
1) Company's profit margins down. Past 4 quarters were rather weak
2) Lots of inter-team politics. Sometimes you need to literally bug other teams repeatedly to get things done.
3) Irresponsible management

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Great opportunity to learn technologies.
cons: staff cuts most years.  no movement upwards.  difficult to move out of support.  customer support changes to process come about with little warning.  upper management believe micro management is the correct style.

review_title: Lot of politics if you're in a large group
pros: Good work-life balance, good food on fridays, good work life balance and if you work hard and impress your boss you might get good salaries
cons: If you are a part of a large group you need to always compete with peers for promotion, salary and projects. It used to be a nice company to work  for but with high attrition rate, and layoffs, the dev-qa ratio is smaller and manual testers are becoming a burden for testing. Automation engineers are overloaded with work.

job_title: Inside Sales Account Manager in Raleigh, NC
pros: Broad and flexible solution stack to implement storage "your way" for private, public, and cloud.   Strong Industry Alliances and Partnerships.  Great culture.  Well positioned to adapt and grow in the market.
cons: For some some job functions, there is a lack of structured pathways for internal career advancement or diversification.  Without that structure, an employee could be blind to new opportunities that could perfectly match their strengths.  One the same token, a hiring team may be blind to the best available internal talent.

pros:
The engineering (and the company) has certainly turned around from its internet "everyone love's us" days. 
* Business oriented in its investment choices and taking good somewhat scary risks -- science projects are dying or dead.
* Competitive and aggressive against the market -- agile and other adaptive thinking are not buzzwords but part of the culture
* Customer focus (instead of itself as a customer) is king in quality and making smart calls on features (including removal)
* Excellent learning and growth environment for unseasoned and willing to learn extrovert driven personalities

Company:
* Growing with increasing smart product portfolio set
* Go to market and aggressive market is real not a buzzword
* Taking away market share from top 5 companies!
* Transparency (ignoring one aspect) is as good as it gets with insider trading information restrictions and other sensitive areas.

Benefits:
* Highly competitive and reasonably measured across the board from health to 401k to insurance
* Awesome set of bonus options from spot, restrictive stock and more
* Salary competitive by region. 
* Additional large location perks such as in-company high end cafeterias at certain sites
cons:
* Some groups are still broken and working in those groups or getting hired into them is a problem 
* IT is mediocre, cyber security fear mongers kill productivity and spending dollars on shiny reporting mechanisms trump improving engineering productivity
* Management processes for promotion and merit still lopsided against technical skill. Traditional management track thinking which can promote great team people who are technically mediocre.
* It isn't clear what lingering impact of many sets of layoffs have done.

review_title: Worked at NetApp for more than 3 years
pros:
Great work culture
Flexible schedule
Good compensation and benefits
Great co-workers
Very friendly atmosphere
Good work life balance
WFH options depending on the manager
Paternity leave, PTO
Good bonus, RSUs, ESPP  etc. 
Beer bash on payday Fridays, 
Lots of VTO opportunities for those who'd like it.
Opportunities to work across different business units, different locations, cross functionally
cons:
Frequent layoffs is  real thing here.  They are usually small and not notified by the upper management. More BS from the upper management during all hands. Needless to say not only it has impacted the morale of the employees and eventually it resulted in huge distrust towards upper management.  

Many highly experienced, very resourceful and loyal  people were impacted by transformations (a netapp euphemism for layoffs,  it's an ongoing thing according to them) over the last few years. Lack of any training available for young inexperienced engineers. NetApp doesn't invest on developing young talent.  Pennywise and pound foolish attitude sometimes.

Many experienced  folks are retired/retiring and lot of their tribal knowledge is lost.  Young engineers have to go through constant uphill battle to learn new technology and  current trends in their roles themselves in order to stay relevant in the industry. 
 
Heavily relies on outsourcing business model.  Real work has become less and less over the years and it's a major threat to job security overall. Like other major storage players, much of the engineering has been outsourced to Asia/India to save money.  As an engineer you'll be end up doing very little technical work sometimes. More focus on meeting the tight schedule and very little on the quality of product.

Upper management favor a particular business unit, while others hardly get any recognition. 

   Less exposure to new technologies, lack of innovation, less challenging environment which can hinder your career progress. 

 Lots of process documents and meetings to improve processes even though people hardly follow any processes.

review_title: It's no accident NetApp is consistently voted a best place to work
pros: Great people, great management, excellent benefits, products that are unique and therefore easy to sell. Company is growing, and a testament to the customer value of the products is that NetApp grew during the recent economic downturn.
cons:
Understaffed in some areas results in overworked staff in those areas.
Top focus areas get all the attention and funding, resulting in disenchantment elsewhere.

review_title: Now that netapp is no more a small company, Needs a change in perspective internally.
job_title: Member of Technical Staff II in Bangalore
pros:
- Beer bash.
- Cool Culture.
- Flexible in terms of WFH or work timing.
- Work-Life balance is awesome.
cons:
- Pay is not as good as HYPED in market.
- Management is seriously crippled here, due to which hardwork doesnot gets payed always. Promotion depends more on manager's choice, No questions asked by upper management.
- No transparency in performance review. 
- Not much difference in compensation between people working hard and people hardly working.

job_title: Member of Technical Staff IV in Bangalore
pros:
-- The best thing I liked about NetApp is that most of the time I get to decide what I want to work on.  There is a lot of trust in engineers and the managers don't micro manage
-- weekly Beer Bash
-- Good decent size personal cubicles
cons: If you don't know storage, will take you a lot of time to start delivering. Only engineers who have been associated with the company long enough like 7+ years are trusted by senior management and not many growth opportunities are given to new guys even if there capable

pros: Amazing company culture.  On boarding classes are phenomenal.  I have a great boss, competitive salary and am overall very happy.  The company moves fairly quickly given its size and doesn't get complacent with its success.
cons: The only thing I would like to see changed is the vacation/sick time allocation.  They currently split your time off between vacation and sick time, which leaves you with a ton of sick time but very little actual vacation time.

review_title: Its a great place to get exposed to vertical stack in Data Storage industry, but process overhead slows down innovation.
job_title: Member of Technical Staff III in Sunnyvale, CA
pros:
- Pretty good work life balance, especially if you are coming straight out of college.
- Since, it has a strong foot hold in the data storage market, you get exposed to all interacting components in the eco-system like customers and partners using the data storage.
- Some really knowledgable, dedicated engineers to boost your domain knowledge and technical skillset in C/C++, data structures and algorithms.
- Has really good tie-ups with some universities, allowing you opportunity to attended conferences from industry experts.
cons:
- Code base being huge and old, ramp up time is pretty high. Due to this, need to spend a lot of time digging into details in your area of work, which leaves very little time to explore other components.
- The technical skillset and culture is very inconsistent across teams. Some teams have excellent senior engineers and managers, and some teams seriously lack the technical expertise and strong management which could slow down your progress tremendously.
- Unfair performance evaluation of employees, as managers could lack technical expertise and domain knowledge. This leads to dissatisfaction for dedicated, passionate engineers who deliver on their targets, but are not compensated fairly, relative to the rest of the group.
- Interviews were not taken seriously for some hires for senior positions, leading to a lackluster group, devoid of good mentors. So, the interview questions for the group, should give you an idea of the competency of the group.
- No useful technical feedback from some managers, as they are not technically equipped to understand your challenges.

pros: Good working environment, friendly and supporting team, Nice Benefits, and  Super strong culture $ value. The career developing classes in NetApp helps younger employees and New College Grads to quickly adapt working environment.
cons: Need more employees at different ages to create more connection links between each other. Everything else is pretty good. Can't complain about working life here.

pros: Flexibility, autonomy, fair pay, decent benefits, good culture, nice campus and work environment. I am fortunate to have a great manager, so that makes things great here.
cons: No growth, so fewer opportunities to advance, leadership at top doesn't seem to be able to respond to changing markets. Budget constraints right now, which makes getting things done even harder.

review_title: A few Executives at the very top do not practice core values that are apparently to be followed
pros: Nice people - cafeteria food is sort of nice I guess
cons: A lot of talk of strategy and values but execution is totally stuck  - right now there is complete panic and fear and too many controls to succeed- teams that could collaborate together are not  - loosing people rapidly and the good ones staying behind are not getting any salary increases - bad bad

review_title: Company needs to change its strategy. Faster innovation and execution is required.
pros: Transparent culture and good work life balance. Lots of good technical folks specializing in systems software, storage and filesystems.
cons: Very low synergy among internal business units. Widespread "not invented here" syndrome creates barriers for adoption of new technologies. Too much focus on a single, monolithic product.

review_title: Great pay and benefits, future with company always in question.
